column9: These are excellent earbuds. Great sound quality, build, appearance. They pair quickly and easily, can be optionally controlled from an app, and have a great color scheme. The black with copper accents is particularly sharp, but the silver is also excellent. They slip easily into their battery carry case, which is a bit on the large side but does have rounded corners and a sturdy magnetic lid that stays shut. I especially liked the voice prompts that let me know what the various control taps on the left and right were doing. The sound is punchy and has plenty of bass, without being strident or boomy. Highly recommended.

Just inboxed these and all I can say is wow. Sound quality is fantastic, noise canceling works as advertised, synced right out of the box no problem. I avoided the app as there where too many negative reviews. I used the largest earpiece and they fit nice and tight. Another thing I like is they don’t stick out to far from my ears. As of now I am more than satisfied. We shall see how they work under workout situation tomorrow. Update-the app works fine. Maybe a little slow but useful in tweaking your sound preferences. After using a few days they are still great. My only gripe is their sensitivity on taps seems to be sporadic as sometimes it takes double taps or harder taps to work the controls.

I've had these headphones in my possession for a couple days, and I have to say they live up to my expectations. I was looking at getting a WH-1000XM3 (the full-sized headphones) to use in my office, where I have both noisy neighbors and a loud HVAC system to deal with, but when I saw these come up for pre-order I thought they might work better for my use case (aka, not on an airplane). So far, here's the pros: Battery life is directly on the mark with what's advertised. I used it in my office with noise cancelling on, volume at mid-levels from 11-5 before the left earphone actually died. The right still had 20% - maybe using the touch controls for playback a lot causes quicker battery drain? Along with battery levels, charging from the case also seems on the mark. After the earbuds died, I threw them in the case and left for a quick walk. 20 minutes later, my right earbud went from 20%->100%, and the left from 0%->70%. Excellent imo, this more or less means I can just recharge my earbuds whenever I have a brief conversation with a coworker and never have to worry about the battery dying on me. Music quality is great. These sound excellent on the "Excited" EQ preset to me, and I rotate through all kinds of genres, from (electronic) hardcore, 80s city pop, 00's nu and death metal, pop and R&B and rap. The noise cancelling - honestly, on a first wear, I was slightly disappointed. I had read the pre-release reviews about how great it was, but when I started to use it out the box, I could still hear people talking to me. Really, these won't block out loud/direct conversations, but that doesn't diminish their usefulness. It completely eliminates the fairly loud HVAC noise in my office, and makes mouse clicks/non-mechanical keyboard usage fade out. And that's without music playing. Once you add music to the mix, these really do block out the world really effectively, even on low volumes. I actually had a coworker today try to get my attention for a minute, of which I noticed nothing, before they resorted to a loud knock on my desk, which I actually thought was a part of the ambient soundtrack I was listening to at first. Very impressed with the noise cancelling when combined with music, and even on its own with my tempered expectations. They're not earplugs, but they're pretty darn close. A quick note: Using full noise cancelling when walking outside results in some annoying wind noise, but there's a preset called "wind noise" one step below full noise cancelling in the app that will completely kill that wind noise and still block other noises very well. Connectivity is great. No issues connecting it to my TV, computer, Android phone, or iPad. Protip: Hold the touch sensitive button on both ears for 7 seconds to enter pairing mode for connecting to a computer or non-Android/IOS device easily. The cons (aka, why I'm saying 4.5 stars): No wireless charging. It's a shame with the bulky case, and would make things way more convenient. No volume controls/option for volume controls. Having to open use my device to change volume all the time is kind of more annoying than I originally thought it would be. No way to quickly change noise cancelling modes without the app. Those last two points are fairly understandable given the small(ish) size of the buds, but still would have been nice. The ambient pass-through mode does work perfectly once you enable it in the app though. Overall, I really like these things and I'm super satisfied with the risk I took ordering them before reviews came out. If you're on the fence, I'd buy these. I'll update this review in the future if I have any other complaints/issues, but I'm honestly really happy with these. EDIT 8-12-19: Two weeks have passed since I wrote this and I have a couple updates. One, you actually can quickly change the noise cancelling level by setting one of the touch controls to "ambient sound control" in the app. This lets you toggle between a couple different noise cancelling modes with a tap. I've also started to use the adaptive sound control option, which I've found to be pretty accurate and useful. I have mine set up so it's in full noise cancelling when I'm sitting still, wind noise reduction when walking, ambient sound level 10 when running and full noise cancelling when on transportation. I've only really tested the first two options since I don't run nor commute by public transit, but the app switches modes pretty quickly and it's convenient when I decide to go for a quick walk while working. I've also noticed that every so often I do lose sync between sounds/video when connected to my tv, but it often fixes itself pretty quickly, or a pause-play will fix it as well. I haven't noticed it on my phone, so it's likely a mix of distance and the Bluetooth chipset on the TV.

column8: My Ideal Kind of Wireless Earbuds
column9: The following is my first impression after receiving them in the mail today and WOW I am ecstatic. I currently have the first generation AirPods, the overhead WH-1000XM3s and now these earbud WF-1000XM3s. I really liked the convenience and the decent sound quality of the AirPods but unfortunately didn't like how easy it was to hear my surroundings, especially while lifting in the gym, and had to raise the volume so high. The build quality is excellent. The case overall is a sturdy plastic with a nice matte feel and is light weight which will be great for travel despite being bigger than the AirPods case. There are individual LED indicators on each earbud and on the case itself to allow you to know when its charging. I also like the flat, glossy circle on each earbud and how they are touch sensitive so I can use that to control the music as well as the noise cancelling features. Another thing I appreciate is how they give you 6 additional sets of earbud tips in order to allow you to find your perfect, personal fit. In terms of looks, I find it to be a classy look. It definitely doesn't look bulky, (like an oversized bug sitting in your ear) and it feels light weight, being overall comfortable. However, I do have some big ears that stick out like open car doors so your own experience may vary from mine. The fit of the AirPods never bothered me either but it would after a few hours. In terms of sound quality and noise cancelling, I find it to be excellent. My music library consists of mostly hip hop/lo-fi music and these have great bass without being overly "boomy" nor too tight. There is definitely a punch you will feel greater than the AirPods. I'm no audiophile with knowledge of mids and highs but I do think they are great for the average listener with a bass preference. To top it off, they are noise cancelling (!) and I find them to work surprisingly well blocking ambient noise. In comparison to the WH-1000XM3s, of course it is definitely not as precise, the noise cancelling is noticeably better and the sound stage on those headphones is large/more open. However, given the obvious size difference in consideration, these earbuds are a delight. In summary, I think these will end up replacing my AirPods. I liked those but I love these for its noise cancelling (which will be perfect for lifting in the gym), greater bass and overall sound quality along with its style. However, for enjoying a full listening experience while not actively moving or traveling, I will stick to my overhead WH-1000XM3s.

column8: Amazing for iOS and Android. Mediocre for Mac or PC listening
column9: I was so excited to get my hands on the Sony WF-1000XM3 ANC earphones! They definitely sound incredible on mobile with their ANC capabilities and are way more isolating than the Powerbeats Pro but if you are in an iPhone/iPad/Mac universe, go with the Powerbeats Pro. The XM3 performance on Mac is terrible, low audio volume and no punch ⚡️ On iOS and Android you can get the app to tune the sound which works very well, but on Mac there is no such app so the sound flat and low. Very underwhelming 👎

I just received my buds earlier today. Put in the medium foam tips and wore them for about 3 hours. They blow my anker liberty lites out of the water when it comes to sound quality, probably on par with my low end bose over ear headphones. Pairing is a breeze and noise cancelling works great. Overall love them so far.

Sony's reputation comes through in this offering of the WF-1000XM3! Wow, the sound I expected would be fantastic, better than my three other over-ear and in-ear sets except Sennheiser, but the noise cancelling is amazing for a product so light and mobile as this. Now the noise cancelling is augmented with the seal of in-ear, but riding in a car / crowded bus, and walk just take you away from everything. As to the design, I love the form factor which allows for gesture support to navigate through ambient noise levels for hearing those around you, as well as audio playback volume and start / stop. I had the Bragi Dash a few years ago and that surface area to perform gestures on those is what made be fall for the Sony WF-1000XM3s and I was not disappointed. Further the look with both black and silver (more like a manila or tan) as not as dorky looking as AirPods. Apple could have done AirPods in black to alievete the dork factor, but apparently choose not to. The Sony WF-1000XM3 buds have the same well machined feel typical of other Sony products. They magnetically snap into their respective left / right bezel in the charging case and the case charges with USB-C. I look forward to a QI charging case, but that's just being a bit picky on my part. Another update I'd love to see is a water resistant set with official IP rating; again nitpicky on my part. Overall, these pair of ear buds changed everything in a very unexpected way for me. I sold off my pair of Sony WH-1000XM3 over-ear headphones as well as my Bose QuiteComfort 35 IIs. I expect both of these over-ear offerings to drop in price because of the Sony WF-1000XM3 and for good reason. I honestly am blow away by these and certainly recommend anyone get them at least to try, they are a game-changer!
How does this thing aim to compete with the Airpods? Neither pairs through NFC or Bluetooth with my Samsung Galaxy Note 9. It's a disaster.

Let me start off by saying I wear some kind of headphones every time I leave the house, when I'm commuting to work, when I grocery shop, when I work out, when I'm clothes shopping, etc. and for the cost being higher than airpods I expected a lot more. Pros - the case is a lot sleeker and more stylish than the airpods case, the music equalizer has pretty great pre-installed settings, they come with multiple ear pods for a smooth fit and noise cancellation Cons -I have tried every single size of the ear cushions and no matter what 10 - 20 minutes later I feel them slipping out -the noise cancellation only works with an airtight seal in your ear -you are instructed to download apps and for the life of me I can't figure out what one of them is supposed to do, when I open it and select library it just opens my apple music app which I don't need a shortcut for -the touch censor on the side is so sensitive if my hair touches my right ear at all the song gets paused so I ended up turning the touch censor off entirely -the supposed long lasting battery went down 10% with 15 minutes of music play which was disappointing since they're supposed to last 24 hour -The sound quality is not worth the cost at all, the sound is the most important part of headphones and they sound like a pair of drug store headphones Sony makes amazing over the ear headphones with impeccable sound quality and they have wireless over ear headphones that I would invest in twice over before getting a pair of these.

I just received my pre-order of the Sony WF-1000XM3 earbuds. I expect a quality product from Sony but these earbuds far exceeded my expectations. The noise canceling technology is awesome and the sound quality is a 10 out of 10. I would highly recommend these earbuds to anyone.

column8: Best truly wireless headphones on the market today, with some battery and bluetooth bugs
column9: So by and large, I love these in ear headphones. They have the best sound and noise canceling features of any headphone of its kind on the market right now! Now onto some of the bad- on two separate occasions, both the left and the right earbud drained battery inexplicably, and occasionally while walking through the city I’ll get a stuttering skipping affect inside of the earbuds, even though it is set to focus on stable connection through the Sony app. At a price point like this quite frankly, it is unacceptable. I have since requested a replacement in the hopes that I just got a bad apple. These two things aside however, they are still the best headphones for the money- bar none!

column8: No real noise cancellation - defective product?
column9: No noise cancellation compared to the WH-1000XM3 I own. The sound is just muffled by the earpieces with external sound amplified or not by the system depending on the level you chose. Switching on/off NC does not change anything. With the headset, turning it on gives you an impressive immersion experience into silence. With this one, nothing. Could be a defective product, returning and will not try further. Not that if not properly fitted, will fall off easily. No water resistance, so forget it for the gym - will likely fall anyway, even properly adjusted. Will keep enjoying the WH headset, which is fantastic and has a real and super effective noise cancellation (and a much better sound than the last super expensive and plasticky Bose.

column8: Great sound Quality, Good Noise Canceling but not Great.
column9: I received my earbuds yesterday, I have been using them nonstop. So far I can say that the noise canceling is good but not great. In an environment with too much noise, the noise-canceling does a good job, but you can still hear some noise. What I love about the features is that with a touch you can deactivate the noise-canceling and hear normally, even better conversations from the people around you. So If you're buying a Starbucks, you can hear perfectly to the bartender shout your name. The earbuds are extremely comfortables and music bass is Great! Definitely worth my money.

These completely demolish any earbud that I’ve ever purchased, and to some degree some over ear headphones. Unlike most earbuds, the sound isn’t piercing in your ear with many of the highs and snares that some songs emphasize. Balance is a very strong point for these buds. Noise cancelling works very well, as well as the ambient mode. I did have to change the tips on the earbuds, but that’s expected. I wore these for a few hours yesterday, and didn’t get fatigued for a while, but at some point fatigue is inevitable with anything on or in your ear.

column8: Had them for ONE DAY and the LEFT EARBUD CRAPPED OUT
column9: Received these just a day ago. Everything went well. Noise canceling is pretty good. After 24hrs of use the LEFT EARBUD is not charging or pairing. (SEE PICTURE). Not sure how good SONY's Quality control is. This is my first time buying a Sony Product and am a bit disappointed. Have had the Apple Airpods for 3.5 years and they still work flawlessly albeit the battery life is a bit dismal. Getting a replacement soon but they won't ship out till August 9th, so it's back to the Airpods. If you are considering buying one, definitely opt for some sort of warranty. This incidence has made be lose faith a little in the quality control. Let see how the new pairs that I am getting hold up. I will update the review. UPDATE: So I did find the manual on how to reset the pairing by holding down the BUD for 10 seconds while they are IN THE CASE. So far that worked well .But there is ONE MORE ISSUE. THE right pair's battery DEPLETES MUCH FASTER. So both start at 100 then, one goes to 70. I DID GET A REPLACEMENT. So the depletion ISSUE is NON EXISTENT in the new pair. I am returning the buggy ones. So if you have the 1st issue, keep the buds and do a reset but if it is the 2nd ISSUE. Return it. I will see how the 2nd PAIR holds up and then update. So far the 2nd pair is doing fine.

column8: Possibly needs a firmware update to fix the poor mic sound transmission quality
column9: The reception sound quality is great. The mic sound transmission is choppy--people keep telling me it's hard to hear me and the sound is inconsistent. Let's hope a firmware update fixes the mic issue. I'm still getting used to the controls which are not very intuitive. The Sony iPhone headphone app doesn't consistently connect to the earbuds. The noise cancellation is decent for earbuds. I haven't had the time to test the battery life. The bluetooth distance seems fine--I can walk around my house without any crackling. I may return these.
Outstanding performance and sound quality. Just make sure to get a good seal, adjust the sound using the Sony app and get ready for some great music listening.

Great sound quality, noise cancellation and fits great in the ears. I also like the graphic equalizer that once set works regardless of which app I'm listening to audio with. Well done! For those complaining about a tinny sound or noise cancelling not working very well, my experience is once you've found the right earbuds that are making a good seal both problems go away and the sound is excellent! I had to go up a size, the earbuds that come already attached are the 2nd to largest, for me switching to the largest made the noise cancelling much better.

column8: Close to be the king of true wireless buds
column9: Pros , good sound Amazing ANC , great Bluetooth connection,, Cons , might not be waterproof
Awesome sound and overall quality. I’d buy it again!

column8: Best Sounding True Wireless Buds. Period. Battery Life so-so. Weird Noise cancelling issue
column9: I wasn't expecting to like these as much as I do because all I really care about is sound quality. When I heard these did not support Sony's own LDAC higher-res Bluetooth codec, and also did not support any of the APTX codecs, I was concerned that the sound would be limited and that nosie cancelling would cut into the bass and midrange frequency responses. I was totally wrong. I have had them over a week, and have not picked up my Galaxy Buds or Bragi Dash Pros ( which, three years on, are still the standard bearer for full featured true wireless buds) or even my 1More Quad driver wired earbuds since. The reason is simple: they sound damned good. They are better, by far, than any other true wireless earbuds, including the Sennheisers, the Jaybirds, and the new 1More true wireless buds. They have plenty of bass, but don't dump it on you like so many cheaper or lifestyle/branding phones (Beats, etc.). With these, the bass notes are still musical notes, not just vibrating punches in the head. The sound stage is open and airy, even competing with some of the better wired earphones like the 1More Quad driver buds. There is an ease and sweetness to the output that make it easy to listen for hours and that no other true wireless buds have. Cons: - no wireless charging; - the case is too big - they protrude from the ear more than the Galaxy Buds or Bragi Dash Pros. You can't lie down on your side with these in your ear - everyone says battery life is 5-6 hours. So far, I am maybe getting 4 - Adaptive Sound Control is pretty useless. Turn it off. - Significant wind noise ADDED when noise cancelling is turned on I set mine to maximum noise cancelling, which blocks out virtually everything, opening the sound stage even more. But a weird issue has arisen. On this setting (with ambient sound control turned off), I get some very noticeable wind noise. If I cycle through taps, first turning noise cancelling off and ambient sound on, and and then tap again so that ambient sound control is off, I hear ZERO wind noise. I hear a little bit more general background noise, but zero wind. if I tap to "noise cancelling" again, the overall sound deadens, but wind noise starts to come through. I assume this is because with noise cancelling on, the buds microphones are listening to outside sound so that the buds software can cancel it. But the software is not fast enough to catch wind? Weird. My solution is to set the buds to ambient sound control off instead of noise cancelling if I am in any breezy/windy environment. But if your primary concern is sound quality, buy these now. You will not regret it.
I can’t believe these earbuds sound the way they do. They sound better than many high-end over the ear headphones. I highly recommend these things

Here is what I love about these wireless earbuds. The sound is SO much better than I was expecting! Clean, precise base, and incredible highs. Also, I love the charging case, and it is well made and attractive, more significant than Apple's earbuds case. I'm not too fond of the look, sound, and practical use of Apple's earbuds. (They look like small Q-tips hanging from people's ears). Not to mention the one size fit's all, that Apple forces on its customers. Sony's noise cancellation feature is near perfect, and the battery is beyond adequate. I don't see myself listening to anything for more than six hours at a time. Your mileage may vary. The sound quality while playing Spotify and Amazon music was borderline sublime. If Sony were to update this product to play high-resolution files, they could take my money a.s.a.p!

column8: Amazing Playback & Noise Cancellation, Not-So-Great Mic (2nd gen Airpods comparison)
column9: I pre-ordered the WF-1000XM3 to pair with my iPhone X after initial impressions collected online and the earbuds DELIVERED on sound playback, noise cancellation, and battery life. I purchased in order to compare to my Airpods 2nd gen; there are plenty of editorial write-ups online done by pros that cover all the granular details but here are a few notes I think worth sharing: - Paired, Airpods (2nd gen) are a fraction of a second faster to connect than the Sonys when it comes to playback - Sony Headphones app used to control XM3 features and settings is a bit slow to connect to the XM3s (8-10 secs). Pay off is customizable equalizer and sound cancellation that are unavailable with Airpods - Sound quality of XM3 microphone is average. Sony's chip cannot compete with Apple on the sensitivity to decibel levels -- the Airpods are able to record (and playback) whispered conversations whereas the XM3 mic simply does not pick up on low decibel audio activity. I used the iOS voice memo app and checked the frequency activity and could can tell right how much more effective the Airpods were. That said if you project your voice enough for everyone to hear in an average sized room then the XM3 will be fine but anything that is considered soft will annoy you like the coworker of yours on a conference call that is 15 feet away from speakerphone. In summary I'm a bit conflicted -- I wanted something that can be optimized for work and play but unless I'm willing to own both pairs, I'm going to have to lean towards the Airpods for now; nothing is more irritating than being misheard or inaudible during a call. My recommendation is if you travel or commute quite a bit and need the sound cancellation then go with the Sonys and just remember to speak up. Soft talkers should look elsewhere.
Really uncomfortable, keeps falling, couldn't use it for more than 30 minutes because it felt so weird.

the sound quality are amazing. the noise cancellation is not that great due to tips not really giving a good isolation seal. 2 days of use and the left side just died, no i was not working out, running or anything just listing and the left side just died it wont even turn on. I really wanted to keep them :(

column8: Great Promised but Bricked After A Few Hours
column9: I received the product and immediately - and successfully - paired it with my phone. The noise cancellation and audio quality was outstanding. The reviews on voice quality were mixed but I planned to give it a few more tests. Unfortunately, the left ear bud stopped receiving audio after just a few hours of use. Looking online, there are several identical incidents. I went through normal troubleshooting including removing and repairing and several complete factory resets. No luck. Returning to Amazon but unfortunately more than a week away from receiving a replacement. EDITED: I received the replacement and am happier but they are still not close to perfect. The audio quality is outstanding and if you are purchasing them only for music, go for it. The microphone is poor, so if you plan to use them for calls, plan on having people annoyed on the other end of the line. Unlike Airpods, voice dictation or anything requiring character recognition on an IVR is impossible. For example, the American Airlines IVR could not detect my birthday or frequently flyer number using these while it was no problem with Airpods. They also randomly drop calls much more than they should (or much more than any reasonable person would expect). Again, the noise cancellation and music audio quality is solid. The microphone is poor. Also, the app is poorly developed with a terrible UI and limited functionality. I'll bump this up to 2 stars but the mic issue is frustrating.

column8: These Are Good But Depends on Preference
column9: I like the design of the charging set and earbuds. Set up on iPhone was a breeze, and the optimization with different size silicone ear tips exceptional enabling the buds to fit snug. The multi-function touch pads for each side for easy music, sound variations, cell phone, and Google Assistant pairing. As far as sound it comes down to preference. Obviously wireless buds have improved but for these being Sony the sound is more smooth and crisp rather than loud and bass. I like to FEEL the music so I favor loud and bass, especially when working out. If that’s you I’d suggest going sign Dre’s or Bose. I maxed out the loudness and bass yet it still doesn’t feel right. The Noise Canceling does work and there is an Ambient Sound function. The box says it can be paired with Google Assistant which o didn’t try. Too bad it doesn’t work with Siri like it’s other competitors so that’s another con in my book. The touch pads are very sensitive which is good when needed to control music especially when exercising. Good pair of earbuds but personally I’d go with Dre’s or Bose before these for loud and bass quality.

column8: Far Superior to Bose and Sennheiser. Crushes AirPods.
column9: I've had the opportunity to sample some of the latest True Wireless products and over-ear headphones currently on the market. Suffice to say, when I had the opportunity to review the new WF-1000MX3, I took it. The charging case featured a silky, back neoprene finish with an elegant copper lid. The texture of the black plastic finish and copper accents on the headphones were tasteful and understated. The opening of the lid was smooth, and the lights on the case indicating the charge status were quite helpful. Putting the headphones in my ear were a piece of cake; all I had to do was insert the foam tip and slightly twist the headphones counter-clockwise until they were comfortably secure. Pairing the XM3s to my iPhone X was a simple task. But the sound; the sound blew me away immediately. After owning Apple AirPods for over half a year, as well as trying the Sennheiser Momentum True Wireless and Bose headphones, I was totally shocked at how much better the sound was and how Sony could pack so many features into a such a portable product. The new noise cancelling chip completely eliminated the chatter surrounding me while the driver brought the concert to my ears! These are truly audiophile quality headphones with the ability for adjustments via the Sony Headphones Connect app. The Google Assistant integration makes these wireless earphones allow me to interact with my smart home and calendar without ever touching my phone. I cannot wait to purchase my own pair and enjoy my music, and nothing else.

column8: Best wireless earbuds I have ever used
column9: I love how these ear bugs fit and sound. They have very easy to operate controls and a nice app too. The volume could be a little higher and volume control on board would be nice so that you would not have to reach for your phone to control. Overall the work well with my iPhone 6s Plus.

column8: The worst purchase in a while
column9: After looking at the positive reviews on youtube and all the tech sites, I was excited about the earphones. But it was a epic fail. The earphones fell off multiple times in a couple of days use. Which is ironic because the Apple airpods never had such an issue. The design of this one is poor as the width of the earphones is the culprit. The noise cancellation is terrible too. My in-flight experience with it the litmus test where it failed miserably. Bose is still a gold standard no matter how many paid reviews rave about Sony noise cancellation. It's absolutely worthless. The Bluetooth connection kept dropping off and the awkward pairing process didn't help either. I am delighted to return it before I lose an earphone. Will wait for Bose to come up with their version in 2020.

column8: Easy to use once you get it set up.
column9: At first, I thought the left headset wasn’t working. It wouldn’t light up, and no sound came from that one. After following the instructions from the user manual on how to reset the headset, they both started working. Before using this headset for the first time, I had to download the Sony Headphones Connect app from the App Store. Once I started utilizing the app to control the headset, I found it easy to use. This comes with a charging case, a usb charging cable, and additional earbuds. I like the built-in microphones because I can talk, handsfree, while my phone is in my pocket. The sound quality of voice calls is good. I can clearly hear the other party, and they can clearly hear me. The sound quality of music is good, but there’s not much bass. Noise cancellation is decent. These stay in my ears without falling out.

column8: Amazing headphones marred by difficult interface
column9: So I got the Sony WF-1000MX3 buds with active noise canceling, and as a long-time Bragi Dash Pro user keeping an eye out for a replacement when these inevitably die, I have comments. My use case is mainly walking 8 miles a day to, in, and home from LA's Runyon Canyon to maintain my 300+ lb weight loss. The active noise canceling is *amazing*. I walk a lot on busy city streets, and they reduce traffic noise considerably. The ambient passthrough is good, but the Bragi system is better - I can converse with people with the Bragis on, but not really the Sony's. The user interface and controls are a mess. In particular: The app is confusingly laid out and takes a noticeable pause to connect to the bids when loaded. About the same as the Bragi app. A lot of space is given to a system that attempts to auto-configure ambient sound options based on location and activity, and was the first thing I turned off. The ANC/ambient sound settings are really screwy - There's a single toggle that turns the whole system on or off, and a slider below that slides from noise canceling to ambient pass-through at one of 20 levels. However toggling the system from the bud control always puts ambient passthrough at the highest level. There's a toggle for sound quality vs connection quality. Selecting the former puts up a confusing alert that says if you prioritize sound quality, you may not be able to go back to the other option, but I've been able switch back and forth. Connection has been pretty solid even on the high quality option. There's another toggle for what seems to be some kind of interpolative oversampling but that is just labeled "DSEE HX" without any explanation. Sony makes the same mistake as Jabra in their audio-passthrough option - activating it *mutes* not pauses. This means if you're listening to a podcast, you must remember to pause first or spend a minute finding your place again. Seriously, this is the one thing that Bragi got right that no one else has. The most important thing is to be able to quickly hear the outside world as needed and get back to my listening, and no one has it better than Bragi. The buds use a touch-sensitive button on each one as the only physical control. Right bud is 1 tap pause, 2 tap FF, 3 taps Rew. Left button is tap to advance ANC/Ambient/Off, and hold to temporarily turn on ambient sound and mute (not pause!) playback. The buttons respond slowly, and multi-tap control inputs only give one feedback beep for multiple taps. I'm lucky that as I walk I have the phone handy in a holster that permits me to adjust volume and activate Siri from the phone without removing it, but otherwise no volume control. The press and hold to hear control is awkward to hold for more than a second - you're literally holding a hand to your ear as long as you need to hear, and it activates slowly like all the controls. Also there's not a lot of physical feedback that you're hitting the right spot on the bud. You get used to it, but at first it's terribly frustrating to tap, wait, and then realize you missed. The case is large but much better than the terrible Bragi arrangement. The buds sit down into the case immediately, and there's a hinged cover instead of the awful, heavy, and opens from the wrong side aluminum slide. I miss the 4D motion interface - as annoying as it can be when it activates accidentally, it's handy when my hands are full. Overall the sound is slightly inferior to the Bragis when it's quiet out. There's a good soundstage, but bass is a little muddy. But when it's loud out and the ANC kicks in, it's like you're alone with the music. I find them a little tiring in the ears for long walks. They are much bigger and heavier than the Bragis, even the 65ts, and between the weight and the deep placement required for the ANC to work, it's hard to wear them continuously for hours as I do the Bragis. When the ANC is on, there's a mild feeling of pressure that's hard to describe but is occasionally uncomfortable. The lack of stated water/sweat resistance is scary. I walk rain or shine, and I'll keep the Bragis for the wet days, but I do sweat a little as I walk and I try to keep them free of it. There are points of ingress for water on the buds, and I just don't know how durable they'll be. Phone conversations are reasonably good - my test is my hearing-impaired father, and he can hear and understand me even outside, unlike the Bragis. I'm keeping them, and they'll be part of the mix for daily wear, but it's not the Holy Grail for me of one headset to rule them all. I have been carrying the Bragis, the 65ts for when the Bragis need a charge (I'm getting about 2-3 hours out of mine now) and the AirPods for when I need to talk to someone on the phone. It might switch to just the Sony and Bragi. My recommendation for most people is still the Elite 65t with really good tips. I'd love to hear comments from other users who've taken the plunge. Thanks for reading!

column8: disappointed with call quality. mic doesn’t effectively capture user voice.
column9: audio quality ++ noise canceling ++ comfort + call quality -

column8: Sony’s Latest Earbuds vs. The Elephant in the Room!
column9: So many of us have eagerly awaited Sony’s latest top-of-the-line noise-canceling earbuds. They’re here at last. But what do we all truly want to know?? Ahem! How do the WF-1000XM3 measure up to Apple Airpods? Read on for a long detailed analysis. Quick spoiler answer: Very well indeed, and maybe even better! SOUND QUALITY I personally place the far highest priority on listening quality. The Sony sound is more dynamic, fuller, and truly excellent compared with the also high quality Apple Airpods. These are par with the even more expensive Bang & Olufen Beoplay and Sennheiser Momentums. In the $200 price range, these Sony’s are the sound fidelity new champ and MUCH better than the just ok last generation. When you first try them, if the sound is not immediately blowing you away, you may have a temporary fit issue. Sony supplies a very generous number of different and comfortable tip sizes. Once you nail the fit, they will truly impress in all aspects of sound quality: accuracy, tonal range, non-fatiguing, and punchy (but not annoying) base. If it’s better mic quality you are after, or have hearing difficulty, the Airpods are a bit better, capturing more-subtle voice tones. However, the Sony noise cancellation feature can be left on, or turned off, during phone calls. This is a great option so you are comfortable hearing during a call. NOISE CANCELLATION Apple currently has none. Sony wins this battle because the Apple noise cancelling version, tentatively known as Airpods 3, is not likely to launch until late 2019 at the earliest. If you haven’t experienced noise cancellation in headphones, or earbuds, you’ll likely be as blown away as I was. I got my first noise cancelation Bose headphones six years ago when they were the only game in town. Life changing, truly. A must for any noisy environment and a godsend for rest on long airplane trips. These are my first noise cancelling earbuds and the result is spectacular. I urge you to audition this feature. It alone makes the Sony’s win the battle versus Apple Airpods. LOOKS AND PRESTIGE This depends on what type of person you are. Apple Airpods were considered rare and prestigious gems just a few years ago. Now they are seen as everyday mundane. These Sony’s are a new look: somewhat more understated due to the slick black color. Personally, I like the Sony’s better because they blend. They are still pretty noticeable, though. All things considered, notice your face, not odd mini chopsticks sticking out. This of course is highly subjective. For me, I’ll always take best sound quality as first priority. BATTERY LIFE Simply stated, Sony battery life is good so if you’ve been concerned this is an issue, don’t be. Sony states eight hours of life after a fast charge, or six hours with noise cancelling on. So far, this seems accurate to me. I have not run a longer detailed comparison yet but will update this review as needed. The Sony’s do not offer wireless charging. The highest end version of the Aipods has it as an optional feature at an additional $40. CASE QUALITY Sony gets the nod here, as long as you don’t mind a very slightly bigger case. The case design is all new and very cool looking indeed. Even more important, it disappears just fine in pocket. SWEAT RESISTANCE This is not Sony’s strength. If you drench ‘em in the gym, I’d stick with Airpods. VALUE AND OVERALL BEST CHOICE Since the Sony’s are still new, the price is not yet creeping down and is quite a bit more than the venerable Apple Airpods. Although only released in December 2016, the “age” of the Airpod technology is showing. Head to head against even the just released 2nd generation Airpods, Sony wins on its noise cancellation ability alone. Beyond that, music is noticeably better, too. Although the 2nd generation Airpods came out in March 2019, improvements are merely incremental. If you’ve just gotta have Airpods, my suggestion is to wait until late 2019 or early 2020 when Apple’s 3rd generation will be much improved. Thus, if you can wait, audition Airpods 3 against the Sony’s and compare the noise cancellation. I trust that Apple’s version will be excellent. Expect the price to be at least as high as these Sony WF-1000XM3, though. If you need earbuds now, not only is Sony the new Sheriff in town. At this price point, the WF-1000XM3 earbuds are the best sounding, too. Thanks for slogging through this long review. Hope it has been of some help. HAPPY LISTENING!

column8: Best true wireless right now but no support for multiple devices
column9: Overall I really like these. Sony gets a lot right with their headphones now, especially the foam/silicone ear buds, battery life and sound quality. The case is a little big but that's understandable given the size of the earpieces and the battery. That all said, the noise cancellation works pretty well but mostly on lower frequencies and it's not as successful (or maybe just not as aggressive) on higher frequency noises. I've only used them on a train so far, but it's good enough to cancel most of the noise from a commuter train. In a subway station though, it lets through most of the noise of passing trains. My biggest complaint is how terrible these are when trying to use them with multiple devices. I want to be able to switch between my Android phone and tablet but all that happens is they'll just fall back to connecting to my phone. For example, I can disconnect from my phone by tapping the NFC area on the case. Then I'll go to the tablet and connect and it'll work for about 15 seconds. But then it'll just fall back to connecting to the phone. Bose seems to be the only company that has figured out how to connect to multiple devices. Oh yeah, and I wish companies provided a way to turn off the flashing blue lights. To end on a positive note, the sound quality is excellent so far. Compared to some JBL noise cancelling earbuds I have, I've actually noticed some parts of songs that I don't hear on the JBLs.

Fantastic sound. Have listened to a broad range of music so far from opera to jazz to rock with entirely satisfying results. No sound adjustments, DSEE HX off. Sound Quality Mode: priority on sound quality. Using with an iPhone XS Max. Zero issues connecting (faster than my AirPods) and staying connected. Won't be able to speak to NC on flights (my primary NC use case) for another couple of weeks but other reviews score them very well. Very comfortable from my POV.

column8: I have mine with me at all time
column9: Whether you really like something can be determined by whether you carry them with you at all time. In my bag, I have my Ultimate Ears Custom in-ears monitor, Sony WH-1000XM3 and now the Sony WF-1000XM3. I wish the battery for the WF-1000XM3 was at least 10 hours but I am sure Sony need to save up improvements for XM4. These WF-1000XM3 sounds great but more importantly they are extremely comfortable. the charging is not huge to the point where I cannot store them in my pants pocket. I have not had problem with making and receiving calls. As for not having physical buttons nor the ability to control volume, it is a personal preference.
NO Multipoint?? Really is this 2000? Or 2019?

column8: Low Volume on Mac and PC
column9: These work great connected to an iPhone but I wanted to use them with computers as well. I tried a Macbook and multiple Windows 10 machines. I had the same annoying problem on all. The volume is too low to be useable. I can max out the volume and it isn't anywhere near the volume you get from connecting to an iPhone. It could be that the iPhone requires the Sony Connect app and that app is doing something to improve volume? Maybe a firmware update can fix this in the future, but apparently Sony rushed these to market and they won't work for me because I need to use them with a computer and not just iOS or Android devices. Sony rushed this to market!

column8: Left earbud stopped working after first 15 min of use!!! It never turned on again, what a joke.
column9: Review from August 26, 2019 I love these earphones sound so much that this is the only reason why I am holding on to it. Because there are so many connection problems that it makes me hate it like once per hour of my daily use! This is my second pair, the first one I had to return to the BestBuy (just from not knowing how to reset the left or right ear). Now I know how to reset it, because I have to do it twice or three times daily. If I play a song then I press pause and do my thing.....3 to 5 minutes later I want to resume my music. I press play on my right ear and it doesn't respond, I press left ear and it responds with turning on or off the noise-cancelling that's all. I press and hold both ears nothing works, I can not find or connect the right ear to resume music play. Only one thing works I have to take them off and put it in the case. Then once in the case, I see the red light on left ear and nothing on the right ear. So, I do the reset by holding on to the right ear (in this case) then the right ear comes back after holding it for like 20 seconds. Later the same thing, I play music then I need to talk to someone, I press pause, maybe 2 or 3 min later I want to resume music my both ears not responding. I can press both ears and hold for 20 seconds, nothing works until I take it out of my ears and put it back to my case then do reset by holding on the the ear that doesn't have the red light. Don't you guys think this is highly inconvenient that the earphones can NOT stay connected to the device for more than a few minutes when I don't play music? Common, I have Jaybird X3 & X4, Jabra Evolve 75, Bose QC35II and all can be resumed playing music after the small pause of few minutes. Next, today is my 12th day having these earphones (second pair) and the blue light on the earphones started blinking when in ears. It used to only blink blue when I remove the earphones from my ears then it blinks for a few seconds. Now, it blinks blue being in my ears, first right side one blink then left side one blink. I can totally live with this but not disconnection problems. Third problem is connectivity, my cellphone is Samsung Galaxy Note 9 and I have a regular thin clear TPU case, when I turn on the earphones and put my cellphone in the right pocket on my shorts when I walk and turn my head left my left ear starting to cut off music, when I turn my head right my right ear cuts off. I tried removing the case and it was better but still, when I walk fast I feel my left and right ears cut off once in 30 seconds. I tried to change from music quality to the stable connection in the app but it didn't solve the problem. Last but not least the issue that everyone knows about, my wf-1000xm3 doesn't work with my SurfaceBook 2 (marvel Bluetooth adapter). I am waiting for the Sony's update late August. Hopefully, this will work. What do you think guys? Is this pair is also a dud? Should I return this one too? I am just getting so frustrated with this earphones, I have never had to struggle so much with the earphones. I can live with the blinking blue light, I can live without Windows 10 connectivity BUT I can not live with the earphones can not be discovered if I have 2 min break between songs this is ridiculous. Sometimes I just put them in my ears to have quiet environment without any music, as I do on my QC35II and the Sony works for 5 minutes then dies I am trying to press any botos to maybe wake it up but it's gone, I have to look for the case in my backpack, place it in the case then reset then turn on reconnecting place in my ears and 10 min later it will be the same story again. Help anyone, I have no idea what to do with this damn wf-1000xm3 earphones. Review from August 08, 2019 I see that it isn't only me with such issue. There is another couple of people with the same issue on bestbuy reviews. It is the same story as mine, they also have left earbud bricked within first 24 hours of use. Also, this is one of really huge minuses for me, if you use your own ser of eartips from other earphones that fit perfectly fine on this earbuds you will have issue with the case, it wont close! Dear sony, how hard was is to make some kind of clip that keeps the case from opening? So, you can only use the eartips that came with this earbuds. Another one minus for me, there is absolutely NO WAY OF KNOWING how charged is the case, is it 100% or almost dead nothing on it. Another draw back there is no volume buttons, no power of/on buttons. P.S. I was hoping this will be it...unfortunately this wf-1000xm3 came with way to many minuses and issues. I loved the music quality and a battery life (promised one, not the one I got on my right ear only :)

column8: Field Tested - Not ready and its worth $50
column9: I had very high hopes for this Sony iteration. But alas all the favorable reviews by influencers seem to be too good to be true. Sound: First the sound when connected to the phone is excellent. However, that’s where all the favorable accolades end. Noise Cancelling: I couldn’t tell at all if it’s working or not in an office setting. It’s that subtle. Most of the cancellation is coming from sound isolation using the right tips. Well, this can be achieved at a very high level with any ear buds paired with comply tips. If Sony’s selling point over MW07 or kilpsch and sennheiser was noise canceling then I can tell you it’s just a gimmick. The larger 1000MX3 are league ahead of these buds. This changed as I boarded my first flight to MSP. Here once ambient noise was activated, you could hear everything amplified while in noise cancelling mode, I could really tell the amount of noise cancelling. I was ready to change my review this happened on my next flight. To compare, I brought my MPOW true wireless with AptX with me. Both were equipped with Comply tips so sound isolation would be equal in both. I first tried the MPOW and they did an amazing job isolating the engine noise. Another advantage was that the sounds was generally higher in MPOW so I didnt need to crank up the decibels on MPOW. Then I placed the Sony and was completely surprised that in Noise cancelling mode, they were WORSE than MPOW. I have no explanation for this. I was very impressed with them on my first flight as the noise cancelling was stellar. What happened? It could be that when compared to MPOW the noise cancelling effect was worse but when tried by itself, it was acceptable. Anyway, the MPOWs are less than $50 and they have better codecs and sound fidelity than Sony. Sony still has punchier and cleaner bass but MPOW is right up there. Connectivity and Controls: its very buggy. It would not connect to my Samsung TV. After a power cycling it did connect but the right earbuds continued to lose sound. The sound was hollowed and not rich like when playing music from phone. I was playing a Dolby 5.1 source so it should have been much richer. The app is another story. It would not show as connected even though my Bluetooth list showed it was connected. I also noticed that sound during calls would randomly cut off and come back even though the phone is right next to me. The Hifiman have 150 Meter range. These don’t even meet their advertised range. Its unforgivable at this price to not have APT x and IPX rating. I get it that they are likely withholding on some features from the first version. However, they left out the wrong features and besides the sound, these earbuds is a work in progress. Battery: This is a deal breaker. The right side was draining much faster then left side. They were at 70% to 95% of left side. This is a real problem on longer flights. You don’t want one side just draining faster than the other. Updating battery usage. Battery with NC does not last the promised 5.5 hours. It lasted 2.5 hours for me. Also, the right side lost battery before the left side Overall I think these require significant firmware upgrade. NC need to get closer to 80% of the 1000MX3 over ear pairs. The battery is a big issue and connectivity needs to be improved. I’ll test these in a flight next week and report back. These are likely going back

column8: Great sound, good NC, volume issue
column9: So I already own the Cambridge Audio Melomania 1, which I love considering price, performance and just overall goodness. Have owned several pair of TW IEMs, including the $300 Senn Momentum TW (sold them), the first gen Sony TW and a bunch of others, including the Nuheara IQ buds (first gen). Settled on the CAs but also have the Sony full-sized M3s, which I also like a lot. With that as contect, I am a big fan of these Sony TW 2.0 buds. The only two gripes I have are the sound on some, not all, of my tracks is too quiet even when maxing out the slider on my iPhone 8+. I know it's the mastering of the tracks, mainly, and I don't expect ear-shattering sound, too old for that (and it's dangerous). But even with NC on, when out and about I have to skip some tracks, mainly the pre-loudness war tracks (classic rock, some jazz and mellow vocals). Not a deal breaker, but not the best scenario. The other issue is they are not as secure as the CA Melomanias, and sometimes it feel like I am ensuring they are snug way too often. Also not a deal breaker, but I may explore using foamies with these buds. Of course, that brings up the hassle of keeping them in the case without their OEM tips, a plague across almost all TW buds (at leas the ones I have experienced). Bottom line, I am keeping the Sonys (I had a decent credit on my Amazon account, so I paid $130 for them) and my 1-2 TW option, along with the Melomanias. Two different flavors, but both offer excellent, balanced sound, not bass heavy or light, just right. The Sony NC is not quite as good as the full-sized M3s, but 80-85 percent there. Oh, almost forgot. The lack of volume control could be a deal breaker for anyone using these for on the go listening, if you have the same volume issues I have. Constantly changing the volume is not much fun. The other options is creating specific playlists in iTunes to use with the Sonys, so you don't access any tracks that would be deemed too quiet. On that front, moving to a streaming service alleviates the issue somewhat, because streaming (in my case Amazon Music Unlimited) tends to stream every track at identical volume levels. I don't use streaming out and about, but I may do that with the Sonys. I do have unlimited LTE on my mobile plan, which I know means they slow it down once you hit the cap. Anyway, there's this option too. Are the Sonys worth $229? Close call. If I had to choose, I'd take the CA Melomania at $129. But again, both ice cream, just different flavors. Update: I started the return process. Two things are potential deal breakers for me, but I am going to try different tips (Comply foamies? Not sure) before a final decision. As noted, the volume on some of my onboard tracks is woefully quiet, even at max on my iPhone 8+. Also, sadly, the Sonys generate wind noise; I found out on my first dog walk outside with them in use. Not horrible, but if the wind kicks up, it's annoying/distracting. Maybe foam tips will solve both issues, but I doubt it. If not, back they go. I actually think the Cambridge Melomania 1s sound as good if not better than the Sonys, without those two issues. And they are much less obtrusive, don't need an app (use Kaiser Audio player to tweak the highs a bit), are built like tanks and do take Comply tips, once the original foamies that came with them wear out (my preference in tips for these phones). Update #2 Digging into my bag of tips accumulated over the years, I did find a better pair than what comes with the Sonys. Not sure where I got them, but they just work. On the other hand, I have to sort of agree with a reviewer who says after sound quality, which is very good, the NC is just okay (not really like the full-size Sony M3) and I still have to resolve the wind noise issue, which is a deal breaker for me no matter how good these sound. On planes, trains and such, I would always favor the full-size Sonys. So what's the point if the in-ears are going to make wind noise when out walking? None. I can use the Cambridge Audio buds for that job (plus the CAs are sweat proof). So the chances are pretty good I am going to return the Sonys. Sorry to say, they didn't match up to the hype IMHO.

column8: Impressive - Some NC Tips - Hot Swappable Bluetooth for multi-device use !
column9: Overall: I give these a 9 out of 10. I. Noice Cancelling (NC): The NC of these earbuds are nothing short of Absolutely Amazing, bar none! To anyone who says differently, they probably have not taken the time to form a proper seal. Here’s a good way to test for a proper seal: 1. Wear the earbuds, NC set to ON, in a noisy environment. (I used a stretch of highway in a car). 2. See if lightly pushing inward on one (or both) earbuds causes the outside sound to become more quiet. If it gets quieter, you do not have a good fit. Try to form a better seal: push inward, twist, pull outward a tad, whatever ... If you still can not get a proper seal, change to another tip size. You may even find you need different sizes for each ear. I wear the default size in left, and one size up in the right. I think many owners will probably not be enjoying the full NC that these units are capable of. I want to confirm that there is a vast difference in each of the three levels: Ambient Sound: outside sound is passed through with a very slight amplification. Ambient Sound Off: the earplug effect solely from eartips. Noise Cancelling: ambient sound is cancelled to various degrees based on the app setting with an optional checkbox dedicated to pass/not pass the vocal range of frequencies. When fully engaged, all car road noise was completely eliminated; and you experience driving in silence while feeling all the bumps in the road. Wow !!! II. Comfort In testing the battery usage, I wore the earbuds all day at work with NC on. Although, I do not believe these earbuds are AS-COMFORTABLE-AS my Jabra Elite 65t's, they are still fairly comfortable. I did not suffer from discomfort or fatigue after wearing them a little over five hours. UPDATE: I have not worn my Jabra's in over a week now; I decided to use them. Now, I feel it's just a different fit, and I actually feel the Sony's are more comfortable than the Jabra's. III. Battery Usage: (not quite as good as they claim) BLUF: 5.25 hrs. This was with Noice Cancellign ON, DSEE HX on, & Bluetooth focus on Sound Quality vs Connection This may be why my experiences are below other reports where battey usage is right on the mark. The battery readings (on the iOS app anyway) jump in steps: 100%, 70%, 50% and 20%. Both left and right units drain in unison. You can see one unit at 70% and the other change 70% to 50%, but that apparent difference is only shown for 2 mins, and the other unit will drop from 70% to 50% to match. I.e., they "bump down" farily close to the same time, but not exactly at same time. I ran with NC on and loud AC unit at work for 3.75 hours before reaching 20% and hearing the first voice prompt to recharge units. Continuing, I achieved 5 1/4 hours of usage before the units gave a second recharge prompt, and then powered themselves off. IV. Have Two Devices? Enjoy "Hot Swappable" Bluetooth Connection !!! Hot Swappable BT Connection is a feature that many have missed in reviews. If you plan to connect with multiple devices, this should be important to you. Hot Swappable means you do not have to disconnect from one device (yourself) in order to switch to another device. The earbuds will disconnect from the first device automatically when you connect to a second device. It's fast and reliable! You'll get audio confirmations too: "Bluetooth disconnected, bluetooth connected." (This feature works for any device that has ever been connected before. If it's the first time the device has connected, this feature will not work.) A Word on the Blue Blinking Light Thing ... There were some very early on concerns that the blinking blue lights would be annoying at night in comments on you tube - it’s nothing to be concerned about - the lights don’t blink when you’re wearing them - they signal Bluetooth connection and allow you to know when they auto power off if you take them off, and don’t place them in the case. There is an off/on setting to auto power off in 5 mins if they are not being worn, and not in the case. Pros: Outstanding sound signature ! All the detailed items listed above -especially hot swap bluetooth. The touch panels are reliable, ( not my experience with Sennheisers). Cons: Phone quality is good if you’re in a quiet environment; Otherwise, hit and miss - too unreliable at times. No direct volume control from the units themselves (wondering if future firmware will address this) The Sony Connect app (ironically) has to re-connect if you ever switch to another app, blank the screen, or minimize it. The app should be named the Re-Connect app. UPDATE Sept 8, 2019. ANC comparison with overEar ====================================== So I’ve heard how much better over-the-ear headphones are for active noise cancelling. Yesterday, I was passing by a Best Buy, and had these earbuds with me. I wanted to do a head-to-head comparison of these, the WH 1000xm3’s and the Bose 700. I didn’t play any music - just Noise Cancelling comparison. I stayed about 40 mins ... and heard a few different background environments - overhead speaker announcements, conversations of customers, and loud deep base entertainment demos ... I walked away with the following three thoughts: (a) no headphones offer perfect noise cancelling. They all do a fantastic job - but none are perfect. (b) I was disappointed with the over-the-ear headphones not being MUCH MUCH better than these earbuds. If the over-the-ear headphone were better, then it wasn’t by very much at all - it’s not a STARK difference, it’s barely perceivable if at all. (Yeah, I know, I’m going to be accused of being paid by Sony to write this - but this was my experience. I was thinking that if over-the-ear phones were drastically better, I may walk out of the store purchasing the Bose 700 -as those are best for phone calls.) (c) There is absolutely no way in the world that I would buy either the Sony WH 1000xm3, or the Bose 700 over-the-ear headphones - not when these wf 1000xm3’s arepractically keeping up with NC-ing with very little difference, and they’re cheaper, and a lot more convenient. I remain very happy with purchasing these units and my only complaint is phone call quality for the person on the other end. ===== If you found this review helpful, chances are others would too. I try to cover points others miss. Please consider floating this review to the top by tapping the "Helpful" button. Thanks =====

column8: Noise cancelling not as great as many professional reviews said
column9: bought this blind without trying and ended up fairly disappointed, definitely not as great as many pro reviews tout it to be. Noise cancelling is a fraction (maybe 50% IMO) of the demo Sony over-the-year XM3 model I tried oor the Bose wired version that I am replacing. I used it mostly to listen to podcasts on commuter trains. While the voice still sounds clear, the background train noise is still fairly substantial and the isolation is disappointing, nothing on par to my old Bose (which broke) but certainly better than the $50 Taotronics that I was using as an intermediate gap. On top of that, there are a lesser myraid of connection issues, button not sensitive enough, bluetooth connection with windows, etc. that some other board mentions. All these are minor stuff but the most critical noise cancelling ability is in general a disappointment to me considering this pair sells for $230.
Great wireless earbuds

column8: great sound, for me, poor sound isolation
column9: All the reviewers are correct, this headset appears to have GREAT SOUND. Unfortunately for me, it has very little sound isolation. When listening to music, I love music, all types, I hear every noise in my surrounding environment. I tried all of the supplied eartips, NO HELP, kinda sad, because this headset does have great sound, even though it does not support some hirez formats like sony"s own LDAC for one... My problem may be due to the fact that none of the supplied eartips fit my ears properly causing poor sound isolation...hope you have better luck
Good product and comfort

As has happened to many others here - after two days the left earbud is dead as a doornail. Will not charge, will not turn on. DEAD Fit - impossible to insert and get a seal. And yes I am following Sony's directions. No fit problems at all with my B&O E8's, Etymotic ER4, or Airpods so it's not my ears. The inability for these to fit- and thus to create a seal, means the ANC is basically useless. Based on others having the same issues I think Sony has a problem here.
Love it
Best true wireless headphones ever!!! !.The sound is amazing. The noise cancellation is fantastic. Highly recommend.

Comfortable to wear and great sound quality, however the noise cancelling does not work. I have wired ANC earbuds and wanted to switch to bluetooth. Tried every setting, reset earbuds etc, only time I could tell the noise cancelling was active was outside with wind blowing. Several other reviews mentioned lack of noise cancelling, I suspect that Sony has some QC problems. Thank you Amazon for the easy return.

Having trouble to play any sound even though it's shown successfully connected via Bluetooth. What is weird is that I can use the earbud to pause YouTube video and other playback function, but not able to have any sounds. The driver needs more work. I can have sound from other earbuds such airpods or beats.

Awesome sound, download the app to further tailor it with an equalizer, DSEE-HX. These are pretty loud earbuds, iPhone volume set at 50%. Any louder and you will damage your ears. For small earbuds, the Active noise cancelling is really good. It is not going to match over the ear headphones. Paired with my iPhone and Android tablet easily, only one at a time though. They fit securely in my ear, I have no fear of these falling out. I highly recommend these for every day use, for workout only wireless buds I would go with the Powerbeats Pro(I also own). These Sony earbuds blow them away sound wise but the Powerbeats Pro has a water resistant rating.

column8: Returning it...not good as advertised...not even close
column9: I have the big brother of this and AirPods and i was expecting a product that simple works but nope sony did it again and trying to sell a product that is not ready for prime...noise canceling is not working properly...you can put some cotton balls in your ear and that would work better... touch controls are hit and miss...come on sony just buy an AirPods and see how a product is just simply works without changing this and that.... with this product i am giving up on sony products and appreciate the apple more.... not recommending this at all....

Pro: great sound quality. Con: 1. Noise cxl 0, i followed the instruction, reset and change all 6 pair ear p, same result. 2. Last generation charging cable, if u lose this one u gonna have hard time to find a replacement. 3. Touch control is all over the place, the graph only inst is not helping at all. 4. Sound volume is min even on max, i tried it at the gym and the max vol is about 60-70% of airpods. 5. Sony paid too much to social media influencer to hype this and resulted in way over the top expections on a mediocre item.

These headphones are amazing. I am usually not a fan of headphones that go in the ear, but these are very comfortable. They give you the option to then on/off ambient noises/noise cancelling or nothing. I have 4 loud children and a husband, so I decided to see how truly noise cancelling they were. Popped them in while my husband was on the phone, tv was on and toys were going off and could only hear my music. That right there won be over. They also have the ability to take phone calls. Connecting via bluetooth was extremely simple and they charge right in the case via USB-C. Do yourself a favor and buy a pair, you won't be disappointed.

column8: Great sound with decent noise canceling
column9: So I have Sony's newest over ear noise canceling headphone and really love them, except that they are bulky to carry around, mess up my hair in the morning and make my ears sweat in the summer. So when I saw these coming out I rushed to get them. So far I'm only a day in and the sound is great. I've tweaked the settings and found the right size ear piece and now can't be happier with their sound quality. Their size, weird and design are exactly what I wanted. With an additional case I bought on Amazon I can just hook the case to my backpack or pants so don't need to lug them around. Now for noise canceling, like with the over ear you may need to tweak the settings to have a better experience. Some of the defaults let in higher levels or types of sounds you may not want. To be clear though, no matter what setting you use they are not as good as the over ear units for eliminating sounds but are much better than anything else out there in their style. On the train it eliminates the train noise and significantly lowers background chatter. With my music or a book on the outside noise is completely gone. They are not perfect, I wish they were water\sweet proof. I wish they had a volume control. I wish they supported Alexa instead of Google (like the over ear unit). I wish the noise and wind canceling was better. But realistically I don't see anything else on the market that comes close to these and sound quality wise I can't be happier.

These buds do everything they say they will. I got these for me and my wife and I to use on the treadmill when we workout. The sound quality, and the noise cancelling, both fantastic. I have a pair of Bose QuietComfort 35's that I use when I fly, which is pretty frequently, and I would say the sound and noise cancellation are pretty close, which is impressive because these are a much smaller package. I wouldn't want to do long flights with any headphones jammed in my ears, because I just find they become uncomfortable after extended use, which is why I sue the Bose cans, but for short flights, train rides, working out, etc, these are awesome. Definitely a great product. Also, the little charging cast they come with is sick. Very solid and looks cool.

column8: Exceptional Noise Cancellation and Sound Quality
column9: I have numerous noise-cancelling solutions ranging in price from budget to premium, both in earbuds and headphones. The WF-1000XM3s true wireless earbuds are the best amongst the various noise cancelling earbuds I own. It’s important to understand what noise cancelling is and is not. Noise cancelling does not block all ambient noise. It listens for constant background noise (e.g., jet engines, construction, general crowd roar) then issues a counter signal to block out that sound. When I watch You Tubers unbox and test a new noise cancelling product, I often see them switch it on then ask someone in the studio to shout at them, and they then nod understandingly as if this ridiculous test has any bearing on noise-cancelling efficiency. Noise cancelling should also be distinguished from noise isolation, which is what occurs when your ear canal is blocked by a well-seated ear bud tip. That reduction in ambient background noise is caused passively (versus actively) by your ear canal being blocked. When you put your fingers in your ears in anticipation of a loud boom, you are doing the same thing. That said, effective noise cancellation also requires effective noise isolation. The best noise cancellation in the world is meaningless if ambient sound is entering your ear canal around loosely seated noise-cancelling ear tips. I point out these differences because most of my friends and family (and some YouTubers) don’t understand the differences between these two concepts. Now that I have that out of the way, on to the review. In short, the XM3s offer excellent noise cancellation and superb audio quality. The XM3s ship with a very generous number of ear tips. Once I figured out which set offered the best seal and fit within my ear canal to maximize noise isolation, the sound quality was apparent. I despise tinny sounding ear buds. I prefer a deep bass response that is not muddy and doesn’t overwhelm the music. These offer fantastic bass. Sony’s Headphone app offer various profiles, once of which offers a bass boost. Thus far, the bass boost is my favorite. My music is clear, crisp, and has a nice bass emphasis. Call quality is also great. Calls are crystal clear on both ends of the conversation. The noise cancelling is impressive. My favorite noise cancelling headphones are a pair of MW65s. The XM3s offer very comparable noise cancellation at 10% of the size since they are only earbuds. I enjoy being in a noisy environment and cycling from ambient noise to noise cancellation just so I can hear the satisfying “whoosh” of entering a near sound vacuum where the ambient noise is being cancelled out by the XM3’s. The XM3’s have a noise detecting microphone on each earbud. If you choose, you can use the Sony Headphone app to automate the noise cancellation. The app will use the microphones to determine what setting you are in (sitting, running, transport, etc.) and will adjust the noise cancellation automatically. You can further tune it to allow in however much ambient noise you desire. You can even choose for it to isolate and highlight voices so you can hear people who may speak to you. You can also cup your hand over the left earbud to pause everything so you can hear people. I find this very helpful when out and about since I can quickly ask or answer a question without dislodging the earbuds. The XM3s are not waterproof, nor rated for any water resistance as far as I can tell. This is odd since one of the app’s sound profiles is running. Clearly Sony intended these to be used for exercising yet did not make them water or sweat proof. I guess they figured your sweat is unlikely to reach the units themselves since they do sit out a bit from your ear. I use these at my gym so I guess time will tell. The earbuds themselves are bulkier than standard earbuds. Oddly, however, they do not feel heavy at all. I forget they are even there. I also love the charging case. It is magnetized and just sucks the earbuds right into place. It thankfully also uses USB C. The case is kind of bulky, however, and isn’t comfortable in my pant pocket. A purse, backpack, or gym bag is the way to go. My other noise cancelling earbuds are connected with a wire to a unit that rests on the back of my neck (that unit contains the noise cancelling microphones.) The unit on the back of my neck isn’t the end of the world, but if I am moving around a lot (like at the gym) I am constantly having to readjust the neck unit. Being truly wireless, the XM3s are the next step up in convenience and comfort. Overall, these offer great active noise cancelling and sound quality in a smaller footprint than full-size headphones. They are not, however, inexpensive – but at least you’re getting what you pay for. It’s a technological achievement to be able to offer outstanding noise cancellation and audio quality in true wireless earbuds. If you are not put off by the price, I highly recommend them.

I have the W2 headphones from sony, these work pretty similar. They are pretty comfortable and the noise canceling works really good, this is my first week with them and so far I enjoy them a way more than the headphones. They don’t make my ears all hot and they stay in place when I’m at the gym and running. I have an Iphone Xs max and siri works with no issues, I also have a note 8 and have no problems with google assistant. These aren’t bass heavy but do sound crisp and clean, I adjusted them as i wanted through the sony headphone app to get them to what I feel is good. Overall I’m impressed and I definitely recommend them if your looking for a smaller option over the headphones.

column8: Won't be leaving the house without them UPDATE
column9: These are very nice. Much better than the previous generation. I was surprised how strong the noise cancelling was for such a small form factor. The sound is A+ as well. Battery life is as advertised so far. If these were sweatproof then they would be the be all end all of mobile headphones. I'd stick to the Jaybird Vistas for workouts. All in all another great 1000x product from Sony. UPDATE Ended up returning these. Was barely getting half of the advertised battery life after a few weeks.

These sound great, block noise extremely well, hold a pretty long charge, and also don't look super dorky like a certain other major brand. I got the Galaxy Buds free as part of a phone pre-order deal and these sound far superior.

I was so excited about these earbuds because I love my wh-1000xm3's so much. Unfortunately they didn't live up to expectations and I'm returning them. The biggest issue I had with them was comfort. They felt ok at first but after 20 minutes they really started to hurt. I tried all of the included silicone tips and multiple positions but it was always the same. Not sure I can blame the ear buds for that though, as it may have just been a bad fit for my ears. In addition to being uncomfortable, they just didn't feel very secure. Even after ensuring that I had the bud placed all the way into my ear canal with a good seal, they would still wiggle around when I moved and I would have to readjust them every few minutes. I also had an issue the day after I got them where the left ear bud completely died. It wouldn't charge or anything. I found out that this has actually happened to several people and in most cases can be fixed with a hard reset, which worked for me. But I've heard from others that the problem has recurred. Bugs like that are not something you should expect with a price tag like this. Next, the noise canceling. From some of the online reviews it seemed like the noise cancelation was good enough to rival that of the wh-1000xm3's. Not even close. I mean it's still pretty decent for in ear headphones but it's not even in the same stratosphere as the WH's. Besides that, everything else about these was pretty solid. Really good audio quality, fast connectivity, great battery life, classy look. But ultimately I do not believe these ear buds are worth $220. Maybe $150. I've since bought myself a pair of the "1more stylish true wireless" ear buds and I much prefer them over the Sony's. Way more comfortable, comparable audio quality and battery life, sweat resistance, and best of all only $100. Jaybird also just released a new pair of true wireless ear buds called "Vista" which are apparently fantastic as well so I'd recommend looking into those.

column8: I'm not sure why these are getting such negative reviews...
