column9: I'm honestly shocked these are getting bad reviews... EDIT: To those who's left earbud has stopped charging/working. Place the earbud in the case with the right one. Touch and hold the touch sensor for 20 seconds, or untill it starts flashing red. Let go, and it should start taking a charge and reconnect! Syncing was a cinch, between NFC or bluetooth, I'm really struggling to understand how anyone was having issues pairing these with their phones. I have a Note 8 for reference. The range decreases if you switch from quality over connectivity in the Sony app, but if you're working in an office or just around the house with your phone in your pocket, you shouldnt have an issue keeping these set to quality. The sound quality is surprisingly really good! I previously had a paid of Bose quietcomfort, but over the years the wires began to short out, hence the switch. I do feel Bose has these beat for noise cancelling, however if you factor in that these are the first truly wireless earbuds with ANC, these do an amazing job. Plus if you use an ear tip that creates a decent seal, the difference in ANC quality is truly negligible. I've had 0 issues with the left earbud not charging or cutting out or anything. I'm really thinking they may just be a fluke. My only grievances would be the no IP rating, the Sony app itself, no volume controls on the earbuds themselves, and mic quality. The latter three can be fixed with firmware/software updates. And being these just came out not too long ago, I'm willing to bet an update is in the works. Overall these are fantastic. I'll most certainly be keeping my pair!

column8: Poor pairing, mediocre sound, mediocre noise cancellation
column9: I'm not sure if my set is faulty, but they are VERY disappointing. Pairing with a computer is/was a nightmare and frequently doesn't work. The sound is often very quiet. I have to unpair and repair over and over before suddenly the sound works. Noise cancellation is not impressive whatsover. Honestly, I don't notice a difference when it's on or off. The ambient mode is supposedly suppose to help you hear your surroundings when the earbuds are in, but it doesn't seem to work.

column8: Great sounding and decent noise canceling
column9: I'm pretty impressed with sound quality and noise canceling these Sony true wireless earbuds are capable of. They are great sounding and the noise canceling is pretty good. I own a pair of Bose QC 35 II headphones and I would say the Sony earbuds sound better to me. However, they are a tad below the QC35 II in terms of noise cancelation. Though they are pretty close and should keep most people happy, especially in such a small, portable form factor. There are many things I like about these wireless earbuds. For one, I like the touch control - left earbuds to adjust noise canceling and right earbuds to play previous/next track. The Sony Connect app has an equalizer to tune the sound to your liking, and various controls to customize your earbuds. The built-in microphone is pretty good. Voice is nice and clear. No problem hearing people speaking to me or hearing me on the other end of the line. The earbuds support google assistant. I don't use it, so I don't know how well it works. The earbuds run for 6 hours on a single charge. I was able to get very close to that. The charging case can recharge the earbuds 3 more times, for a total of 24 hours. The charging case, albeit a little large, is fairly portable and very nice looking. These earbuds are not without issues though. Initially, I couldn't get the left bud to work until I preformed a reset per instructions. Now both buds show up as separate Bluetooth connections on my phone. Secondly, the there is no volume control on the earbuds. You'll have to bust out your phone to adjust the volume. Pretty inconvenient I would say, especially when your music are not normalized to the same level. Thirdly, they are not sweat resistant, so I probably won't use it in the gym. Lastly, the touch control is super sensitive. I found myself inadvertently triggering the touch control while I was re-seating the earbuds in my ears. All in all, these earbuds are great sounding and have good noise cancelation. Despite the issues discussed earlier, I really enjoy them a lot. They are great especially if you're constantly on the move. A great, portable alternative to a pair of full-size, noise-canceling headphones.

There are flaws with these headphones. They're not great for working out. They do get a little achey in your ears after a while (though I have yet to try the other sized ear pieces). None of this matters. The sound quality is so good, and the wireless functionality so efficient, that these headphones are immediately worth their value. These little buds sound better than my massivd ATH-150s! If you're going to spend $200 on headphones, these are the ones.

column8: Great for travel and other environments.
column9: I love these for short domestic flights. I have a large pair of over the ear headphones, but they're cumbersome to dig out and use with cords, etc. These are awesome. The noise cancelling is plenty strong and effective. I found setup to be very simple. Download the app, connect with bluetooth, and bingo, they just work every time. I like the multiple ear size adapters to find my perfect fit. The sound is good, for music or videos. For the traveler, these are a great option. I can listen to a movie on a plane around 30% volume - vs. my airpods at nearly 100% to hear everything.

Like other reviews I got about 5 hours of usage before the left earbud completely stopped working. It won't power on or charge. It's completely bricked. The headphones worked great until that happened. Returning and will probably rebuy in a few months if Sony can figure out these issues.

These are the earbuds your looking for. Excellent sound quality, stays put in my ears during works outs and the noise canceling works great. Don’t have to bring my big beats Headphones any longer to have good noise canceling. Charging case is a little big, but not to bad. Testing battery duration and will come back with an update on that. Beats all ear buds out the water.

First time writing a review here, the earbuds came in today and i was happy with them untill the left ear bud died on me. only after around 20minute of use the left earbud died, tried everything and it still doesnt work.

Honestly the volume on these are weak, the sound is not as great . Its actually horrible. You will hear a lot Of STATIC noise, which is noise related to the wireless connection but not properly adjusted. Overall it was just hyped, Airpods are still king and will return this junk and wait for BOSE 500, really disapointed.

column8: I really wanted to like these but can’t
column9: Purchased these as an option to bulky over the ear noise cancelling headsets for flying. I had high hopes - small package and completely wireless. However the sound quality is greatly lacking. My AirPods blow these away in that department. Noise cancelling isn’t great either. And the connection options via the app are clunky. If you like to switch between phone and iPad like I do it’s a hassle. At this price I am returning them

column8: It's all about the ear seal!
column9: The noise cancelling on the Sony-WF-100XM3's is actually quite impressive, BUT you have to insert them into your ears deeply enough and with a big enough tip to completely seal off your ear canal from any sound slipping past the earbuds. If you don't create a good physical seal (like I didn't at first) you still hear the sounds that are going around the noise cancelling. So... STEP 1: Create a complete seal (make sure the tip you choose is big enough) STEP 2: Be amazed how well these suckers work! I was sitting in front of a window air conditioner—a great source for the kind of steady sound that NC headphones eliminate so well—and I could still hear a decent amount of its rumble, even with the noise cancelling turned on, especially in my right ear. Bummer. I was disappointed like a number of other reviewers here. So I started to play with the right earbud, really getting it in there and twisting it upwards as recommended in the instructions. And then...SILENCE. Woah—these things work! As others have said, it's probably 85% - 90% as good as Sony's over ear WH1000M3 headphones, which is a fair tradeoff for me, considering the very useful form factor of these small earbuds. They'll still take away the energy-sapping drone of a jet engine just fine. I have found the foam tips seal off sound a tiny bit better (like 5%), but they take a lot more messing around to get a good seal and they're less comfortable than the silicone ones. So right now, I'm using these with the largest silicone tips, typing in front of an AC on full blast, and it sounds like the equivalent of a small computer fan running across the room. So that's my experience—yours may vary as everyone's ear canals are different. But I'm guessing most anyone (except those with really wide ear canals) can make these things work great as noise-cancelling option that lets you travel light. And as others have noted, these things sound amazing, feel like quality, the app is kinda dumb but useful, the case is biggish but pockatable, the touchpads are touchy, and it's a mild bummer that you can't control the volume directly from the earbuds. Overall, I love these things, even more after I figured out how to make them work. For about $50 more than Airpods, you get a lot more performance and features (and you can get them in black! ).

These may be the most comfortable earbuds I’ve used. The Sony earbuds were super easy to connect with my phone and iPod and have superb noise cancelling. I never thought I would get ear buds better than Apple’s, but I think I prefer Sony’s. The fit quite nicely and the sound quality is excellent. If they have any fault it may be because I can’t adjust the sound level. I have a Soundcore Bluetooth headset that I also like mostly because it lets me adjust the sound level. It’s noise canceling feature is not quite as good as this unit however. Small and compact, these also permit pairing with more than one Bluetooth unit. Battery life is suppose to be about six hours of continuous play, but putting them back in the charger for 15 minutes easily gives you another 2 hours. I like em...

Pros: Excellent sound quality Music preferences: Bassy EDM, Electronic, ASMR Noise cancellation: Best in class, comparable with QC35s, WI-1000 Battery life: Good enough Call quality: inconsistent, sometimes good, sometimes bad, mostly bad. Overall: Can’t live without. Rankings: WF-1000M3 * best all around Powerbeats pro * best for gym and calls Airpods 2g * best for calls WI-1000 * prior best all around Price: Worth it. One star off for unreliable call quality and factory rest required on first use due to some kind of pairing issue. (Hold the button on the earbud for 5 seconds to reset them when they didn’t turn on).

column8: Sound quality is great, No multi device support
column9: I was so excited to get these headphones and day 1 was great, day 2 was a nightmare. Pros: Great sound quality Good noise cancellation Ok battery life Nice design Comfortable Ambient sound feature is nice Cons: No multi device support Charging issues (left earbud stopped charging for about 24 hours) Pairing isn’t as easy as it should be Not good for cardio or intense head movement App isn’t very useful Doesn’t work with windows 10 The good: These headphones have great sound quality. I love bass heavy headphones and these have them without drowning out mids and treble. Noise cancelation is also great from earbuds. They have a sleek design. Thats about all its got going for it. The bad: They dont connect to PC. Pairing is a nightmare. If you use multiple devices, DO NOT GET THESE HEADPHONES! It’s a pain to have to pair each time you want to change your device. I have a iPhone, 2 iPads, a PC and a MAC. (I work in IT) Pairing in general is a pain. There’s no pairing button, and in order to pair another device you have to unpair with the other device. I only had them for a week and yesterday my left earbud stopped charging. I just checked today (almost 16 hours later) and they just started charging. The app is clunky but it allows you to adjust bass, noise cancelation and equalizer. Doesn’t let you change the name of the headphones so if you have 2 (maybe 1 for and your spouse) it can be problem especially when you want to change devices. Doesn’t tell you which devices you’re connected to. Call quality is good on your end, but people on the other end says I sound muffled or under water.

column8: Privacy Nightmare and Poor Noise Cancellation
column9: As part of the agreement to use the app that provides full functionality of the headphones, Sony forces you to agree to allow them collect all usage information about how you use the headphones, including when and what songs you listen to. The privacy statement states that it collects your IP address (and location if enabled) and assigns each person a unique identifier and they are allowed to sell all of this information to third parties. If you don't mind the privacy violations, you will be disappointed with the noise cancellation capabilities. I dutifully watched the in-app tutorial and the additional instructions on Sony's website about how to wear and use the headphones. I tried every single combination of the six different tips they provided, and repeatedly tried to re-seat the headphones into my ears to get the best seal possible. The noise cancellation was marginal at best. The one bright spot is the sound quality, which I judged to be better than AirPods. In the end, I’m buying another pair of the Bose Quiet Comfort 20 Acoustic Noise Cancellation headphones. Unfortunately I left my prior pair on a flight, but they worked superbly, particularly with canceling jet engine noise at 35,000 feet. The Sony WF-1000XM3's could barely put a damper on my tiny little 5000 BTU room air conditioner.

I have been waiting for a good set of NC earbuds and unfortunately, I am still waiting. Initially, they worked great. Great sound and above-average noise-cancelling considering they are earbuds. Then after just 2 days, I pulled the left one out for a minute then put it right back in but no sound and the app showed it was disconnected. I tried a re-pair and nothing. I followed every online instruction I could find but the L remains dead, completely 100% dead, no pair, no lights, no charge dead.

column8: Possibly the best earbuds I’ve used, sound wise and active noise canceling
column9: These are very well, quite positively the best sounding true wireless earbuds that I’ve used and they are definitely the best active noise cancelling ones (albeit with a small sample size). The controls work well, they surprisingly stay in my ears and they are comfortable. There is one knock for me and that is the battery life seems either a little exaggerated or too optimistic because I’m getting only about 4 hours out of them with Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) on but I’m getting much better than that with ANC off. I like the transparency mode for hearing what’s going on around me and the ability for it to figure out what I’m doing and adapt ANC to that is impressive. I wish they had some kind of volume controls on them but it’s not nearly as bothersome as I worried it would be...on a scale of 1-10 concerning how much that bothers me, the answer would be about 1 or 1.5. The earbuds covers are AMAZINGLY comfortable and they provide a very good seal. They also provide a lot of choices for tips. Concerning using these for active activities...I’d hard pass on that because these are not rated to be moisture or waterproof (bummer because at this price point I’d expect that) but careful consideration can keep these going for a long time, I believe. The sound quality is awesome for earbuds. These have punchy, right bass, a firm middle and a very customizable high or low end because of the EQ. The app works well but still isn’t my favorite...but at least it does provide more than just banal settings. The case size is a different shape than I expected (pic shows the case beside a Powerbeats Pro case) and the Sony case is actually more comfortable for me to carry than the other because it is skinnier. Charging is very good and very impressive. I might have the battery die more quickly than I expected (could be I am using a higher volume level than they tested) but I usually only have to put these in the case to charge for circa 10 mins to get close to full or a full charge. Super fast! Pros: Sound quality is outstanding (I like it better than Powerbeats Pro) Amazing call quality Great ANC (id say about 80% of the Bose 700 level) Feel and fit nicely Nice touch controls Lots of ear tips included Very nice case with USB-C charger FAST charging App has pretty good functionality Cons: Not moisture or waterproof Battery life with ANC for me is about 20% less than expected (could be my volume level) Only connects to one device at a time These are some outstanding truly wireless earbuds and they are the start of some great ANC capable ones that actually have a pretty good battery life or at least a battery that charges super fast. The sound is great, noise cancellation is awesome and these just work consistently and they work well. These are definitely not cheap...at all...but they are worth it for some people who love some good sounding earbuds with some great noise cancellation. These might not be worth it to some who’d rather just use over the ear headsets for noise cancellation because these do approach that cost point.

These are excellent for their form factor. In terms of noise cancellation, they are EXCELLENT for their size/form factor. Some of the NC is dependent on the seal (you get a lot of tip options with them and I'd venture you could use aftermarket tips of your choice too), but the active NC is very good. It won't be as good as over ear headphones, but still VERY good. Sound quality is decent and the accompanying app gives some EQ that does make a difference. Connectivity is the only quibble. First, you have to get used to each earphone pairing to your phone. This isn't a big deal, but it's an extra second before you're ready to go. Connection is strong. And other than maybe a little weirdness when pairing both to phone off the bat a few times, haven't had any connectivity issues. I do wish it could connect to more than 1 device at a time, but that might be a size/battery life issue that just can't be addressed with current, in place technology.

column8: Do not order these from amazon!
column9: I am so disappointed in this purchase. I was so excited to receive these headphones since the shipping took over a week but when they came, only one of the earbuds would charge properly. I tried everything possible to fix the issue with no success. I am extremely disappointed that $230 headphones came broken. I expected better from amazon. I would not be surprised if I fell for another cheap China dupe since I have received some other low quality products in the past. Truly disappointing. I will not be buying tech products on amazon anymore. Returning and buying these from Best Buy instead, I suggest everyone else do the same!

column8: Bad fit, not suitable for outdoors
column9: These earbuds fit very poorly. They're big and awkward, and easily come loose from your ears. I tried all the tips included with the buds, and the "spongy" ones seem to stay in best, but still come out if you're even a little bit active. They're also awful if you plan on wearing them outdoors. The noise cancellation can't handle even the slightest breeze without playing the wind over whatever you're listening to. This can be "turned off" and adjusted for wind noise, but has to be done every single time you put the earbuds on; this makes the ability to adjust it basically worthless unless you don't mind opening the app every single time you go outside. On top of this, they lack of any kind of water resistance which means you can't do any outdoor activity without the fear of breaking these very expensive earbuds. On top of the major issues, these buds also use touch-sensitive buttons for media control which make them really frustrating to use. They're super sensitive and easily accidentally activated. I've unpaused my music many times when taking the buds out of my ears. For positives, these buds have a USB-C charging case which is strangely rare among buds available on the market right now so I have to give them points for that. The case is also magnetic so the buds fall into place very well and are super satisfying to place into their case. My only complaints about the case are its size (it's huge) and the lack of simple indication of battery level. I just guess how long it's been since I last charged and plug it in when I think it might be low. Overall, I wouldn't recommend these since there are better buds on the market, especially at lower prices with better functionality.

I don't use these for working out so I don't know if they're good or bad for that. But what I can tell you is that these are the best sounding earbuds or headphones I've ever heard. I can't believe people are not giving them 5 stars. If you are not going to work out with them then these are the best quality buds you can purchase in the market, hands down. I can't believe Sony was able to make these sound so good in such a small size. And the noise cancellation and bass is mind blowing.

column8: Not compatible with Windows 10, falls out of ear
column9: I tried the earbuds daily for a week and I am returning them. First, the earbuds are very large and heavy, making it difficult to keep them in my ear while I work at my desk. I used the smallest ear tips, but they are still too big for my ears. When I talk, chew, or even make faces, the movement of my jaw, cheeks and ears make the earbuds wiggle out. The longest I can keep them in my ears is 10 minutes WHILE I AM WORKING ON MY AT MY DESK. I also have longer hair which occasionally tug on the earbuds and pull them out. I would never use these anywhere outside due to fear of losing them. The sound quality is just OK. Just OK, but better than most earbuds. The low end/bass is not powerful and I found myself struggling to hear some vocals. The ambient sound is constantly turning on and off when the room fan/air triggers the auto ambient controls. The noise cancelling is not as good as my Bose QuietComfort 20 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones (wired) and that was just the normal office noise. I'm not even bothering with airplane or outdoor noise. Again, I would not use these on an airplane because they keep falling out (I've seen many Airpods littering airport walkways). I'm glad I got the wired earbuds for travelling. But the thing that really got on my nerves is that they are not compatible with Windows 10. I searched discussion forums, video tutorials and manuals only to discover in buried discussion board that a "Sony Rep" promised an update by the end of August 2019 so the earbuds could be used with Windows 10. For nearly $250 I am not wasting any more time waiting on something that may not happen. I plan to use these only at my desk at work and not being able to use it with a Windows PC is a nonstarter. Last night I purchased the Bose Sound Sport Wireless at a local big box electronics store for $179. I paired the earbuds with my Samsung Galaxy immediately without trouble and listened to the that beautiful Bose sound. I paired it with my Windows 10 laptop this morning at work (I had to find a solution on a Bose forum to find the right steps). It paired and it sounds great. It took about 10 minutes from start to finish.

column8: Great Sound, Good Noice Cancellation, Room for Improvement
column9: 3.5 stars, rounded up. I'm coming from the over-ear Sony headphones (the WH1000 something), which have the best noise cancellation out there and an incredibly clear, immersive, and expansive sound stage. These are just a step below in sound quality, but still great. The noise cancellation is good but not great compared to the over-ear headphones. Still, it is night and day compared to Airpods, which of course have no active noise cancellation. The improvement in sound isolation and listening enjoying from having external noise largely cancelled (maybe 75% to 80% of the level of the over-ear headphones) is more than worth the price. FYI, the noise cancellation depends heavily on the earbuds creating a seal. I could not get them to work effectively until I up-sized to the largest tips and performed the little twist after insertion like the instruction video recommends. With past earbuds, I've used middle-sized tips, so it was a surprise that I had to use the largest ones. I did not find the App to be that useful, other than to turn off the adaptive sound control (which does not make a huge difference and requires giving up your location) and turn on the high-definition upscaling (which does noticeably improve the audio). Just set what you want and don't bother with it again. The lack of volume control is an inconvenience. I have not taken out my over-ear headphones or Airpods since getting these. Their size makes them much more convenient than the former for work and travel, and their noise cancellation makes them much better than the latter. UPDATE: Wore these on a 3-hour flight. The noise canceling was good—not great like the over-ear Sony earphones, but good enough to be preferable given the smaller form factor and convenience. However, the battery on the right bud ran out before the end of the flight, while the left bud still had about 20% left. On longer flights, unfortunately, these will have to be recharged intermittently.

Worked 1 day, then in subway car at rush hour it showed Connected in iPhone Bluetooth setting, I plugged them in and... my iPhone was playing but not a sound from this marvel. Disconnected from iPhone, connected again - sound started in this earbuds. Cam to the office with load coworker, noise was coming as Iif I did not put them on. I had better noise with $10 bought in pharmacy ear plugs better protected me from noise than these $240 (price+tax) thing. Next time same day I tried to connect I had to Forget the device and after that pressing on left earbud button for eternity did started flushing blue and red light, the device turned invisible. This is a junk - and ruined Sony reputation for me and probably more people who bought this thing. Returning this 'lemon' back.

column8: Great sounding earbuds, but doesn't stay in the ears. Had to return it
column9: These earbuds sound very good, NC works good only when something is playing. They are very loud, usually I adjusted the volume somewhere in the middle and it was good enough for most of the time. The real downside is the fit, they don't stay in my ears no matter what eartips I pick, and I followed the instructions to get a good seal, but no result. It gets really uncomfortable wearing them for an extended period of time. Sony need to come up with a better fit, maybe add some earhooks to it. It's really a bad fit for earbuds this expensive.
These earbuds surpassed my already great expectations. Great sound. Well made. Incredible noise cancellation. Beautiful case and earbuds. Worth the three week wait!

I tested the new Sony WF-1000XM3 noise canceling wireless buds for a few weeks by using them in all types of surroundings. I’ll just get this out the way, the sound was far more superior than other wireless buds. The sound and battery life are really a difference maker. The battery lasted about 7-1/2 hours with music and podcast listening. This is on par with some on-ear wireless headphones. Add in the charging case and you can get up to 32 hours' worth of playtime. This is really useful since I work at a desk for 8 hours a day. I'm still adjusting to the adaptive sound control. This is a neat feature in theory, as the buds can tell if you are sitting, standing, running, or riding on a noisy train. The only problem I have is the buds normally are set to standing when I am sitting, then in five minutes the music pauses to change to sitting. I am used of it, and that's nothing a software update can't fix. The Sony noise cancelling wireless buds come jam packed with a host features: Ambient Sound Noise Cancelling USB C Charging Case Dedicated Sony Connect App HD Voice Calling Support Adaptive Sound Control Instant Bluetooth connection As awesome as the Sony buds are, there are a few quirks that I didn’t like so much: The wireless buds are not water resistant. No volume controls on the buds. Touch controls have slow response time. Sony Connect app can be confusing at first usage. The buds overall fit may not be for everyone. May be too expensive for some. Overall Sony did a very good job with the WF-1000XM3 wireless headphones. The Ambient sound feature works just as well as the noise cancellation. With the ambient sound active I can hear people talk around me without the need to take out the buds. I really enjoy the noise cancellation on these pair of buds. The noise cancellation drowns out a good bit of noise, you may notice some degradation in the sound but not much. Music and Podcast sound really good, I have no complaints with clarity, and bass response. Sony has done an awesome job at checking all the boxes with the WF-1000XM3.

I won’t make this very long but I just have to say that The Sony WF-1000XM3’s are the AMAZING. I’ve had products from Beats, Bose, and Apple and nothing even comes close to matching the sound quality of these earbuds. The noise canceling is on par if not slightly better than my first generation Bose QC35’s. The sound stage is incredibly broad with sharp definition for all frequency ranges. I’m no audiophile but even my untrained ear can tell these earbuds are a massive cut above all others in this price range. I simply cannot recommend this product enough. To clarify I’m an iPhone user (iPhone XS running iOS 12.4). At the time of this review I have experienced no problems with the Sony app (which you need to make use of all the features of these bad boys). While these are made to be used with primarily android devices the loss of Siri is not enough of a deterrent for me. If you’re an Apple user and you’re considering the AirPods with the wireless charging case just do yourself a favor and spend the extra $30 for a set of these. I promise you will not be disappointed. These loss of wireless charging is a minor inconvenience for a truly life changing audio experience. AirPods in comparison sound lifeless after spending a session listening to the Sony’s. I hope this helped any Apple users with their decision making.

For a few years now, the noise-canceling earbuds of my choice have been the Bose QC20i, which are wired. The noise canceling is excellent, the sound quality... less so. My experience with Bluetooth earbuds has been that sound quality is mediocre, and noise canceling is often very poor. That said, I have been a Sony fan for decades and early reviews of the 1000XM3 were positive, so I thought I'd give these a go. When I first tried them out and played the tracks, from my iPhone X, that I typically use for earbud testing, I was blown away with how freaking GOOD they sounded! Clear, tight bass, unmuddled midrange and crisp treble. I was hearing things in tracks I had not noticed before. And this was with the "DSEE HX" sound improvement feature off. Next I tried the noise canceling. Unfortunately, the Sonys arrived just AFTER I returned from a trip with 12-hour flights, but I fired up a white noise machine and had it approximate the sound of a jet airplane in flight. When I activated the canceling, the noise dropped to a bare whisper, at least the equal of the Bose QC20i if not better. By default, the Sonys automatically adjust between noise canceling and ambient sound based on what it thinks you are doing. For the way I use them, I disabled this option and just set it to maximum noise cancellation. These adjustments are done through the Sony Headphones app, but once you set them, they stick. You can also adjust an equalizer in the app if you want and change the function of taps on the buds' control pads. Tapping the left or right bud, once, twice or three times can switch among noise canceling/ambient modes, pause/change tracks, answer/phone calls and more. Tap-and-hold the left bud temporarily switches to ambient so you can hear announcements and the like. Unlike the Bose ambient feature, the Sony made the sound seem natural, if a bit lower in volume. Note that there is no volume control on the earbuds, you'll need to use your device for that. Sony makes a big deal of promoting use of Google Assistant with the 1000XM3, but you can also use Siri and this worked fine. For either, you have to tap and hold the right earbud's pad until the assistant of your choice activates - you can't do a "Hey Siri" or "OK Google". Phone calls sounded good on both ends. Sony includes four sizes of silicone tips and three sizes of "comfort" tips that are a bit stiffer. For me, the silicone tips worked better and, unusually, the small size was best where on most earbuds I take a medium. I found the buds comfortable to wear over long periods, but those looking to wear these during exercise should probably pick something else as they don't claim to be moisture resistant. The earbuds turn on automatically when taken out of the charging case and turn off when returned to the case. If you are playing music, taking one bud out of your ear automatically pauses. You can use just one bud if you want. The buds will run 3-6 hours on a charge, depending on what you're doing, and the case can recharge them three times. A 10-minute charge gets you up to 90 minutes of playtime. The charging case has a USB-C connector - a short A to C cord is included. The case is elegant (black and copper), but I wish Sony had included a soft pouch to keep it in. (I have no doubt third-party pouches will appear.) Is there anything about the 1000XM3 I don't like? I did find myself accidentally tapping the control pads, but I expect that will diminish over time. They do stick out more than the QC20i buds so I would not try sleeping on a plane with these in. I do like that the LEDs stop flashing soon after you put them in your ears. For me, the Sony WF-1000XM3 is a superb set of earbuds and I look forward to using them on my next flight.
These are terribly insufficient compared to AirPods and barely work

column8: Noice Cancelling is lacking, Sound quality is good
column9: I usually use the Bose QC35 headphones, so I have pretty high expectations on the noise cancelling. These earbuds are OK for NC, but not in the same league as the QC35. They are particularly lacking when it comes to voices, but also have trouble with other types of ambient noise. I've tried them outdoors, office, and on the train. They never really satisfied in any of those environments, but they were useful in the office and on the train. Outdoors I feel they just didn't cut it as they seem very prone to wind noise effects, even in the slightest breeze. I'm not big on their comfort either, but I need to experiment with other size ear buds they provide. With Sony's recent NC headphones being so good I had high hopes for these, but if I had got the chance to try them first I would not have bought them. The User interface is also a mess which doesn't help. I've only had them a week or so, and I'm sure I will use them from time to time, as I can't wear my hat with the QC35, but I'll be watching for more advanced buds if Apple continues to refuse to make AirPods in black. Charger works OK, but manual is a joke. The quick start on the box, is only a quick start for charging and downloading their spy app. When you open the instructions there is a completely different set of quick start instructions (much more useful ones). It seems like they could not make up their mind on who was going to write the quick start guide, so we ended up with 2. There is no information with the earbuds on what their spy app is used for. There is mention of one function of it in the manual, but no mention that the function is part of the app. When you go on-line, many of the help pages are generic and talk about all their headphones together with no indication of which features are supported on which devices. OK so thumbs down on documentation. All my testing was currently done on an iPhone 5SE, as I didn't want to re-pair it if I attached it to my other iPhone or iPad right now. So I think these score 3.5+/5, I gave it 4 stars as there is not much competition. They don't really deserve a 4 though given the UI, no support for aptX, or remember pairing for more than 1 device (crazy). I may have updates as I've only had them a short time.

Sony almost defined perfection with these earbuds. They check off nearly all the boxes: Small stylish design for the buds and charger/storage case; decent battery life; and exquisite noise cancellation. The sound quality is among the best I have heard used, with excellent and customizable bass. The mids and highs are equally balanced and clear. I am a real audiophile, and I own just about every pair of high-end earbuds and earphones on the market today. These earbuds easily dominate the current market with two exceptions: 1) noise cancellation; and 2) call clarity. First, the noise cancellation is easily the best for wireless earphones, but it differs from Sony's high-end earphones or other competitor's full earphone (cans). However, in a small form factor some of this is expected. Buds are never going to seal like over-the-ear headphones. The noise cancellation filters out about 90% of background noise, but it is still there. The background noise is most prominent when you are not playing music, so you cannot use these to medicate or tune out background noise; it works best with music to override the remaining background noise. However, one of my favorite features, which I have not found on any other earbud/earphone, is Sony's auto adapt noise cancellation feature. The earbuds listen to outside sound and automatically adjust the level of noise cancellation. For example, the earbuds correctly switched from transit mode while I was on the train to walking when I got off the train. This is a spectacular feature for commuters using different transportation. I had maximum noise cancellation on the train, but when I was in traffic I could hear the cars and nearby noises. The adapt feature works correctly about 98% of the time. The second main area where these earbuds need improvement is their calling feature. The earbuds are unfortunately useless when making a telephone call. While I heard callers loud and clear, people consistently could never hear me – even in quiet rooms. I hope Sony will correct this issue with a firmware update. This lack of telephone clarity prevents these earbuds from being the commuter's ultimate earbuds. Sony did a great job with the phone app, which is rare among even the best audio companies. Often the app is a huge downfall. The app has a variety of custom equalizers, plus the ability to set and customize your own. It expertly controls the features of the earbuds, including the level of noise cancellation and auto adapt function.

column8: If you need this for phone calls, stay away
column9: I've had multiple sony speakers/earphones. You just have to give in and accept the fact that they never work well. Didn't work well on MDR-1000X, MDR-1000Xm3, WF-1000x, wf-1000xm3, MDR-EX750BT, SRS-GH-1, unfortunate but it is what it is. I keep buying new sony product thinking that it will be fixed, however it's always more of the same. Unfortunately. Connection: it constantly falls off connection - tested both on Ipad pro 10.5 1st gen, galaxy note 9, it goes in and out. Sometimes, it syncs well, other times not so much. Few occations there was a lag between left and right ear. Mic: Useless - people on the other side thinks you are a robot. Sound: Decent, well defined and neutral. Best in class but if you dont need NC there are many other great sounding earphones. Fit: Great especially with different earpiece they come with

column8: Great fit for my ears -- but that's the only good thing I can come up with.
column9: These true wireless buds come in a charging battery case featuring a USB-C connector for charging; in case you don't already have USB-C cables handy, the box contains a USB-A to USB-C pigtail. Battery life appears to match the promise of 6 hours play time and total of 24 hours with complementary charging from the case -- comparable to the main competition, Apple's AirPods. The buds are small and are fitted with removable tips, and they come with an assortment of tips of different sizes and types. To wear them you insert them and turn a quarter turn; I find them to be a perfect fit for my ear: they sit comfortably and don't fall no matter what I do, unlike the AirPods which have a hard time staying in my (I assume) oddly shaped ears. Installation, at least on an iPhone, is cumbersome. Not horrible, but a long shot from Apple's incredibly easy one-button process. I assume it's easier using NFC on a Sony phone. At least coming out of the box they enter pairing mode immediately; when I needed to pair them to a new phone I had to google to figure out how to put them in pairing mode -- not obvious. Each bud has one and only one action, triggered by holding the bud by the side and touching the center. The right bud controls play/pause and the left one noise control. Configuration options are limited. Music quality is superb. The buds support AAC, a guarantee of high quality on iOS, AptX for some Android phones, and Sony's own high end codec (if you play music through Sony's app). Unfortunately, this is where the good news end; After a couple of weeks of daily use I have a litany of complaints which make me believe the gushing reviews that have recently popped up in the press have been maybe a little "sponsored" by Sony. Problem #1: ANC *sucks*. First, setting up the controls so you can reliably trigger between the various modes using the left control button is amazingly unclear. You often get into a configuration where the bud pings but nothing changes. When you finally turn ANC on, however, you realize it wasn't worth the wait because it is completely ineffective. I fly a lot and it is completely incapable to cancel out engine noise, which is unforgivable considering Sony currently produces the top rated noise cancelling headphones on the market. Problem #2: buds occasionally lose sync, meaning there is a very perceptible delay between the left and right bud. It's unbearable. You can fix it by pausing the music, taking out a bud, putting it back in and restarting the music, but it should never happen. Problem #3: they can't be used for phone calls. The microphone is so bad that when I used them on a call, my friend interrupted me and said literally "I don't know what you're using but it's awful and I can barely understand you" -- and I was alone in my house with absolutely no background noise, in ideal conditions. I can only imagine how bad the sound is going to be if you're on the street or in a busy office. Problem #4: controls are cumbersome. You have to hold the sides of the buds and tap. It's easy to miss, and you can also trigger it unvoluntarily when you insert or remove the buds. There's also a smattering of more minor issues that are still aggravating: the voice feedback is sometimes going to a single ear, sometimes both; the case is small enough to fit in a pocket, but it's really massive compared to the diminutive AirPods case. In conclusion: these are earbuds with good audio quality, but they're marred with technical issues that make them impossible to recommend. While it's conceivable most of these issues could be addressed by a firmware update, I doubt fixing the lousy headset microphone performance is one of them. As they are today, I find it impossible to recommend this product.

I pre-ordered these back in early July. Received them the second week of August. The ear buds are phenomenal. The left side of the charger died after 4 days. Unable to charge left ear bud. Returned to Amazon. Unfortunately, long wait for replacement unit.

column8: completely useless if you use it with your phone
column9: I bought this because I wanted wireless earbuds with noise canceling feature. For that purpose, its great! Everything becomes really silent. I can concentrate while at work. Also, the audio sound is great. Not much delay, very similar to Apple's earpods. Sound quality is much better than Apple's. For sure. HOWEVER, when it comes to making a bluetooth calls with this Sony WF-1000XM3, it is completely useless. Sound is horrible to the caller. All of my callers will say "huh? I can't really hear you. What are you saying?" So I end up disconnecting it and taking my phone (in my case iPhone) which completely defeats the purpose of having a wireless earbuds microphone speakers.... I don't know how SONY decided that this is okay to sell, but it really needs more improvement. For that reason, I gave 3 stars for the sound quality. Oh, another problem is that my WF-1000XM3 does not work with my Windows 10 Laptop. This seems to be pretty common issue as I see many others with same problems. So, if you are looking for simple audio experience with great noise cancellation, this is for you. But if you are planning to make a calls with these, don't buy it. Also, it picks up a lot of wind noise if you jog. So not so great for jogging or outdoor activities either.
Phone calls suck

column8: Near the same NC capabilities as over-ear Sony XM3s. Very impressive.
column9: General thoughts: there's not much to say about sound quality. Typical sound quality from Sony: amazing, very comparable to the XM3 over ear headphones. The charging case is slightly larger than expected, but honestly, I really appreciate the extra battery reserve. Pros: Battery life is true as advertised for both NC and non-NC. The highlight for these earbuds is the noise cancelling. For earbuds, I was blown away. I'm comparing these to the Sony SPN700 sport earbuds which also have noise cancelling. The Sony spn700s do absolutely nothing compared to these. The NC is not exactly like the over ear XM3s but get shockingly close. It almost feels as if it blocks certain frequencies better than the over ears when using the foam tips that seal the ear canal. Cons: The touch controls aren't as responsive as I'd like them to be. There's a one or two second delay when touching, but really at this point, I'm just finding things to complain about. In fact, struggling.

column8: Great if you around or in heavy equipment.
column9: I love them. I was looking for a replacement for my corded won’t battery Bose QC20 noise canceling earphones. QC20s are the gold standard but you need a jack on your phone to use. Tied air pods - cool but they hurt my ears and no ANC. Tried The new Bose quiet control 30 - fell good but the ANC sucks and the neck thing never stays put. So I have been using the Sony WF 1000XM3 for about a week now. They are good. I walked up to a Caterpillar D6T and I wasn’t for sure if it running. It was. I’m really pleased with them. They have enough power to run a half day before needing a recharge. But that is with ANC on and sitting in a dozer running wide open and ac blowing. Phone calls are Not great in a peace of equipment. Update: I put the buds back in the case this morning and few minutes later put them back in right is dead. Rest did nothing. So I guess great for 6 months. Well I left them alone for a few days, ordered some air pro pods. On back order for a month:-( So I gave the Sony pods a try today and both pods are working again. :-)

I recently purchased the Sony WF-1000XM3 Wireless Earbuds, to replace my old wired headphones. I travel a great deal for work, and when I'm on a plane I like to disconnect completely! These earbuds are the perfect travel companion. The charging case is sleek and the charging time is excellent! The fit on these earbuds was ideal for me, as most earbuds don't fit my ear. These fit snuggly into my ear and doesn't hurt my ear canal. Also, they included 12 different tips, which definitely helps find the right size. If you are looking for a great pair of Noise-Cancelling earbuds, the Sony WF-1000XM3 is the way to go! Great quality and even better noise canceling!

Sound quality is good but noise cancellation not as good as my Bose earbuds. Also found that voice quality on phone calls is ok but not great. Had to stop using them on a conference call when people on the call had a hard time hearing me when I spoke. Disappointed for the price.

column8: High expectations due to its high price tag, but I can’t say that I’m 100% impressed.
column9: + Noise cancellation is good with “big” noises, such as the sound of a car honking, etc., but some sounds do “leak” through + Charge is great, but I have not been able to test how long it actually lasts; I will update shortly + The app allows you to change anything to desired settings; quite powerful and helps you figure out what settings you’ve adjusted to already + Ability to use one earbud whilst leaving the other in the case + Beautiful case and earbud design + Good portability + Great sound quality, but you will need to adjust out of the box due to a lack in bass + Comfortable after hours of use ± If you have small ears, then these may look a little odd ± When I enter my car, which also has Bluetooth, these earbuds go haywire; these do not take priority - Charging case scratches very easily - Easy to change settings (touch areas are too sensitive and easy to accidently hit) - Moments where you’re trying to change it from noise cancelling to ambient, and it stops telling you which setting it is on - Ambient amplifies surrounding sounds. I was able to pick up someone’s conversation about 20-25 feet away; was odd, yet cool, at the same time - Noise cancellation feature picks up some ambient sounds, such as the whistling of air from air conditioner in a car; wind noise setting hasn’t helped in this case - Not sweat or water proof, which is surprising at this price point - Not aptx Bluetooth, which is also surprising at this price - Using the right earbud touch control pad to pause music ends up shutting off that side. As a result, I have to pull out my phone in order to resume the music ------------------------------------------- I’m definitely not an audiophile when it comes to such products, and I was initially overwhelmed by these earbuds due to its pairing with an app. Coming from cheap $24 Sony wired earbuds to these presented as a learning curve, so I wanted to give it some time before I reviewed. I feel comfortable enough now and believe that I finally have an, so I’ll try and be as clear and detailed for those in a similar position, and in the market. To start off, these are expensive, yes. With a hefty price tag of $228, you can expect the following benefits: noise cancellation, with ambient switch, a charging case that boasts 24 hours of extra charge, and earbuds that claim 90 hours of play time, touch controls on either bud, voice assistance control, adaptive sound control, and ear detection (quick attention) for quick playing. There are far more benefits, but the product description can fill you in on anything that I may have missed. Is this impressive? I vote yes, it is, but how well do they work? Well, considering its price, I’d say it’s a solid 3-3.5 /5 product. Noise cancellation and ambient noise are the main selling point of these earbuds, with the advertisement geared around it as well. Is it industry leading as claimed? Eh... I’m not quite sure. I’ve tested these in several locations: I’ve gone kayaking with them (risky move due to its lack of waterproofing), ringing the doorbell to get the dogs barking, in the car on a road trip, and at a crowded festival. Based off of each situation, I’d say that these can be hit-or-miss. At the food festival I wasn’t able to hear individuals nearby. It did, however, pick up the conversation of people about 20-25 feet away with ambient switched on. It was hilarious, weird, and then annoying. Switching to noise cancellation was a nice treat, and it does work in crowded venues. Now, when it came to using it on a road trip, I had some noise leakage. On ambient, the earbuds picked up the whistling of the A/C wind. It was fairly annoying, so I decided to try noise cancellation. Unfortunately, it did not help at all. The whistling was still prevalent, which was quite the surprise. I tried the “wind setting” in the app and was met with similar results. The charging case, as mentioned earlier, is beautifully designed. It’s simple, eye catching, and effective, albeit delicate when it comes to scratches. It boasts a backup charge of 24 hours, and the top opens and closes with a magnetic latch. A full charge is indicated by an LED indicator (red), with the earbuds also giving off a red glow. Once out of the case, the buds change from red to blue, signifying that they’re in operation. Likewise, the earbuds are aesthetically pleasing, but also finicky when it comes to user control. Each one has touch control options, with the left controlling ambient and noise control, whilst the right allows for pausing, fast forwarding, and rewinding. Unfortunately, none of the buttons allow for volume control, and is done exclusively through the Bluetooth device. Furthermore, I don’t like how sensitive the touch areas are. When I brush my hair behind my ears, any accidental brushing ends up changing the settings or pausing the song. It’s annoying because sometimes I have to pull out of my phone to get the earbuds working again. Hopefully this is a firmware issue, it sometimes not resuming, and I’ll report back if it resolves. I glanced over this earlier, but it’s unfortunate that these are not waterproof earbuds, or sweat proof for that matter. As I do enjoy water activities, such as kayaking, these are not ideal in my situation. I occasionally workout or take the dogs on a run as well, but these are not meant for strenuous activities, so risk of them falling out is high. Walking is fine, but if you’re buying these for workout purposes, perhaps opt for another model. I won’t lie when I say that I was initially thrown off, in a good way, by the packaging. It’s exciting and new, and is clearly built to impress. There are 6 earbud tips that allow one to find their perfect fit, and they feel just as good as the product itself. Unfortunately, while everything is made out of quality material, I can’t say that it’s a good enough reason to justify the price. It suffers from issues here and there, and while some are preference, others are glaring technical problems. Again, I’m curious to see if these are issues that can be fixed through firmware updates. If not, then hopefully it can be improved upon in subsequent productions/models.

column8: Decent sound but Noise cancelling is over rated
column9: I'm no audiophile and the sound from these is good, but I expected a bit more for the price. As for the Noise Cancelling, it's okay, but nothing like the over the ear Sony 1000XM3's. I was hoping I could replace those for travelling with these smaller buds, but the Noise Cancellation and isolation just isn't there. Honestly for sound quality I prefer the Jabra 65T Active's. These Sony's have similar sound quality to the Samsung Buds, but at roughly double the cost. Update: After two weeks and one Transcontinental flight, I'm returning these. The noise cancelling is poor, and do us the fit, they just don't stay in my ears securely and having one drop down the side of an airplane seat was the last straw, the one good thing is that after falling out the blue light flashes so the passenger behind me found it and handed it back.

Update to review: Have had these a few months now, and the negatives are mounting. First, they are excellent for music playback. But they are useless for cellular phone calls. Not my words, but have had complaints from every person I have tried to talk to using them. Second, as a writer I wear headphones all day at work to keep out unwanted noises and distractions and to focus my mind. Well, they do not lie about the battery life - these are only good for about 3.5 to 4 hours before needing to be recharged. And the '10 minute' quick recharge to get four more hours is questionable at best. Third, while they are light, extended wear does cause some discomfort. I am still happy with them, but I have sent my LG's in for warranty repair. Original review: Very happy with this product. Gave up on the LG Tone HBS-1125 when my second set broke after only 9 months. Performance is actually better than I expected. With the app installed, the sound quality is remarkable. It is also really nice to have an adjustable equalizer, with both presets and programmable options. I did go through the paces of trying each size of earpiece out, and was startled by the extreme differences in both sound and noise canceling performance between them. Operating distance (from phone) is spot on at about 30ft.

column8: Excellent sound but some soreness and software/connectivity issues. Updated review.
column9: I've only had them a couple days but already (mostly) love them. First off, ear buds will never sound as good as over the ear cups, but they aren't an option for me. Cups give me headaches from the pressure and I'm prone to heat stroke, can't take the added heat/sweat from cups. That said, these come incredibly close and are the best sounding buds I've ever had. Very rich sound covering all ranges. The noise cancelling is really good. You can still hear voices and high notes but even they are muffled. With music or even just white noise at low volume you'll block out everything. I don't mind the look, classier than airpods and fairly sublte (more so than a goofy neckband). They fit snug and never feel like about to fall out. They are also very comfortable while wearing them, I forget they're even there. That said, the moment I take them out I realize just how much pressure they've been putting on my tragus. It downright stings as soon as remove them if wear them for a length of time. Enough so that putting them back in immediately isn't an option, it hurts. That may just be my big ears though. The other cons are the touch controls and connectivity. The touch controls are extremely sensitive and beep at the slightest touch. However, sometimes that's all they do is beep. They don't actually take the intended action like pausing or cycling ANC, just beep to acknowledge your touch. Connectivity leaves me doubting each bud actually connects independently as claimed. The signal is ussually good but I've found that the second bud inserted (tried left first and right first) can have issues. So far noticed the second bud inserted occasionally stuttering. Not a lot, but now and then. Also once so far the second bud inserted just turned off mid song (fully charged). I had to put it back in the case and then back in ear to reconnect. This may be fixable by future software updates. The case feels a little bigger than necessary and wireless charging would have been nice, but not a deal breaker. That said, it still easily fits (male jeans) in a pocket and feels sturdy and lightweight. I'm hoping the functionality issues will be addressed by a software update and they are minor compared to many non updatable cheapo buds. They sound absolutely terrific. So, in the end my only real word of caution besides the price is comfort. You sort of twist them in, so hoping I can find a position that doesn't hurt the tragus of my ear. If you don't have dumbo ears like me and don't mind the high price, go for it, I really want to love these. Update after having them a week - More software issues but better comfort: -I've actually encountered more software issues. They just updated the firmware yesterday which may or may mot be related. Today they suddenly dropped in volume about 50% for no reason and max volume was half what it previously was. I tried putting them back in the case and back in ear and they would not reconnect to my phone. I rebooted my phone and the buds again and regained connectivity but still at half volume and the left bud kept stuttering. I ultimately factory reset the buds and regained volume and connectivity. A pain but I'm still hopefull that as new as this model is Sony just released them before really ready, in beta software, which is what most companies do at this point, and that down the line the software will improve. -I intially found the foam tips a bit more comfortable in my ear canal but was getting real soreness in my tragus (cartilage nub in front of ear). The foam tips are a little less secure feeling so I was drilling them into my ears as deep as I could, rotating them as Sony reccomenfs so the front faces directly forward at a 90 degree angle to your body. I've found that the silicone tips rotated to get them in your canal but not as far, facing downwards a little puts less pressure on the tragus and feels very secury in place. This will vary depending on your ears, but point is I transformed pain to at most mild discomfort after extended use. P.s. I don't normally write such long reviews but for $230 and really high hopes for these, wanted to share real world vs. glowing paid reviews on tech sites. Overall, I do really like these ear buds.

column8: Great pair of true wireless earbuds
column9: These are just amazing for what you get and the app is very intuitive. I like that it detects your surroundings and adjust the noise cancellation to your surroundings. Only two flaws is that the automated ambient sound mode can be a bit wonky, but noise cancellation works great in manual mode. The other flaw is the magnet inside the charger someone activated my vape that was off and destroyed my vape battery.

column8: "Why do you sound like a serial killer?" or "Are you a mutant robot?"
column9: I really want to love these. I actually do love parts of these earbuds,but there is a huge problem that is likely going to result in me returning the earbuds. I keep having problems with my voice during phone calls. I've heard "why do you sound like a serial killer", "Are you a mutant robot", "It sounds like you are chewing on rocks every time you speak" and other complaints about the sound quality. Now, I don't actually hear this problem, as the people on the other end sound perfectly normal to me. This is the truly upsetting thing about the earbuds because everything else works pretty well. I originally bought the earbuds to wear while using my riding mower. The mower is loud, and I wanted something that could cancel some of the sound out and save my ears from unnecessary loud noise. These earbuds do the trick! They do make mowing the lawn a more relaxing experience, but I can't overlook this problem I keep having with my voice during calls. I don't want to keep terrifying friends, family, some poor unfortunate Airbnb customers.

The headphones are okay. Not great though. Noise cancelling is not as good as my Boses and I am not entirely sure their algorithms work correctly as far as identifying noise levels automatically and choosing specific noises to block out. I was in a noisy room with about 50 people chatting, wearing these and listening to music. Quickly realized that i was hearing way to much of the noise and pulled out the Bose - immediately experience that magic moment when you push the button and the noise disappears. Even bigger issue is that the connection to the phone is not as good. It wasn't droping very frequently, but enough for me to notice that it is far from stable. Additionally, although a minor inconvenience, but these do not handle the phone notification sounds very well. When an email comes in, one headphone stutters, then the other one. They don't do it simultaneously, which to me was kinda annoying. I understand that someone else may not be as picky, but I'd rather be honest and highlight this - for those who are. I loved the build quality though, and the fact that the music pauses when you take one of them out. Pairing was quick and simple. In my opinion, accompanying apps can use some work, but that's subjective and others may like the interface.

column8: Great with only one big issue...
column9: As far as sound quality I would say its really good but I wouldn't put it on the same level as the Sennheiser True wireless. The noise cancelling works surprisingly well. My only wish would be better fit. I tried all the attached tips and still it would at fall out of my ear. Which leaves me with no confidence wearing it out an about. I had to order additional tips to make it work; one thing that would have maybe made it better would be to have something similar to those Bose stayhear tips. That would have maybe made the Sony WF-1000XM3 my go to true wireless headphones to use. They do have a nice built quality and the case has a premium feel to it. Because confidence out the box in wearing these on a day in and day out is the purpose I gave it a 3/5. Hopefully in the next version they look at the bose style stayhear design.

column8: Great wireless earbuds, just a few points from perfect
column9: Overall these are great earbuds. The noise canceling is overall great but not perfect. I have owned a pair of Bose QC1 headphones for over a year and will say the sound quality is superier. Sony provides an app with multiple equilizer settings that i wish my Bose also offered. The only complaint i have so far is the noise canceling. I did not expect it to be as good as over the ear headphones but because its so good and so close to my Bose headphones, it's one thing i can point out as not perfect. I have noticed that some noises actual get magnified when using these. Bugs chirping or large machinery humming seem to be louder when using these. Other than these specific types of noises, the noise canceling is as good as my Bose QC1 headphones. The build quality is overall great. I have one small complaint, the hinge on the case seems flimsy. Im concerned it will break easily with normal use. Outside of that, these have very strong magnets to hold the buds and case lid securely, you wont have to worry about them falling out of the case. Because the magnets are so strong, even if the case lid breaks the earbuds would still be secure in the case. The fit and comfort are also great. They are obviously bigger compared to Apple Airbuds but still very light weight. Sony offers 7 different ear tips so you should be able to find the ones that work best for you. They stay securely in my ears and i have not had to think about them once i start using them. It's actually amazing how Sony fits so much technology in such a small package. Overall these are worth the price. These are way over my expectations and i would recommend these to everyone. The small concern i have with the noise canceling could be fixed with a future firmware update. GREAT EARBUDS!
Active noise cancelling feature did not work on the pair I received. Amazon service with the return has been outstanding, as always.
Fabulous ear phones. They almost never need to be charged compared to my Apple AirPods. They are much more comfortable than my AirPods also.

Don’t buy these for noise cancelling. I originally Bought these from Best Buy since they were sold out here, tried them out for a few days but ultimately I returned them for a few reasons. First off , they sit way too deep in the ear its ridiculously uncomfortable. Second , the Sony app is probably one of the worst apps out there, it can barley detect and connect to your earbuds, and when it finally does it’s so glitchy. Lastly, in regards to noise canceling , it literally doesn’t cancel anything out, maybe 10% of external noise at best. If you are expecting these to be as good as the over ear version, your gonna be disappointed.

column8: Sound nice ... if they will stay in your ear.
column9: Very disappointed in these. The sound quality is pretty good for the brief period of time that you can get them to stay in. I think the just weigh to much for earbuds because no matter what size ear insert I try, I can't get them to stay in my ears.

column8: One of the Best Wireless Buds Out There
column9: Sony has been in the Audio market for a while (think Walkman) and they know a thing or two about it. Pretty much all major movie and music studios use professional grade Sony headphones for their production purposes. I have owned a bunch of over-the-head Sony headphones as well as In-ear ones and they surely did a good job. When I was presented with an opportunity to use Sony's WF-1000XM3 buds, I didn't hesitate to buy them, because I knew Sony would not disappoint me. First of all, these wireless headphones are pretty comfortable compared to the other brands I own, I would suggest that if you are a new user, please try all the available silicon rubber earbuds provided in the box to fit your ear just right. Pairing these with my phone was also easy, just download the Sony Headphones Connect app and you will be set. Within the app, you will find multiple ways to customize your listening experience. What I like about these headphones is its noise cancelling function that kicks in and automatically detects the environment you are in and adjusts to it: if you are walking or in a noisy transport, it knows exactly what to do. You can also use your select presets or your own custom equalizer to make your music sound even better. I would say the charging case looks really cool and has a nice feel, however it could have been a bit smaller, also the lack of charging it wirelessly is something I would suggest Sony add to its next generation. I would also suggest that Sony include some type of water resistance to the buds as well as a way to turn volume up or down by using the touch pad on the headphones. These are the only improvements I can suggest to make these truly wireless buds even better. I like how these buds reproduce sound, its bass and treble are excellent. Most of all, its battery performance is superb! I went on a camping trip and these buds lasted me on and off for 7 days! I also enjoy using the Google Voice assistant perfectly integrated. All in all, these Sony headphones will be traveling with me a lot, no more dangling cords! With 10 min quick charge for 90 min of play time - one cannot ask for more! I look forward to discover what else Sony has in their pockets for us in the future. These headphones were offered to me at a discounted price for my fair review and testing.

These Sony WF-1000XM3 headsets are pretty nice. The adaptive sound controls successfully detected all my movements whether I was standing still or moving around. I was able to set the noise canceling to allow more sounds through the headset as I needed it to be while I was at work and changed the settings to block out more sounds when I was out for walks or I was in noisy environments. I was really impressed with how well the adaptive sound controls worked and they are probably my favorite part of these headsets. In an office environment, they worked great, blocked out all the ambient noises and muffled out a lot of voices as well. When I was out walking, again it blocked out most sounds, except wind noise. Wind noise seemed to be amplified with these on, but I'm guessing the wind was able to enter my ear from a lack of a good seal from the headset since the noise sounded a lot like what I hear when riding a motorcycle and the wind entering the helmet. Sounded a lot like a wind tunnel in my ears. These are a little bulkier and heavier than some of my other wireless bluetooth headsets, but they weren't too bad really, but that might be a reason I had a little issue with the fit. A few times the headset fell out of my ears when I just looked down or if i barely touched it on accident, they would fall out. I almost lost the left side when I looked down over a sink full of water and it fell out of my ear. Luckily i caught it in mid air before it fell into the water. The sound quality from the headsets are pretty good and the sound quality improves a little when you turn on the DSEE setting, although it does drain the batteries faster. With the Adaptive sound controls turned on and the DSEE turned on, i averaged about 3 1/2 hrs of use before they needed to be recharged. With DSEE off and adaptive sound controls on, I was regularly averaging 6 hrs of use before recharging. This headset was a good buy for me and I have no regrets. They have become my go to headset for daily use. :)

column8: New step into BT and ANC
column9: I like it because of convenient. Nice BT and ANC tech added into this little iem. Cannot control volume from iem. Ears got itchy due to iem near ear canal built a little to big for my ears. Nice iem in the end; however, SQ is no near as my other wired iem. Noble K10C, Savant, Encore, and now Khan. IBasso IT04. Sennheiser 800 iem.

column8: Choose the right tips for best results
column9: Scooped up a pair of these before they went sold out everywhere. I've used them for about a week now. I will say I had to play around finding my perfect eartips to get the best sound quality and noise cancelling results (the Sony app advises you of this, and although it seems like the sort of thing you could brush off, don't). So if you, like me, try them out with the stock tips and are even remotely unimpressed or disappointed, try going through the different tips and cycling through the noise cancelling settings while standing near a noise machine or a fan or something similar. It makes a huge difference and you'll know when you find the ones that work. It really does blow me away the level of noise cancelling they have achieved on wireless earbuds. Excellent build quality and premium feel too, even though I was surprised at how small and lightweight they are given how much larger they appear than a lot of competitors in so many review videos. I was expecting them to really look and feel bulky, but they somehow don't when you're holding them, even though they just are objectively quite bulky in relation to what else is out there. Which brings me to my only complaint--their general shape and design just reminds me a lot of those Bluetooth mics people wore a few years ago for phone calls. Sennheiser and B&O have much cleaner and better designs and sizes, but I do understand Sony had to make room for more stuff and presumably bigger batteries (battery life kills it BTW, much longer than the competition). Anyway, pick yourself up a pair if you come across them or just put an order in so you get them once they're back in stock. I don't write product reviews often but these are really something pretty special and I know how helpful they can be when you're considering buying something like this.
Me gustan, no molestan en los oídos y son sencillo de utilizar. La música se escucha muy bien y reduce el ruido ambiente.

column8: One and Only Noise Canceling Buds
column9: If you are looking for the perfect wireless earbuds that include every single feature from wireless charging, small, compact and portable, waterproof, all day battery, multiple audio coding formats, durable and stays in your ears then it has yet to arrive, but in the meanwhile the Sony WF-1000XM3's are the best of the bunch in my opinion and here is why: The only truly wireless earbuds with active noise canceling, yes they are not the Sony WH-1000XM3 but the Sony WF-1000XM3 offers a decent experience when it comes to blocking those outside noisy environments and you can adjust how much ambient noise you want to hear through the Sony Headphones app. The battery life has been very good so far with active noise canceling on, I would say I do get the rated 6 hours on one charge and I love how the earbuds tell you how much juice they have when you first put them on through an audible voice letting you know the percentage and when they are paired. Talking about charge, one downside is that there is no indicator on the charging case that tells you how much charge there is left on the charging case, there is only a red light indicator when you plug it in to charge through USB-C cable and did I say USB-C, finally an industry must when it comes to cables not some propietary Lightning or yesterday's micro USB connections. The form factor of the earbuds is not bad, they tend to stay in my ears with the right sized earbud tips that are included with so many options and different materials to choose from also, they do sometimes feel like they are coming loose after a while, but they have yet to completely pop out of my ears. One thing that is not clear is if they are water resistant, by the looks of the Sony marketing material these are suited for your casual business or just walking outdoors type individual, so do not take them out in the rain and be weary if you sweat a lot during workouts. I think it is time to wrap up this review with the most important aspect of any headphone, the sound. The Sony WF-1000XM3 sound is balanced, the highs, mids and bass are all excellent and you can tweak the equalizer settings using the Sony Headphones app. I like to listen to my music at loud volumes which probably is not the best for your ear health, and one thing I noticed is that these wireless earbuds are not very loud even at the highest setting. So, if you are looking for one of the better premium options of truly wireless earbuds these Sony WF-1000XM3 deserve a buy.

column8: It just works? ... spoke too soon.
column9: Update - Changing my review temporarily while I figure this out ... but I didnt use these for a week or twoa nd started using them again ... One thing I dont like is when adaptive sound control changes it cuts sound out for a bit. I have an AC near me so this forces a mode change quite a bit. Anyways thats not the issue but today and yesterday twice it has just stopped playback sound ... im not sure if it is due to the app or what? I have to put them back in the case and start over to get them reset. It has only happened twice and the past two days, not sure if its an update that hit or a fluke. Original - After I got my free samsung buds (I thought I would never use) I got hooked. When I lost those I tried Bose, I tried Jabra ... I figured Id look for 'batter ones' neither lived up to the hype .... often dropping out or being uncomfortable ... I saw sony was coming out with noise cancelling and just drooled!!!! So far I have been wearing them most of the day and they are great .... connection was fast and easy ... i cant hear my own thoughts much less anything outside of my zone. Right now im typing on a loud mechanical keyboard .... nothing. The sounds is good, there is a lot of sound profiles ... I feel like there could be some more punch, maybe some of that can be added via tuning ... but for an earbud it just .... works ... no earbud cutting off like bose and jabra .... touch pad so you arent jamming it into your ear to click like the Jabra ... and noise cancelling!! My only complaint is that I have this feeling like they are going to fall out. I need to play with the fit. I have shaken them vigorously and not had any issues but I think I just need to get the perfect pieces for a better fit. The only pos of Samsung is comfort. Even via gen2 these have semi better sound but if I'm trying to sleep over the gf snoring I chose Samsung cause of comfory

column8: great sound quality - a couple minor issues
