column9: right ear bud is randomly disconnecting. then left ear bud wouldn't turn on or connect. Putting the ear buds in the case and doing the reset while holding down the buds for 20 seconds worked for the time being.

Sound quality and noise cancelling are so good. I wear them on the treadmill and they stay in fine. I can even leave my phone in a cubby and the connection stays good as I move around the gym. I also wear these in my open office and I am able to hear myself think. Amazing product.

column8: Great sound, when i wasn't cutting out...
column9: Loved everything about these except.... It was very faint but I could hear the song slightly skipping/cracking/dropping signal when playing. When testing the same songs with wired buds this did not happen. I am giving up on true wireless until they get this issue fixed.

column8: Sounds is great, fit is mediocre, features need work
column9: There are a lot of true wireless earbuds available. They all have one thing in common: by their very nature, they are heavier and bulkier than wired earbuds. These Sony buds are no different, but unlike others I have tried, they make little attempt to contour the bulk to the shape of a human ear. They have an oblong shape that I, at least, had a hard time getting to stay in my ear (they do come with a set of tips in different sizes, but none of them gave me what I considered a good fit). The sound: This is where Sony can't be beaten. These sound great, with a really nice range for all types of music. I also tried them with an audiobook, and again I have absolutely no complaints. They seem good at blocking out ambient noise, though I guess you'd need to be on a plane for this to be essential. All earbuds give decent noise reduction. Given that I love listening to audiobooks, a lot of the content I choose is mono. Other earbuds I have tried let me remove one bud and continue listening with the remaining one, which is the best of both worlds for outdoor exercising. I don't want to block out traffic sounds if I am walking along the side of the road. When I removed the left bud, they both stopped playing. You need to use both of them or they don't work. Pairing with my iPad was effortless. I just removed them from the case, opened the Settings app, and chose these buds off the bluetooth list. I had no connectivity problems. I will likely save these for traveling, where movement is minimal and noise reduction is needed. For everyday use, just for walking, these will not be my first choice.

The quality of the bluetooth is either lacking heavily or I got a broken set. When paired to my phone, if I put my phone in my pocket the earbuds start to cut out to the point where now I have to walk with my phone in my hand. I figured it may be a phone issue but then I paired the earbuds to my computer and if I move more up to 2 feet away or turn my head the earbuds will disconnect. Noise-canceling works great but this is my first pair of noise-canceling anything so I may not be a great judge. Sound quality is alright I honestly expect it to be clear all the time for the price but have experienced a couple of crunchy trashy bits of sound.

Bought these a couple of weeks ago. I already own the WH 1000mx3's. Best sound quality of any true wireless earbuds! The noise cancelling works ok but not up to the over the ear WH's. Currently having major problems with audio quality on my Windows 10 laptop. The sound stutters and drops out - really doesn't work at all!!! This is a major problem that supposedly was addressed with a firmware release a couple of days ago. However, the problem still remains for me. Please Sony, step up and fix this!

constantly disconnects from my iphone xs. Update did nothing for this issue. My phone is right in front of my face with absolutely no other electronics on around me and it will still disconnect every 10-30 minutes.

column8: i found the active noise cancellation to be ineffective
column9: i bought this hoping it would be a good noise cancellation set of earbuds, but it isn't. otherwise it works fine, just not worth the price.
Great earbuds, quality sound, user interface, bass, the only flaw, no water resistance

column8: I wish I liked them more than I do
column9: The sound quality and noise cancellation of these earbuds are amazing. The hear through option works relatively well. I just can't find a good fit of ear tip for my ear. I was able to find a moderately comfortable fit, but I could not be fully active while wearing them. They often fall out of my ears. I really want to like them more, but I just don't.

column8: Needs the app, and noise canceling not that great, expensive for what you get.
column9: I really want to like these headphones more. I preordered them and have had them for a few weeks now. Have used them around town, and during traveling. I like the noise-canceling technology in general and often use them. I have/had several other products from Sony and Bose. I was really looking forward to a true wireless noise-canceling headphone. Well, they are not great, not horrible. It is important to note that you need an app to get the most out of these headphones. You can control the sound quality and equalizer via the app, but you have to dig into the app to control all of that. Pros: The case/charger is slick. Very well put together. Neat and tidy package. Sound quality is excellent once you dig into the app and adjust the settings to your preferences. Other reviews don't seem to have realized that the app makes these very adjustable. Cons: In the instructions, it says that if noise-canceling does not seem to be working try to seat the unit in your ear more or try other rubber ear-piece. In short, unlike full headphone or in the ear headphones, these are primarily relying on isolation, and not sound wave interference. I have tried to swap out the supplied earpieces with a Comply foam earpiece, and this helped considerably, however fitted with the Comply foam they don't fit in the charger as well. I will continue to try a few other options for the Comply foam to see if I can get a good balance. On an airplane, these do just about nothing. I have the Bose QuietComfort 20 headphones and on a plane, the Bose are superior to Sony. No contest, with the Bose, usually the lowest setting on the plane entertainment system is almost too loud. The app can be confusing. Some of the settings are not clear and in some cases it seems that the headphones revert back to the default setting. I have the most recent version, but once you close the app many of the settings, especially related to noise-canceling seem to revert. Equalizer settings seem to be held. Finally, the tutorial is about how to get them in your ears, not how to use the app or headphone. Very stupid. I'd expect better from Sony. I'm keeping these since they are convenient, and are decent around town. I'll still try different foam earpieces to get better performance. Unfortunately, they are likely not worth the cost. On planes, I will still use the Bose QuietComfort.
Excellent sound. Good noise cancelling stay charged long time . comfortable
volume could be a little louder

2 3 4 5 This has got to be one of the quietest and robust wireless headphones I've owned. Great sound quality and the fit and finish are great. The battery life has been fantastic. Super easy to pair with your phone I would recommend these to anyone wanting noise cancaltion in wireless headphones that work

column8: Great Sound! Custom Fit still learning....
column9: I like the shape, the case, and the ease of charging these. They are great sound and I think compared to all the others out there I think they have some of the best sound. I think its hard to find a ear bud that's truly noise canceling. At that same time I think the ear buds can get to be too much in my ears and suction so much that it can become uncomfortable and I feel like I need to pop my ears. But the ear buds come with so many ear bud covers that I just need to play with the one that fits me best. Hats off to Sony for thinking on this and for giveing the user so much control.

column8: Not perfect, but damn near close
column9: CONS: - I get really paranoid about wearing these while sweating. How much sweat will break these? Biggest con is definitely not being water/sweat resistant. - Range isn't as good as you'd think even on the "stable connection" setting. My audio would cut in and out if I was more than two rooms away from my phone. - No volume controls - Some bugs (see below) ******************************************* PROS: - I've dropped these on my vinyl flooring several times so far and it hasn't noticeably damaged them - Although the automatic pausing of media after removing an earbud is standard on most higher range Bluetooth earbuds, I gotta say I just really enjoy this feature. - The noise cancelation setting in terms of just how noise cancelling it is genuinely blew my socks off considering these aren't a closed over the ear headphones. When I turn on noise canceling I feel like I've been yeeted into a vacuum. - I really appreciate the equalizer built into the app. Being able to easily adjust from heavy bass for some media to bright and light for others to the "dialogue" setting for podcasts is something I now feel like I can't go without. I've been spoiled by these earbuds. - Charge in their case incredibly quickly - USB-C charging - DSEE HX audio processor (essentially upscales low fi mp3s) - Better audio quality than airpods ******************************************* BUGS: Sometimes the sound on whatever I'm watching will be super quiet, to the point where I can't make out dialogue. More rarely, the sound cuts out completely. I have to put these in their case and take them out again to "reset" them and the issue goes away. I'd say I have to do this once every two days on average but I have been almost exclusively using them (unless they die) for over a month for the purpose of reviewing them. I could see this being a problem because although you can turn them off via the app, there's no way to turn them on without the case that I know of - meaning if you encounter this bug you have to take the case with you at all times, which is extremely inconvenient. ******************************************* USING ONE EARBUD: You could use one earbud at a time but please keep in mind you'll lose some functionality. For instance if you use the left earbud alone you won't be able to answer calls, and you'll only be able to control playback or the Google assistant feature if you remap one of those functions to the left earbud (it only lets you remap one function but you'll get both). If you remap aforementioned functions to the left earbud, you lose the quick attention mode function and the ambient sound control function (although you can just do that in the app) which by default are left earbud functions. Hopefully that made sense.

column8: Great sound in such a small package
column9: The Sony WF-1000XM3 earbuds are the first set of earbuds I haven’t had massive issues with. Are they perfect? No, not by any means, but they’re pretty great. TLDR Pros Great sound quality Comfortable Easy setup Great battery life Noise canceling and ambient sound Feature rich application USB C charging case Cons Issues using with a PC Software upgrade is cumbersome No volume control on headphones Full Review What’s in the box? Headphones Headphone carrying/charging case USB C charging cable 7 sets of variously sized earbud inserts Setup & Software The software setup and pairing was very simple. Download Sony’s app from either Google Play or the App Store and follow the on screen prompts. Each headphone will greet you with a message. “Power On, Battery <Level>, Connected” The setup on iOS and Android went smoothly, neither device experienced any problems during the initial configuration. The software allows you to configure various settings for your headphones. This includes the Ambient Sound and Noise Canceling features which accommodate four presets for sitting, walking, running, and public transportation. The equalizer can also be adjusted via the app. The equalizer has 11 presets, including a manual and two custom presets. Other options include Sound Quality Mode. Used to to set either quality or stable connection priority. DSEE HX toggle Change function of left and right headphone touch buttons Automatic Power Off Notifications & Voice Guide Automatic Software Download I’ve experienced two problems. The first was with updating the headphone software. On iOS my updates are failing on software transfer. I’ve tried several troubleshooting measures and I just can't seem to get it to work. I am running the iOS 13.1 beta at the moment so I cannot say this is strictly a problem with the headphones themselves. I was able to successfully update on my Android device running Android 9 (Pie). The second problem was with a Windows 10 PC. I was able to connect to my PC but the audio would not work. There was a software update released to fix this problem, you will need to download and install it via cell phone before the problem is fixed. Comfort Once you get the sizing down, these headphones are extremely comfortable. I wear them most of the day at work and I haven’t experienced any discomfort nor have I experienced a drop. Sound Quality For earbud style headphones, these blew me away. I prefer using the Bright preset and all my music sounds crystal clear. I love the fact that these little headphones are able to produce the amount of bass that they do. Battery Life On a typical day, I’ll use the headphones for 3-4 hours and then place them in the charger for an hour during lunch or during a meeting. I’ll take them back out and use them for another 3-4 hours before placing them back in the charging case for the day. Features The Noise Canceling is pretty good. Once this is activated the volume is very slightly increased and almost all background noise disappears. This is really helpful in an office environment or a noisy home when you’re trying to get work accomplished without distractions. Noise Canceling is one of the stand out features of these headphones. The Ambient Sound feature is extremely useful for hearing your surroundings while listening to music. My wife and I are able to carry out conversations while my headphones are in and my music is going at a low volume. It's a situational feature, but it has its uses. The Touch Controls can be customized based on user preference. By default, the left headphone controls the Noise Canceling, Ambient Sound, and pairing options. The right headphone can be used for music controls. Holding your hand up to the side of a headphone will pause the audio being played. Once your hand has been removed, the audio will play again. This is useful for a quick pause to hear your surroundings. Swapping Bluetooth devices works relatively well. I’ve only experienced minor hiccups occasionally with devices not wanting to relinquish connection. Google Assistant works fairly well. I do not typically use GA, however for testing purposes I decided to use it. GA chirped in each time I initiated it via voice command and directly from my cell phone. No complains for the GA feature! I really wish that volume control was included as a touch feature. Having to change the volume on the device you’re using can be inconvenient at times. This is by far my biggest complaint. Overall I give the Sony WF-1000XM3s 4.8 stars, rounded up to 5.

Sony does not offer any replacement parts for this item. If you lose or damage anything, you cannot get a replacement. Dropped my charging case into a sewer drain accidentally and the only option is to repurchase the item. Does not seem very customer friendly.

column8: Noise cancelling ability is nothing special
column9: I purchased these ear buds specifically for noise cancelling as trade reviews remarked how great they were. One reviewer in fact said that a riding mower came up behind her and she didn't hear it. Well, I'm here to tell you that she must have been BLASTING her music not to hear it. These buds do no better a job of noise cancelling than many of the buds that came before them and that are less costly. On the plus side, the sound quality is excellent if you're just interested in listening to music. I purchased them for use to lessen the noise of yard machines while cutting the lawn, etc. And I have passive ear buds that are better. I will be returning them.
Great noise canceling, sound quality, and battery life. Case is a little bulky and infrequent bluetooth connectivity issues.
Performs as advertised.

I really wanted to like these headphones, I've used a good handful of the options out there and keep searching (for different reasons) and these seemed perfect but really disappointed. Pros 1. Excellent sound quality 2. Best noise canceling in portable headsets I've encountered 3. Excellent supporting phone applications Cons 1. Substandard bluetooth connectivity - constant drops and signal interruption (I've used $50 headphones with much better bluetooth stability) 2. Headphones will lose sync with each other and play about a second off (creating some interesting musical mixes) 3. After only 3 months battery life has degraded to ~ 2 hours of continuous use There's some other minor issues, but for me the cons are the ones that will cause me to trash this product and wait a few years before trying sony again. The sound quality and noise cancelling are great, which makes the short-comings all the more frustrating. Its possible I just got a defective set, so buyer beware.

column8: Not as expected from Sony brand
column9: Sound is great. Noise cancellation toggles itself between ambient and noise cancellation on flights. Not good for continuous wear and these are not sweat resistant. Also not good stay in-ear as they slip off sometimes.

column9: Did not ike the fit in my ears or the quality of the sound of music. The heqdphones that came with my iphone arensuperior.

column9: Earbuds sound great, better than Apple AirPods. However bluetooth connection (with iPhone) keeps dropping. It'll reconnect automatically 1-3 seconds later but happens almost every time I use it. Too expensive a pair of earbuds for this to be happening.
These headphones work great and sound amazing but they drop at times. My software is up to date and everything. They really sound great so I can overlook that until they figure out a patch

column8: As good as it gets - but not really mind blowing
column9: I've tested many different active noise canceling (ANC) headphones in the past and currently also own the original over ear Sony MDR-X1000, the in-ear Bose QC20i, and the Jabra Elite Active 65T (passive noise canceling only). I had been looking forward to getting these new true wireless ANC ear buds because I've recently gone from flying several long distance flights overseas to taking more frequent but much shorter business trips that take less than a couple of hours. This change means I no longer check my luggage, so carry-on space is suddenly more precious and my over ear Sonys started to feel too bulky. On the first day of testing them, I was initially really disappointed with their ANC performance. After giving it a couple of days, however, I figured out a way to make them work and now that I've used them for a week, I can give a balanced review. Read on for the details. FIT & COMFORT This was the reason for my initial disappointment. Despite offering seven different ear tips, I simply couldn't find a good seal with any of them. After an hour of frustrating A/B testing with white noise playing loudly from my home stereo system to simulate airplane noise, I could hardly tell when ANC was active and when it wasn't. I then decided to swap out the ear tips with the large one from the Jabra Elite Active 65T, and immediately I noticed a massive improvement in passive noise canceling and overall fit. The difference seems to be that the Jabra ear tips are slightly wider so they naturally block out outside sound more easily than any of the included Sony ear tips. I wasn't very happy with that frankenstein solution though, so I was very close to returning them altogether. The following day I tested it again. This time, after a lot of twisting and pressing, I was finally able to get a decent seal with the Sony ear tips (the largest silicon tips). You have to press the ear buds in quite firmly, I wouldn't say it's painful, but I can't really say it's a comfortable and convenient experience. But it works, after a few seconds of pushing and adjusting. Overall, I'd give fit a 3 out of 5. I was able to test using it during workout and it stays more firmly in my ears than the Jabra - perhaps not very surprising considering how much harder I have to press them in. Sony should offer wider ear tips with the package, or they should take inspiration from Bose, whose ear tips are oval shaped and thus fit more naturally in most people's ears. NOISE CANCELING PERFORMANCE Let's get real. They're not even close to the excellent performance of my Sony over ear cans, but for day to day commuting and the occasional flight, they're "good enough". For long haul flights, I'll still bring my large cans, but for shorter trips, the true wireless buds are simply more convenient and means I can bring a smaller carry-on. I think they do a good job of canceling out low frequencies, but in the treble range you notice the biggest difference between these and the over ear cans, where the over ears block out much more. I felt more distracted when there was a public announcement on my flight over to Berlin than I normally do with the over ears. That said, it's still a very noticeable difference if I switch ANC off, so they're definitely making a difference. Just not as dramatic as I'm used to with the over ears. I also compared them between the over five years old Bose QC20i, and I have to say that Bose does an overall better job of canceling out mid and high frequencies. They're about on par with the Sonys on lower frequencies. Perhaps this is an unfair comparison since the Bose comes with a separate unit on the cord and likely has room for more advanced processors and battery, but it's worth noting that despite five years of technological advancement, there are still noticeable compromises associated with true wireless ear buds. Overall, ANC gets a 3/5 for me. It's good for being true wireless ear buds, but they're not really better than the over five year old in-ear technology from Bose QC20i, and it's debatable how much of a difference ANC makes compared to just getting a decent passive noise canceling through a good seal. Personally I do appreciate the cancelation of the low rumbling from the flight and car engines, which can't be achieved through passive noise cancelation, so for me they're worth the added premium. But the ANC is not even close to the latest over ear cans from Sony, so if your highest priority is to cancel out noise, you're better off with their latest over ears WH-X1000M3. SOUND QUALITY They sound really good. Basically the entire frequency range is crisper and clearer compared to the Jabra, which sounds muddier in comparison. When using the EQ in the app, the bass can be cranked up to be really impressive, much stronger than the Jabras, but crucially much clearer and not as "boomy". I'd give sound quality a 5/5, about the best I've heard from in ears. This section is short because there really isn't much else to say than: wow! OTHER OBSERVATIONS The case is beautiful - but really big. I hesitate to put it in my front pocket, which is annoying because the whole point for me is to carry them with me all the time. Maybe I'll get used to it, but I already thought the Jabra case was big, and the Sony is almost twice as bulky. When I have a bag with me, they always go into the bag instead. Compared to the Jabra, the Sony is really slow from picking an ear piece up from the case to being able to answer a phone call. With the Jabra, it takes about two seconds, but with the Sony, it takes about ten - and then you still need to manually press the ear bud to answer the call (Jabra does that automatically). This means that in order to be on the safe side, you have to answer the phone call with the phone first, and then ask the caller to wait a few seconds while you connect the headset, which is really annoying. It's clear that Jabra has more experience with creating ear pieces made for phone calls. Call quality is ok, but you tend to hear the other end a bit too clearly, with too much treble, making me want to turn the volume down. The Jabras have a rounder call sound quality that is easier on your ears. I haven't heard more frequent complaints about the audio quality on the receiving end compared to the Jabra so I'd say they're on par there. These ear buds are technically not sweat or water resistant, but I've used them at the gym without any issues. I wouldn't worry about the lack of IPX rating there, but I might hesitate to use these in pouring rain. The touch controls take a bit of time getting used to. I find that I often miss the touch target and other times nothing happens on the first tap. Perhaps this will improve with a future firmware update. OVERALL This is a good buy if you care about sound quality and canceling out noise in a true wireless package. If you do a lot of public transport commuting and have some space in your messenger bag to store the relatively bulky case, they're probably an ideal buy. However, if noise canceling is your top priority, you're better off with over ear cans WH-X1000M3. If portability and water resistance is more important than noise canceling or the best sound quality, you're better off with the Jabra Elite Active 65T. All are great purchases in my opinion.

These are big. They are big in your ear. They are too big for a pocket, looking for a small bag for them, or wheels. The biggest problem with a big earbud is that they tend to wiggle out, so you push them back in, but that activates the cryptic button sequences to clobber your music or hang up your phone call. You gotta love the battery capacity and the sound is pretty good - but these are gonna get parked near a workstation and be my third or fourth option. Hard to think of them as portable, let alone mobile. So - I will roll back to the Jabra 65s as my EDC. Maybe try the B&Os next. My biggest gripe with the Jabra's was the lack of magnetic seating in the case. My poor sounding SoundPeats remain the most convenient usage profile.

column8: I love Sony but these do not meet expectations
column9: When noise cancelling is active the right side produces a terrible sound that is simply unacceptable for a product in this price range. I love Sony, for this reason it it very hard to leave this review... I can't recommend them.
Sounds great

I have finally found the one! I am truly in love with these earbuds. I have been using them consistently since the day I received them. First I want to say the packaging and set up was truly breeze within 5 minutes I was set up and ready to rock out. I was really impressed by all the different ear molds that they provided there was many different sizes and even two texture types insuring that you will find the perfect fit for your ear. These earbuds have very powerful bass and the sounds come out perfectly clear. The noise cancelation is amazing and definitely let’s you get lost in the music. I really like the ambient noise control and use that while I am walking or at work so I can hear when somebody calls me out. The battery life is great and they last me all day and when I am talking on the phone the receiver can always hear me well. I also like the touch sensitive controls which allow you to control the noise cancelling and also pause and change songs. The case is a little big but still very pocketable. My only wish is that they could be sweatproof so that I can take them to the gym, maybe the next version!

At first they hurt my ears, luckily they came with so many different ear bud sizes that I found my fit. Now they are perfect for me. The sound quality and customization feature is amazing. Would recommend to all

I expected the product to live up to all the hype. I was especially hoping the noise canceling feature would work. It did not. The buds were somewhat awkward to wear, but that was a minor issue. The range of sound was just average. I cannot recommend these earbuds.

column8: Look no further this is the go to device for true wireless
column9: Pre-Ordered these as soon as I heard about them. I also ordered the powerbeats wireless as well because I was indecisive of which one I would choose. Luckily they came around the same time. So I was able to test them out. And I must say hands down Sony did an amazing job. I gave the Powerbeats to my wife. Thought I would enjoy the over the ear more but I was able to get a great fit with the earbuds which leads to my next point. The noise canceling is the best feature and it’s amazing how powerful these things are in their compact size. I walk around the city and the sounds of the world aren’t present. And if I do so choose to let the ambient sound in, I can choose at which sound levels and still be aware of my surroundings as well as hear what I’m listening to. The app is wonderful and it is easy to control and to check for battery status, ambient sound, noise cancellation, as well as preferences for touch controls. The charging case although bulky has enough charge in them where I rarely charge the case and am able to go a week without charging with my listening habits. Only drawback is them not being water resistant so I won’t use them when I work out. So I haven’t tested how these hold up in the gym and I’m ok with that. Luckily I have some galaxy buds I got for free that can fill that void.
The will not disappoint you
These are the best earbuds I’ve ever used. Love em

These replaced a broken pair of buds from Jaybird, which I've been using various models of for years. These look great, have excellent sound (for bluetooth anyways), and the noise cancelling is fantastic. The phone app is really great, and offers a ton of cool customization options for how you listen. I like the low profile look (I hate the air pod look! ), and these are super comfortable. These aren't rated for moisture, but I've been wearing them to the gym for a few months with no issues so far. Sony made a great effort to give us good ear cushions (they provide multiple sizes and material types), but I opted for the comply tips, which I've been using for years, and feel great.

column8: Exellent! Noise cancelling is not perfect but is good
column9: I Like everything highly recommended. My only concern was the noise cancelling is not as good as i hoped, but is not bad. I really like this what sony this with this product.

The Sony WF-1000XM3 are the best sounding earbuds I have ever used. The fit snug in my ear right out of the box. I noticed quite the difference as I put them on that they truly is blocking all the sound out. I own a couple other wireless earbuds and these has become the #1 choice over the last several weeks. The sound is crisp and clear and I did not experience any hiccup with Bluetooth connectivity. Setup was easy through the app, it didn't take more than a few minutes connect them to my phone. The battery life is great. There has not been one time where I had to stop what I am doing to recharge the earbuds. There are no volume control on the earbuds which can be a bother to adjust from my phone when I am moving around. Hopefully, they would be able to fix this with a software update. Users were able to hear me on phone calls and it didn't sound like I was in a vacuum tunnel. I love the fact that I can finally hear the calls from both earbuds. All my previous earbuds would drop to a single earbud when it came to phone calls. Overall, the Sony WF-1000XM3 are truly wonderful for my everyday entertainment and business needs.

Really disappointing. I had high hopes but almost every aspect of these headphones are mediocre at best. Sound cancelling: F literally fake ambient sound comes out of the speaker when noise cancelling is turned on to trick you that sound cancelling works. Comfort: F- always have to adjust them so they dont fall off, I tried all ear plugs.

Unfortunately, they have to go back.

column8: Great Sound. Great Comfort. Easy to use. Just wish the case was smaller.
column9: Compared to the Google Pixel Buds -- The Google Assistant works very much the same way. Which is a huge compliment. Press and hold while speaking then the search is done immediately on release. Compared to the Sony WH-1000XM3 -- The ambient sound control feels very similar though not quite as impressive when turned all the way up. Good product
Great set of ear buds !! Sound 9/10 charging case 10/10 fitment 8/10

column8: Does not work with any Windows Desktop device
column9: No support for Windows devices, there is a supposed fix but it is super buggy, this should not be the case from Sony. There is also zero documentation on this, besides forum which is pathetic.

column8: Solid earphones that beat out power beats for me
column9: Love the sound / equalizer on these. With the equalizer, I was able to achieve a sound I liked much more than the Powerbeats Pro. Noise canceling worked excellent on 4 hour plane flight and at the gym. Only complaint is they don’t pair as fast or as well as AirPods / Powerbeats.

column8: Best quality sound and industry leading noise cancellation you can find in truly wireless earbuds
column9: Sony is at it again, dominating a particular consumer electronics market and leading the way in quality and innovation. The WF-1000XM3 earbuds take sound quality, range, and industry-leading noise cancellation and put it all in one headset with Google Assistant integrated right in. For me, as an Android users, this is a match made in heaven. I have had the pleasure of owning Sony's latest over-the-ear noice cancelling headphones, and these just take that same wonderful experience and make it more portable, comfortable, and easier. The battery life is exceptional for both the buds and the charging case itself, and the USB C charge port makes charging them back up an even faster experience than competing products. Overall, this is the best sounding truly wireless headset I've used, and I've used nearly all of the major competitors' products. Here's the Pro's: - Either-side, single ear operation - Very good bass - Very good noise cancellation - Google Assistant integration built-in - Comfortable fit and light weight - Outstanding battery life - Premium look and feel for the product, its housing, and its packaging - Reasonable price point Here's the Cons: - Had trouble pairing them the first time, but resetting them and repairing fixed it (but it may have been caused by an update to Android that same day). - Not advertised as water- or sweat-resistant in any capacity. I won't use them for working out. - Inner ear silicone really goes deep into the ear, which (grossly enough) tends to accumulate earwax on the silicone near the speaker hole. It will require diligence to keep wax from getting to the speaker over time. I have already recommended these to fellow coworkers who travel on plane and train often, and will continue to talk well of these buds for a long while to come.
Battery in left unit died within days, and on a long plane flight where i did not have other headphones. Very frustrating for such an expensive product

Great product, fantastic sound and does a good job with adaptive noise cancellation. I will say that these are not for working out. They will definitely fall out, but are great for the office or walking around! Sometimes when I eat and have them on they will fall out though, but if you take small bites should be no problem haha. The touch on the sides also is great for pausing and skipping songs. Highly recommend for everyone as long as its not working out at the gym.

column8: Do yourself a favor to get the Comply SmartCore Sport Pro replacement ear tips too
column9: The stock ear tips are awful; incredibly painful and/or doesn't keep the buds in the ear. Blows my mind that they would skimp on such an inexpensive yet crucial accessory. Love the sound and the noise cancellation, but was considering sending them back till I tried the Comply SmartCore ear tips. They make all the difference in the comfort and provide a better fit and seal. I originally knocked off a star due to the poor quality stock ear tips. But the earbud's performance with the SmartCore tips has been so stellar, I've changed my mind. The sound quality, noise cancellation, battery life, and features of the WF-1000XM3 are incredible.

column8: Better Sound but Poor Bluetooth Connectivity
column9: Decent sound with good sound isolation - both much better than air pods. Those are the only aspects of this product better than air pods. Everything else is worse - especially Bluetooth connectivity. These have much more interference and the connection cuts out more often than air pods. The left and right speakers often go out of sync with one have a slight delay over the other. Pairing and connecting with an iPhone takes far more time. Often times cycling through sound isolation modes by pressing the left earbud doesn’t cycle to he mode. Where these buds totally destroy the air pods is on airplane flights. The sound isolation and noise cancelling really shine here. These are also better at the gym to cut our background noise. I still continue to use my AirPods for voice calls since the microphone is much better.

These earbuds are fantastic as long as you're into sticking them deep into your ear canal. That's how you're supposed to wear all earbuds that have foam/rubber tips, but you can get away with not sticking them in all the way on other models. You can get away with it using these too, but the noise cancellation will be useless if they don't make a good seal. If you do make a good seal by pushing them into your ears as far as they'll go, the noise cancellation is great, and provides much more isolation than the seal on its own. I walked to work along a major road as it passes under an expressway, where I normally have to pause my audiobook because I can't hear it over the traffic noise. With noise cancellation turned on, I didn't even have to turn up the volume to hear the narrator clearly. My biggest gripe is that I wish the case were made of better materials. It feels nice, but it's all plastic, and it got scratched in my pocket on the second day I had them.

These headphones sound decent, but they completely fail in terms of broadcasting voice on calls. I have tried them 5-6 times in locations as noisy as an airport and quiet as my home and every time the person/people on the other end complain about the audio quality. In addition, they intermittently lose connection with my phone in one ear or the other for no apparent reason. I’m a very unhappy customer for an expensive supposedly premium product.
very good product.
The sound quality is ok, but my ear doesn't feel comfortable when I use the ear buds.

column8: Randomly lose connectivity every hour or so.
column9: Sound quality is better than Samsung buds, but the connectivity issue is unacceptable. These are not nearly as polished, user friendly, or intuitive as the Samsung buds. The volume goes a bit higher though and the battery life is better. I can't justify spending more for these when the product was not completely finished. There is a serious problem with connectivity and the Sony earbuds stop working entirely when u take one out. Very frustrating. I LOVE Sony, but they released an unfinished product. I'm very disappointed in them.

I’ve been waiting to review these until I could use them in several situations. I love them! I have never had completely wireless headphones. They really nailed it! I have loved the noise canceling feature. I used them on a plane because the ambient noise of a plane is almost nauseating to me. These cut that noise almost completely. The sound quality is fantastic as well. My favorite feature is the charging case. I can wear these for an hour or 2 for several days before I ever have to charge the case. I would very highly recommend these headphones. They trusty are fantastic.
Excellent quality!! !

This review comes from an audiophile snob. He is ecstatic. The only headphones that ever floored me have been the magnificent and accurate Etymotic ER4p's. Had those in-ears for 15 years. You could hear the resin bouncing off the bows. Now they have a rival. Sony, gotta' hand it to you. These wireless earbuds are exceptional. Classy look, good fit, feel substantial, cool packaging. The noise cancellation is effective and not obvious. After some fiddling, the buds provide excellent addictive sound. Go the the ap store and use the free download, which allows you tune this sound to personal preference and perfection. Sound quality (which is all I care about), is all I could hope for. More, actually. Phone works well, too. Microphone is clean. Calls come through both buds. You'll want to experiment with the many included ear tips to find the best fit. Before trying these, I purchased a pair of the Bose Soundsport buds. No contest. This is the one. Tried the Bose. N o t e v e n c l o s e. . .

First of all, these are some of the best wireless earphones I have ever used in my entire life. Here are all my opinions in a simplified list. Also I will compare these earphones to its competitors, Airpods and Galaxy Buds Pros: - One of the most important things to me is USB C because it is simply the future. Furthermore I have many cell phones and tech that uses USB C. (Galaxy buds have USB C while Airpods have the lighting port) - Battery life Is some of the best and in my opinion both better than airpods and Galaxy buds. - Noise Cancelling is far by the best I have ever used, I can be sitting right next to a fan which is really loud and once I put the noise cancelling one with music, I can't hear anything. Another thing is that I can press the left bud touch pad and it will silence everything out so I can talk to people or listen to convos. - I am absolutely in love with the rose gold color of the case and earbuds themselves. - Consistent, these earphones connect to a special app, that is just for these earphones and it works great. The app knows what your doing, like exercising or sitting down and it will also monitor your surroundings. With all this information it adjusts the earphones in a way for the most optimal sound! This is a great feature which I have never seen on another pair of earphones ever and I'm a truly Impressed by this technology. Also connection is easy, once the initial set up is done, you can just pull out the earphones and put them in your ears and your good to go. They will connect automatically and everything. - Google assistant is available on these earphones, or at least works with them. - Multiple sets of earbuds which will help determine size and likeness. - USB C cable included and packaging is absoulty fantastic for gifting. - I love the lights and NFC Compaitbily is also pretty cool. Negatives: With everything good there are issues and this item is not an exception! - Unlike the airpods and Galaxy buds, these unfortunately do not support wireless charging. - The charging case for these are huge and compared to the samsung galaxy buds and apple airpods very disappointing. I like wearing Jean's and the charging case bulges out of my pocket. - case scratches easily and I've seen some scratches and dents from a couple of drops. Final Thoughts? Well, out of the airpods and Galaxy buds, These are definitely the best in sound quality and noise cancellation I've ever seen!!! So these buds do have their drawbacks but at the end of the day these are fantastic!! Final Decision: If you can live with the issues that these presents with overall portability, I don't think you'll be disappointed at all. Anyway thanks for reading! If this helped you out, please hit the helpful button!! Have a great day !

column8: best ear buds I ever purchased
column9: These Sony earbuds are by far the most reliable and comfortable ones out there... They give you 8 types of ear pads plus the holder case is very convenient, works Great !

column8: Terrific Sound- Flaky Touch Controls-Absolute Cleanest Full Sound Among Peers
column9: Update- 10/17/19- The firmware update made a significant improvement in the touch control issue. I originally ordered from Amazon but after a month of waiting found them on a lark at a local BBstore. I love almost every thing about these, The case is big but so is the battery life. And no volume control on the buds. I hope a future update will have this changed by firmware update. Hopefully not just a new model. The noise Active noise cancelling is great but when ambient sound is on, it opens the soundstage like wearing open headphones. My problem was the "tap" controls". When first turned on I can tap through the settings of Ambient Sound Control to Off to Noice Cancelling and back. after one round of tapping,, the control stoops working until you turn off the buds by placing them in the case or using the app. Anyone with similar experience- is this buggy firmware or a bad pair? The firmware and app update has changed this for the most part though it still skips a tap on occasion. As far as the lack of volume controls, I don't know if Sony just rushed these out the door as they work so well, especially through the app where control is flawless, but the hardware controls on the buds are severely lacking for this kind of money. Sony's have the best sound in "true Wireless" earbuds bar none. Have I tried them all? Most of them above $150. When it came down to just sound, the Sony are most impressive and top all contenders including Sennheiser which I own. The Sennheiser are too boomy in the bass dept for my taste. Don't get me wrong, the Sony have plenty of bass but it's that boom that muddies the mids and highs that are the Achilles heel imho of the Senns. I have both and though the Senns are a hair more comfortable, I can fall asleep and forget these are on. Thanks.

I was really excited to get these but ended up returning them due to the noise cancellation randomly turning off. Battery life while on was about 5 hours. Worked ok on the plane but was not the experience I hoped it would be. Lots of ear adapters make finding the right fit easier then others.

These are really great. The noise cancellation is of course not as great as what you'd get with the over the ear headphones, but that is not their main purpose. I really like how they are light weight and can be used in any situation: running, working out in a gym, working in the office, chilling at home. Do note that they are not water resistant so if you do sweat a lot, you might look for a water resistant pair. As I do not naturally sweat much, I find no problem wearing them during workouts. The phone app is really cool and allows you to tweak equalizer settings and automatic sound cancellation intensity (although I ended up controlling it myself). The touch buttons on each of the headphone pieces can be fully configured for different functions like bringing up google assistant, pausing/resuming music, noise cancellation intensity. The best part is that my ears to do not get tired of wearing the headphones. I can use them all day long without any soreness. I was able to find the pair of ear pieces that works best with my ears. Depending on the structure of your ear, YMMV. Good luck!

column8: Best true wireless on the market
column9: Not made for working out but they are great for any other time. Sound is great. Convenient carrying in pocket with ample battery life. I won’t buy over ear headphones anymore. I returned my Klipsch t 5 and pro beats as both have me connectivity issues. The Connection on these, no issues. I use 1 earbud at a time at work cause I need to listen for my call on Wallis talkie. I used my Amazon credit card points. Definitely worth it.

column8: Constant connection issues with iPhone XS, 11 pro
column9: I’ve been using these earbuds for 6 weeks now and have come to the conclusion that they don’t work very well. I only have them paired with one phone at a time (my iPhone XS and now iPhone 11 pro). One or both of the earbuds fail to connect about half the time when I take them out of the case. When I do eventually get them both connected, one or both will often drop connection or get out of sync between left and right. This is super annoying for a $225 purchase. Noise cancellation works to varying degrees depending on the surroundings, and the volume has to be turned pretty high to work effectively in most reasonably noisy environments. I was hoping they would help me with sleeping on planes or trains, but not really since I don’t like listening to music at high volumes when I’m trying to sleep. They are not overly comfortable. I often get ear fatigue or swelling after wearing them for several hours and I find myself carrying around replacement ear tips and swapping between sizes without ever getting to the point where I can forget that I’m wearing them. Call quality is terrible and people complain whenever I try to talk to them with these ear buds. It’s also insanely annoying with all of the connection dropouts and pairing issues. I wish I hadn’t bought these. Waiting to see if apple releases airpods with noise cancelling. Other headphones I’ve tried for comparison are the wired bose soundsport and the 1more stylish true wireless. For me they were preferable even without the noise cancellation of the wf-1000xm because of how much more comfortable they are and cost less than half the wf-1000xm.
Batteries seem to getting weaker by the week. Connection to iPhone is frustrating, lag time and failed connections. Think I'm going to return them. It is a shame the sound quality is amazing.

column8: Amazing headphones, wonderful sound, bizarre name.
column9: I have resisted buying truly wireless headphones since they started popping up - I've been afraid I'd lose one or that I wouldn't like it or that I was playing into the trend of abandoning headphone jacks. Those fears remain, but it's hard to give them much credence after using these headphones. I do a lot of work in coffee shops, and whenever the noise level gets too high, I can pop these things in and perform a sort of aural disappearing act. I'm amazed at the noise canceling - it really works well, though, of course, it's not perfect - it can't eliminate 100% of surrounding sounds, but it comes closer than I would have thought possible. There a lot of settings for audio quality and even the degree to which you want to cancel noises. There is one weird thing about noise canceling in headphones that I did not anticipate: phone calls are a bizarre experience. I can hear my caller, but can barely hear myself. In a public space, I find this off-putting because I have no idea how loud I'm speaking. Setup could not be simpler. The first time, I barely tried -- it seemed as if when my phone came near the headphones, they just connected. This is because these phones are designed to work with Google Assistant. I tell people that Google Assistant lives in one of the headphone speakers, but obviously that's not true (right?) The second time I had to set it up after wiping my phone was almost as easy -- it just had to connect to bluetooth and the phone and the headset seemed to take care of the rest. Having Google Assistant in an ear is genius. I can just tap it and it will read me my notifications. I have not run out of battery power once (though, admittedly, I only use them in limited bursts). There are two downsides and one oddity to these headphones: 1. It's perhaps a minor point, but what on earth is with the name? I have zero clue what these are called. I'm going to put it here (WF-1000XM3) but that required me to go to the product name and copy and paste it. I don't know what Sony was thinking here. How do you tell someone to go get these if you can't tell them what they're called? 2. The price. Holy moly, that's a spicy meatball. I appreciate it that Sony and Amazon provided these to me to review, but the price of these headphones seems prohibitive. So it's hard for me to really assess the value for the money; having said that, they are, without a doubt, the best headphones I've used. 3. They make random noises that don't make sense. Google Assistant helpfully pipes up with instruction about announcements and the like, and that's great, but every so often there is a chime for which there is zero explanation. I can't find it in the instructions or the manual. After some googling, I found a Reddit discussion where they explained it was the headphones automatically changing the noise canceling strength. Which seems to be about right because when I switch it to manual, the random gonging stops. I wish this were clearer, perhaps on the app? I love these things so much. If you can spare the cost, you should definitely get them.
If you want your ears to ring like your doorbell. Ears ringing 24/7 this is the product for you

column8: Great earbuds as long as I don’t walk. Fall out all the time.
column9: Having trouble keeping them in my ear. They work okay if I just sit, but if I try to walk around they will fall out. Sounds great and noise cancellation works good.

These earbuds are extremely impressive. On a recent flight I was struck by how useful noise cancellation would be, so I purchased these. They’re great! Pros: - great sound quality - a variety of tips to ensure a great fit - noise cancellation is very impressive for earbuds - great battery life Cons: - while on calls, I am often told the other party has a difficult time hearing me - no water resistance, so I’m reluctant to use them while working out - charging case is huge All in all, unless you’re expecting to use them for phone calls, I have no problems recommending them. If you’re expecting great sound quality for calls, though, I’d look elsewhere.

column8: Really good. Worth buying. Fantastic control.
column9: Really good. Worth buying. Fantastic control.
The sound quality is amazing, the noise cancellation is excellent n the battery life is very very good. I was trying to acquire all these quality from the one I had before. Thanks to Sony
For in-ear these cancel noise pretty well. Definitely happy so far

column8: Great sound, good noise cancelling, bad quality control
column9: The sound quality is great and the noise cancelling is pretty good but I’ve had 2 pairs fail already. The first pair failed after a week and got replaced by Amazon. The second pair failed after 2 months

column8: Excellent Sound quality, OK fit/size, Extremely poor mic quality. Sadly won't keep :(
column9: I've recently started moving away from corded earphones and started experimenting with truly wireless ones since the technology over the last year has improved so much. So i was excited to receive the Sony WF-1000XM3 but will ultimately be returning them. Pro's: - The sound quality is excellent. **Like really really good** I would put these in the category with some of the best IEM's i own. Large soundstage, warm sounding that brings out a lot of detail in the music i've been listening to. - The noise cancelling works well and the adaptive mode is good in adapting to your environment (it knows when you are walking outside and adjusts the sound to make sure you can hear traffic etc.) - Quality of build. The case feels like it could take a lot of punches and i wouldn't feel worried about it being knocked around a lot. The earbuds themselves don't feel cheap and seem to use premium materials. Con's: - Mic quality: I don't understand why Sony would release a pair of earbuds where the mic quality is so so terrible. Out in the wind and on a call? Don't expect the other side to hear you. In a quiet room? it will sound like you are talking on a speaker placed about 10ft away from you. 1/10 - Connection: I've not had issues with the connection whilst listening to music but transitioning to a call meant the earbuds started doing some funky stuff. For example, i'm connected to someone on facetime audio on an iphone and it sounds likes the right and left earbud is throwing the sound back and forth to each other. Much cracking, much distortion means i had to disconnect them all together. The charging case: It's huge. Like humongously big. Another bulge in my pocket. If you use these on a commute and plan to keep the case in your pocket, be ready to be annoyed.
Wonderful sound, fit, and look. I’m really pleased, and happy to no longer have to use the “can” over-ear headphones on flights. This is a game changer.
Sound is balanced and detailed, similar to AirPods. No booming bass.
I was a bit apprehensive to buy these, boy am I glad I did! The only thing I can figure is there are just a lot of Sony haters out there. I love Sony products and these do not disappoint

These have been awesome in all their way but size wise I have small ears and I get tired of having them inside my ear canal if I wear them for too long. But any other aspect they're just fenomenal I give them a solid 9.8/10

column8: Easy to use easy to set up.
column9: Best earbuds ever Way to go Sony.
With so many cheaper alternatives, these are not worth hundreds more for a tiny amount of extra features and a slightly better sound.

I compared Sony WF-1000XM3 (certainly an instantly endearing product name) with Apple AirPods, Bose SoundSport Free, Jabra Elite Sport, and Monster Powerbeats Pro and here's the comparison: Technical: Except Sony and Monster, all others are running older bluetooth version and no good for watching videos as there'll be an inherent lag. Both Sony (with their own chip) and Monster (apple's H1 chip from new AirPods) work wonderfully well. Sound stage: A very subjective attribute to test. Sony felt open and bright and yet with a near flat frequency response - excellent, really. In comparison, Powerbeats Pro felt a little bass-heavy but still absolutely a joy to listen. Bose SoundSport Free seems a little "closed" in comparison, but a very fun experience. Jabra Elite Sport was very similar to Sony overall which was definitely surprising. Functions: Apple and Sony are the only two with touch controls without volume control so they're definitely going to appeal to those who hate buttons. PowerBeats Pro has easy press buttons with also come with volume control and thus come in as the close second. Bose and Jabra have terrible controls so they fall in the last place. Jabra and Bose also do not support single-ear listening function. Apple, Sony, and PowerBeats Pro do. Call quality: PowerBeats and Jabra beat others in call quality. Apple, Bose, and Sony are similar to each other so they come in as a close second place. Overall, Sony's latest take on wireless earbuds in 2019 will infuse awe-inspiring audio details into untrained ears making them fall in love with new genres they used to shy away from. These earbuds will bring the audiophiles an inch closer to stop denying the lack of quality if no wires are in the picture. Sony deserves to take a bow, maybe even do a little dance because these buds won't fall out!

Was so waiting for this and so disappointed with them. 1. Great Design and polished case 2. Ease of installation 3. Sound quality is terrible even after adjusting all controls in the app 4. The Bose earbuds have better quality 5. Fit well but they look like Pinto Beans 6. Returning soon unfortunately...

I've tried these on my wifes iPhone and on my Samsung S10 and both times the person I'm speaking with said I was breaking up and I kept hearing a crackling sound too. Would not recommend if you plan to use it for voice. This is as of 2/1/2020 using the most recent firmware. There has been about 3 updates since I bought them.

I really wanted to like these but it didn't work out for me. Firstly let me say that the sound quality on music with these is excellent and I also felt that the noise cancelling was the best I have heard for in ear type buds. However I had nothing but trouble with phone calls. I have a brand new iPhone 11 Pro Max currently running iOS 13.1.2 and although there was no problem with these using them for music, connections with phone calls were distorted and often dropped or I could not hear the caller or they couldn't hear me. I spent over an hour on the phone with Sony tech support and even they said I sounded distorted. Sony admits right in the iOS app that they have issues with iOS 13 (see pic). Except for being unusable with phone calls I loved these ear buds so maybe I'll try again after they get this issue fixed but for now if you're running iOS 13 I'd stay away.

I bought these after using airpods for a while, I can honestly say they are better but I bought some headphones called mpow flame2 and those are only like 25 bucks and the sound quality is very close to these, save yourself the $200 and get those, only problem is the wire connecting them but is definitely worth it being so cheap and sounding so good, also did not stay in my ear well at all

I bought my first pair a week ago and they were great for about a couple of hours. I started getting a hissing, windy noise in the left ear piece when I turned on the noise cancellation. I had to go back to ambient to get the noise to stop. At first, the noise wasn't loud but after a few minutes it began to really interfere with the music. I found a number of others had the same issues so I sent them back as there was really no permanent fix. The second pair arrived and were dead on arrival. For the couple of hours that they worked, these were exceptional and its a real shame both pairs were broken.

column8: The best noise-canceling earbuds on the market!
column9: I've had the WF-1000XM3 for more than a week and used it every day on my commute. My commute is usually 3 hours each day on both bus and light rail, so noise-canceling is important to me. My need for noise-canceling started with a new job that requires me to commute to the downtown area of a large city. To pass the time away, I started to listen to podcasts and stream sports radio on my commute. After a few days, I noticed that the volume was at maximum for me to hear through the wired earbuds that came with my mobile phone. That is a concern because I don't normally have the volume at maximum and I would like to keep my ears safe from any damage. To that extent, I looked for noise-canceling headphones that were not the kind that you put over your head - they are too bulky and messes with your hair. I settled for a leading brand that was considered at the time the best available. I used that every day for 4 years and despite the wires attached to the mobile phone, I was happy because with the noise-canceling turned on, the volume was set to about 50% and I can hear clearly. The wired aspect of it was tolerated because of the noise-canceling. Forward 4 years and my trusty headphone is now on its last legs. Technology has moved on and there are now a multitude of Bluetooth enabled earbuds available but few are noise -canceling and none that could compete against good old trusty. Until I discover this one. Wow. This is exactly what I'm looking for for my commute. Noise-canceling on par (if not better - the volume setting is at 40% instead of 50% so I hope that's going to help with keeping my ears safe) than my old headphone and wireless. No more wires to mess around with and to get in the way. Love the Sony as the replacement! From my use case, I don't listen to music but the Sony's performance on the music front far exceeds the previous headphone. Using the Sony for phone calls seem to be on par - which is to say it is just okay. Let's just say that people noticed that I was using a headset and kind of tinny and mechanical. This is as opposed to the headphone I own that is made by a certain fruit company - when used for a phone call, it was clear and sounded natural. However, the fruit company's headphones are not noise-canceling and certainly not even close to Sony in acoustic performance. I am very happy about my purchase and the Sony headphone will be my "daily driver" going forward.

column8: Mixed bag. Great noise cancelling but lots of usability issues.
column9: Initially these were great. And to be honest the noise cancelling blew me away, as did the ambient sound control. Problems: Tons of drop outs —got worse after last software update When it is windy outside both noise cancelling and ambient sound modes have a lot of wind-on-mic noise. Maybe a future software update can help here. Microphone for calls picks up too much ambient sound and really distracts the person you’re trying to call with. I’ve had much better headsets than this including a cheap aftermarket unit that filters ambient sound just fine for calls in my convertible at 60 mph with top down , so this seems pretty behind the times. The longer I have it there worse the connectivity issues seem to be. Sometimes I have to disconnect my earbuds from the phone and reconnect to get drop outs to stop. Same for an issue where left and right earbuds are slightly out of sync with each other (different latency) which is really weird sounding. I liked these at first but they somehow manage to get more unusable with time. Maybe the last software update is to blame and this can get better?

I bought these for my wife. She used them on a long bus ride and loves them. She says the NC was excellent for both blocking noisy passengers and engine noise. I listened to them and the sound quality is very good. The bass is tighter than my WH-1000xM3 headphones.

Terrible call quality (background noise) audio quality on calls is terrible. People I speak with on the phone report that the microphone is dampening my voice, making it sound echo-ey, whilst at the same time picking up ambient noise. Indeed, most report that the ambient noise is clearer than my voice! I'm not tryign to make calls in a particularly noisy environment - just a regular office.

They are very difficult to use. They frequently drop connection or do not connect. Because you have to reposition them in your ears periodically, it’s easy to accidental activate a change in settings by just touching them while in your ear. This becomes annoying fast.

I really wanted to like these, but Sony missed the mark on these. I got these through Best Buy but ultimately returned them after a month of trying them out. The fit of these are kinda garbage. Not all ears are the same and if you're paying a premium for earphones, this should be taken into account. None of the silicone tips worked well so I had to buy comply tips which helped. The noise cancellation is pretty decent for earbuds, with the comply foam tips, the seal was tighter allowing for maximum noise cancellation. It does get most of noise out, but if you're expecting it to be on-par with over-the-ear noise cancellation like the WH-1000XM3, QC35ii, NC700, then you're gonna be disappointed. The sound quality is pretty decent with these, similar to the WH-1000XM3s in that regard, YMMV since this area is really more subjective to the user. The call quality...complete trash. This is also similar to the WH-1000XM3, maybe worse. It's very muffled, the microphones do not do a good job of picking up noise, I had to yell to get the other person to hear me. The battery life is pretty good! The magnetic case is their answer to the Airpod case and looks decent. With the comply foam tips, they will still fit in the case. It is also USB-C charging which is always a plus. I do not really understand who this is targeted for. The ads make it seem as if it is more "business oriented"...yet the call quality is horrible, which is important for business folks. For working out, they are not sweat resistant, and there are better options on the market for true wireless earbuds for working out. Sony made a very niche product but then missed the mark drastically on the areas that are important to that specific market.

I have owned several different Sony bluetooth headsets, and I generally like the sound quality of their products. These earbuds are no exception. The sound quality when listening to music is great and unlike any other earbuds I have used in the past. I have never been a fan of Apple earbuds because they just fall out of my ears after a short time, and these Sony buds stay in the whole time I wear them. The greatest fault with these earbuds is the call quality. These earbuds constantly drop calls, and I constant receive complains of sound quality from the person on the other line. It is very disappointing as these earbuds are very expensive. Needless to say, I just can't live with earbuds that are only good for music and I am returning them after this review.

I bought these to replace Bose QC35 II over-the-ear headphones for travel as they are more compact. The noise cancelling works well and they sound good but they have some major issues. They will shut off essentially whenever they want. The app for them has an option to disable auto shutoff which is good. Unfortunately it doesn't do anything and if I pause my music to talk to someone IRL for a few minutes, one or both of them will turn off. Connection quality varies wildly and will have distortion/interference occasionally, especially during phone calls. Shutting them off with the app sometimes causes one to go into a perpetual loop of announcing "powering down" or something over and over. It did this for minutes before I put them both back into the case to 'reset' them. That seems to be the solution to most problems actually, put them back in their case for a moment and try again. Hopefully an update will work these issues out soon, but for now they are disappointing.

column8: Hard to use app, bad connection to iPhone. Poor fit for me.
column9: I owned these for about three days before returning them. They did not fit in my ears well and all sizes of ear plug were uncomfortable. The headphones did not maintain a consistent connection with the app, and I kept accidentally turning them off and on while trying to adjust the position in the ear. These headphones sounded ok to me but not amazing.

column8: I had high expectation, but it did not meet my expectation.
column9: I had high expectation, but it did not meet my expectation. 2 major problems: (1) Battery runs out very quickly in 4-5 hours in stand-by (unless you put it in the charging box) (2) keep falling out, I changed various tips. I think the Bose tips fit much better. I have to return it.

column8: Excellent sound quality and battery life
column9: I've tried quite a few wireless buds, but the Sony buds beat the sound quality, and noise cancellation, hands down. These are small and fit easily in my ears, and still has great battery life. Easy to connect. Once connected, they pair very easily everytime the buds are taken out of the box. Sound quality is amazing - treble, bass everything is so well balanced. And now my favorite feature- google assistant. Its awesome that these buds have google assistant built in and its just a tap away, it works every single time. Finally the adaptive sound control lets me change the noise cancellation level based on the situation. So far loving these buds. Only con I have noticed is, the Bluetooth range os these buds are not as advertised. I am not sure if it's my home that has interference or the buds itself. But for normal use it's not a big deal.

So I will leave my original review below, but after having these for about a month I need to change it. The headphones just stopped charging for me. I would plug them in all day and when I got out of work and tried to use them the battery would be at 20% and immediately give me the low battery warning. I tried the reset trick they have on their support page and no luck. The headphones sound quality and comfort is great but it doesn't help me if they won't charge. *********** Original Review: I gotta say I love these headphones so far. The noise cancelling isn't much but in a crowded office building it makes all the difference when your'e trying to focus on a project. The sound quality is the best I've heard from true wireless so far and they have a few features that make these a great pick, such as automatically pausing if you remove them from your ears. Overall I'm a huge fan.

column8: Earpads tore the first week. No support from Sony.
column9: These earbuds are pretty nice. They are only useful if they fit in your ear properly however. Choosing the correct size of ear pad is absolutely imperative. When the earpad that fit my ear tore the first week it rendered these earbuds worthless to me. I contacted sony yet they refused to send a replacement (these likely cost Sony $1-2). Its unclear to me where to even find these replacement pads, so the earbuds are worthless after only 1 week. And Sony has lost a future customer over a $1-2 cheap part.

column8: Single device, does not support Zoom conferencing
column9: When connected to more than one device in the same area (i.e. phone and laptop), they have issues with not playing any sound at all. They don't seem to work at all with Zoom video conferencing. Sound is otherwise good, and noise cancelling works well.

column8: Bluetooth Cutting in and out during calls ANNOYING
column9: 3 stars only, jumped to this before it was released, when it works it works well however the Bluetooth switches in and out during calls while the phone is in my hand. Noise canceling is excellent and the sound is awesome but the Bluetooth dropping is VERY annoying enough for me to stop using it. Too late to send back.
Great noise-cancelling! Slightly bulky and protrudes out of the ear to a small degree.
Everything
Started out kind of shaky - dropped bluetooth and just shut off. Most recent software update seems to have cured it.

column8: Not ready for prime time. Too many issues right now with stability of software/firmware.
column9: UPDATE as of 10/28/19 I have decided to return these since I am nearing the return window and Sony has not addressed any of the issues I outlined in my review. I also started experiencing a new issue where the left and right buds would be slightly out of sync. The audio on one side "echos" the other side and it will do this until I turn them off and on again. ***Original review below*** I've been waiting to pick these up for a while now. They've been sold out everywhere and finally I picked them up from Amazon. However I have been very disappointed so far in my experience. 1. Mobile app - Needs some work. About 1 in 4 times the app can't connect to the earphones. They are paired, connected, and playing audio through the phone but the app says the earphones are not found. Since you need the app to configure things like ambient sound and touch controls, it needs to be more reliable. 2. Connection drop/ear bud "Crashing" - At least once a day I've experienced one of the buds stop playing audio and get stuck playing a buzzing sound. It gets stuck in this state until I put it in the case and reconnect to the phone. 3. Connection speed - the buds take a long time to reconnect when removing from the case. Most of my other buds connect instantly or within 5 seconds. I've experienced close to 30 seconds with these sony ear buds, sometimes they connect in under 5 seconds but its not consistent. 4. Call quality - I've never been able to conduct a phone call with these. Every time I use them the other person complains about the audio and I have to switch to handset mode. 5. Phone audio handling - about 50% of the time I can't answer or place a call with these ear buds as the audio device. When I try to switch to them for a call they disconnect and I have to continue that using the handset. If I ever do get a successful connection see #4 above. I have tried these with an iPhone 11 and a Google Pixel 2. Both have all of these issues so I am looking at the earbuds as the common denominator. I read on multiple forums that Sony released firmware 1.3.0 recently but pulled it due to some of these issues. However, my pair came with 1.3.0 already installed so I didn't have the option to opt out of this flawed firmware version. I hope that an update is released soon or I will be returning these.

column8: Amazing sound for such a little package
column9: I use these all the time from traveling to mowing the lawn. They have exceptional sound for every type of music I've listened to. I like to travel light and these are a perfect solution vs the larger over the ear types. They don't cancel the noise quite as well but I have no issues watching a movie or listening to music on planes. My only complaint is the Sony software is kind of garbage. They recently made a few improvements but there's a lot more they need to fix.
Great

I was eager to try these Sony earbuds as using my old wired headphones while traveling is inconvenient. On first impression, the magnetic battery case and multiple sized ear buds were impressive. It's a very easy set up - you download the Sony app, make sure the Bluetooth on your phone is activated and then you connect. Comfort: I find the earbuds to be very comfortable . Everyone can find their right fit with the multiple sized soft earbuds that the product comes with. Although they look a little bulky at first, once you put them in, you hardly know they are there. Noise Cancelling: this is the main reason I was so eager to try these earbuds. Sony usually has very good noise cancelling features on their headphones. I found this function to be quite good on these earbuds. It effectively tuned out the sound of the subway on my commute to/from work. I really like the fact that I can adjust the amount of noise cancellation depending on my situation - truly customizable and a great feature. Battery life: I seem to have a bit of problem with my left earbud as the battery seems to drain faster than my right earbud (will have to test some more). I've used the earbuds to listen to music during my commute to and from work in NYC and have used them for a few days, charging only with the battery case. I noticed that the app doesn't indicate how much of a percentage battery is left on each ear bud. On my first day using these, I had the battery indicator on my left earbud go from 100% to 0% and then shut off. I had to look up instructions on how to reset it and then it was fine. Touch controls: I was not that thrilled with the placement of the touch sensors as I would accidentally touch the sensors when adjusting my earbuds. I think single tap/touch on the sensors should be eliminated to prevent accidental touches. It should require minimum of 2 taps or a swipe to activate. One major improvement I think they can potentially make is adding volume control to the earbuds. When I'm on a call at home, I may not necessarily have my phone/computer near me. I walk around the apartment with the earbuds on and sometimes I need to adjust the volume and always need to go back to find my device to adjust. Sound: the other parties on my phone calls sounded crisp and clear. My music sounds great with these earbuds as well and with the customization on the app, you can control the equalizer and save 2 custom profiles. Final thoughts: Well done Sony.
I love it, the best nothing to compare with the competitors, other word, if Sony make better app they become the best

column8: Best earbuds on the market, with a couple of tweaks
column9: I am convinced that these are the best earbuds that are on the market right now, with a couple of modifications.
