column8: Tried to love these, but the negatives outshown their entire purpose
column9: I recently purchased these earbuds with high expectations regarding all of the hype around them: Great User experience with Sony connect software (Including programmable functions for touch buttons) Excellent Sound Quality Amazing Battery Best Noise Cancelling for current gen TWS Ear Buds Little bit of background on myself and my set up: Daily driving device: Samsung Galaxy Note 8 Wireless earbud daily driver before Sony WF-1000MX3: AKG N200 I daily drive my AKG 200's, to the point where they're always around my neck, the musical styles that I listen to Range vastly from EDM, Ska, Punk, Rock, Metal, Hiphop, LoFi Hiphop, Classical, and plenty of others just to name a few. I like to fidle with my audio equipment to the point where I feel I can get the best sound, on my Note 8 I use Adaptive sound profiles that involve sitting in a quiet area and listening to the different frequency tones to amplify the sound. I use an individual Adaptive sound profile for every set or earphones that use and if I wish to change earphones, I go through and change the profile to its corresponding set. I also use the following Sound effect: Tube Amp Pro (I enjoy the simulated soft timbre of a tube amplify opposed to the standard sound provided from the content being played, it helps the lower tones sounds have a bit more "oomph" The AKG N200's are a really tough act to follow as they're referred to as "Reference" earphones, and essentially what that means is that they don't have any manufacturer provided Equalization or Sound profile applied to them. They're meant to have a flat sound curve that attempts to represent the content in it's truest form and are seen as excellent assets for the use of Mixing sound. The main weak points I'm left wanting is a stronger presence in it's base for when I listen to EDM, but the sound stage is marvelous, clarity is amazing (Clearly defined highs, Mids, and Lows, without having the lows distort the highs). The bluetooth connection could also be better, but unfortunately it's a product of their time being limited to Bluetooth 4.1 rather than the current standard of Bluetooth 5.0. They're also a set of wired bluetooth earbuds opposed to TWS, with a standard 3 button remote (Volume Up, Action Button, Volume Down) WF-1000MX3-------- Initial impressions: Opening the box, the presentation was great, Earphones were separated from the charging case with a wide array of ear tips to make sure you get the proper seal for the best possible quality of sound. User Experience through Sony Connect: Pairing with my phone did take a couple of attempts, I downloaded the Sony connect software and attempted to use the NFC pairing (just for use of it's novelty, but it failed to pair) Went with the standard bluetooth pairing method and the Sony Connect software immediately recognized the TWS Airbuds, +1 point for ease of use. Sony connect software seemed pretty function filled, and thankfully as soon Sony connect interfaced with the Earbuds and saw that there was an active internet connect, it prompted for a firmware update, which adds further usability to be able to change the functionality of the touch buttons (it adds the software update to allow volume control - ABSOLUTELY NEEDED Function). With the software, you get your basic controls, and get to view the individual power of each earbud along with the last recorded power level of the charging case that updates when the earbuds connect to your device. The power levels do jump around in vague percentages (i.e. 100% -> 70% ->50% -> needs to be charged) so at least it provided some update, but not the most accurate.) Here you also get the ability to control your noise cancelling and cycle through the following settings (Noise Cancelling -> Ambient ->Ambient Control -> Noise Cancelling again) And you also get to change the options of allowing the headset to guestimate your current activity and turn on what would be the programs best option for your current activity (If it detects that you're walking it will turn on Ambient to provide spacial awareness of your surrounds, if you're sitting it'll turn on Noise Cancelling, etc.) Personally, I prefer my hardware doing what I want it to do when I want it, so I turned this option off. You also get a pretty cool equalizer option with some useful presets, my preset mainly resided within the "Excited" option, Speech (Listening to podcasts, youtube presentations, Audible, etc.) or custom, which was simply the "Excited" with the Bass option turned all the way up. A fun integration of the application where it provides playback control of whatever media you're currently using, and a Volume control. Interesting Note*** I found in trying to keep the maximum sound output for the earbuds, that I turned off "Absolute Voulme" for my phone, and this volume slider provided the earbuds their individual volume, and then the phone volume became the Master Volume. I did this to not have to deal with HUGE upsteps in volume control when the device synchronized the earbud volume with the master device volume. Next option was choosing your priority for connection, if you want to prioritize the best sound quality vs. a stable connection. There are several other options available the main option of note is the ability to change the functionality of both the Left touch button and the right touch button. This was great, but disappointing at the same time. It gives the options to cycle through controlling the following: Ambient sound control, Playback controls, Volume Controls, Google Assistant, None Assigned) So if you want to operate within those parameters, it's great! One set of functions per parameters set, and your off... It's disappointing if you wish to create your own custom commands for the different control types (I.e. Single Press, Double Press, Triple Press, Long Press) It felt like a lost opportunity for consumers who want to pack more usability into their controls... maybe some day it may be updated through firmware updates, who knows! Sound Quality: I found the sound to be rather lack luster regarding the quality of sound, at least regarding all of the high level of praise that has been given to these TWS earbuds. I went through, created the individual adaptive sound profile for the hardware, enabled the same advanced option for the Tube Amp Pro and listened to the flat equalizer settings for the device. As expected the through put of sound was very flat. There is a definite increase in the vibrancy depending on the equalizer preset that you choose using the Sony connect software, Excited mode had come high recommended and I immediately found myself going for the option, and the difference is pretty great! Found that flat lows are now producing a sensation of actual base feeling inside of my ears (that resonating you feel inside of your ears which those wonderful notes) but I did notice that unfortunately, the highs were muddled. I have my standard songs that I go through dedicated for sound testing, the ones where I know the minute details that I know to keep an eye out for because I've listened to them for so long... and unfortunately, the highs got muddled a bit. There isn't the distinction of which instruments are playing which notes with clarity. It was a definite let down, but I figured that at least I could enjoy the bass... until I decided to go back and forth between my AKG N200's... and the difference was clear as day. With the distinction of vibrant, sparkly highs, and greatly resonating and punchy base, I noticed in multiple of my absolute favorite songs that I can listen to endlessly while listening to my N200's simply flattened out and became run of the mill and lack luster when listening to the WF-1000XM3's. Again, this doesn't mean that that sound is by any means bad... but it most definitely isn't a reason to upgrade my current daily earphones, especially with a high price tag of $200+ when my daily's MSRP'ed at $149.99 (which for myself I waited for a sale and picked them up for about $80 + Tax) Battery LIfe: The battery life was great, just as advertised! For me, I had the earphones in practically the entire time, when I wanted to isolate and focus on the content, I threw on Active Noise Cancelling and enjoyed the sound for what it is, continuing to tinker around and trying to optimize. One of the positives for sure was using the ambient settings, allowing me to keep the earbuds in, but essentially using them as hearing aids, and being able to respond to conversation or contact in the different locations I was enjoying my earbuds (Work, Home, Traveling, talking a walk, etc.) Using the AKG N200's, I have become accustomed to having 1 ear bud in and keeping the opposite ear open for spacial and environmental awareness. That was a great feature that I did enjoy, but since Ambient mode uses the exterior microphones to pick up your surround sounds and plays the sounds through the driver, it is consuming battery. But with the quick charging feature, 10 minutes of charge provides over an hour of usage, so the feature is DEFINITELY appreciated! Adding the extra charge of 18 hours from the charging case definitely makes these TWS ear buds a stand out if you happen to know that you wont be around an AC port for more than a couple of days! One complaint that I do have regarding the charging case is that it is pretty large. It uses up a considerable amount of pocket space if you don't have any kind of bag on you while traveling or doing the day to day tasks. The stand alone battery time is great! But in terms of being a definite reason to upgrade from my current daily set... Not really. My AKG N200's have a battery run time of 8 hours after years of usage handles all of my daily requirements until its about time to call it a night, which I've become accustomed to charging them nightly. Noise Cancelling: For the size of the earbuds, I feel they definitely did an incredibly commendable job with Active Noise Cancelling in these little guys. Did it block everything out? By no means, but for having the portability of TWS earbuds it's great I'm not sure if it was placebo effect from knowing that the noise cancelling was on, but it felt like there was a definite increase in the quality of the music and sound playing while ANC (active noise cancelling) was turned on. One note*** when the earbuds turn on, the default to being in ANC mode instead of ambient or turned off. Under the ambient section of Sony connect software, you can change your level of pass through sound between 0 (ANC on) to 20 (All sound coming through) BUT there is a very useful little option that is right next to 0, and that is used to reduce wind noise... WIthout a doubt the most useful section of these controls regarding Ambient sound! Unfortunately, this is also the biggest reason for the single star review of these TWS earbuds. When playing media content, the ANC, and Ambient controls work like a charm, they're even fun to go through, but while making or receiving a Call... The earphones default to "AMBIENT" with the pass through being dialed up to 20. I thought that the ambient control could be controlled through the Sony Connect software, but it completely failed to make a change. This was a definite breaking point for me, because the entire selling point of these ear buds are to... ACTIVELY NOISE CANCEL, and they refuse to Cancel any noise while trying to make a call. Especially at a price Point of $229.99 MSRP, this kind of oversight is unacceptable. And it would be one thing if Sony had no clue this is an issue, but there are literally hundreds of people that have complained directly to Sony regarding this issue and it has gone for months without fixing. I went through every single possible fix that I could find to attempt to resolve the issue, factory resetting the Earbuds, messing with every single option, and to zero answer from Sony, there is no sure fired resolution. Sony packed a ton of tech into these impossibly small devices, but being unable to make sure that one of the primary functions of these in regards to being connected to a Cell Phone device becomes unusable, To make phone calls, is a bit of a critical miss that pushed me to forego this tech. Especially versus my tried and true current hardware. Hope you guys find this review useful!

column8: The bluetooth connection is absolutely terrible
column9: If the headphones had a stable connection, I would choose them every time. However, the connection is so bad it completely negates the benefits. I have tried every setting on the app, updates multiple times, still spotty at best. Sony made an exchange and I'm waiting on the return, but I should say that I have two pairs of these headphones. Both are really bad connection wise. The second pair is not as bad, but not good enough for me to feel good about spending $200+ on them. They are fine with one side in, but the second both sides are in it's pointless.

I can agree that this does have superior sound quality than airpods pro. And its ANC works great with the customizable ear tips. Though, If you'd ask me the gap between the sony's wf-1000mx3 and airpods pro in terms of sound quality, the gap isn't that big. In terms of compatibility, on the box it emphasizes it's made for iphone, but the more I used it, the more It felt like it's made for androids. The connection is not as smooth as I thought it would be. And it doesn't update its battery status often that leads to surprising the user with low battery notice. Also, I'm not sure what drained its battery life so fast, but it only lasted 3 hours of usage with the ANC on from 100% battery. Fit , it's not stable. It doesn't make you feel that it is correctly worn. It just feels like it'll just pop out any moment. I did some simple test, and found that it stayed in my ears pretty OK. However, there were some signs that it gets loosened from time to time. *update: they fall off whenever I look down and pick something from the ground. Mobility, if you usually wear jackets, these won't bother you at all, but I can't imagine carrying these while wearing light clothes. Touching interface is simple to adjust things always, but while having unstable fit, it makes its fit more insecure. Conclusion: For wireless earphones, I value convenience & feature over others, but if you can overcome these issues that I've found, then it's worth consider getting these.

column8: It arrived used, with scuffs on the case, and the box it came in didn't have a lid either.
column9: It arrived used, with scuffs on the case, and the box it came in didn't have a lid either. When I pay for a new product, it's a pretty cheap blow to send someone a referb/used item...
It doesn't fit my ear.

column8: Terrible call quality and bluetooth connection. Do not use for audio calls period.
column9: Battery life seems to be the best on the market, but I never used the earbuds long enough to really test it out. Sound quality for standard audio (playing music) is on par with a decent pair of headphones. As many other reviews are saying the call quality is horrendous. It is actually bad in multiple ways. First, the Sony Connect app turns up the gain and drowns out your voice. The Sony software engineers behind this app made the absolute worst decisions possible, completely ruining the sound quality without sufficient options to fix it. The profile that the app makes you use makes you seem like you are at the bottom of a well while amplifying all the noise around you. People I spoke with thought cars were crashing due to the noise from my dryer over 50 ft away, yet could not understand what I was saying. If you do try these out, do yourself a favor and do not install the Sony Connect app; just pair with your device normally through Bluetooth. Call sound quality improved from worst imaginable to standard without the Sony Connect app. The problem on top of this is that the Bluetooth connection is very shoddy and drops in and out. Despite having a new iphone sitting less than 3ft away from fully charged earbuds, the connection was choppy and my voice reportedly repeatedly dropped out on the listener's end. Swapping over to a wired set of earbuds (and to PXC 550's over bluetooth) fixed this issue. Things sounded okay on my end, but every caller I dealt with complained about the audio quality and forced me to switch (they strongly preferred speaker mode on my phone; thats how bad it was). Personally the ear buds were pretty uncomfortable in my ear, but your mileage will vary here. Bottom line, these are really not worth bothering with, even if they were half of the cost. I know that many Youtube reviewers claim these things are the best on the market, but they must have not tested the voice calls over Bluetooth enough and focused more on specs and music playback quality. If you are looking for something to handle calls with, you will be disappointed no matter how low you set the bar. Try literally anything else.
Product is great just not a good fit after awhile my ears would start too hurt

Just got my ear pods the other day and have used them twice in the gym, as for the reason why I got them, very happy that these come with 6 different size ear rubbers to get a good fit for your ear, after getting the right sizes for me the fit was great, was able to do decline bench at the gym with no issues of them falling out or coming loose, so far so good, sound quality is great and so far the noise cancelling in the gym works great on keeping out all the random noises , these are my first ear pods I've had and so far I'm not disappointed.

column8: Best NC headphones in the market
column9: Best noise cancellation earphones in the market hands down. Doesn't pair that easily than Airpods in iOS but the sound quality more makes up for it.

column8: Great sound... when they stay in your ears!
column9: My wife gave me these for Christmas. The sound quality is great, battery life is pretty good but they simply don’t stay in my ears. I think I gave them a fair shot but I’m still not satisfied. I’ve tried every size ear bud and nothing works. During workouts, they constantly feel like they’re falling out and I have to push them back every few minutes. column9: Superb Sound, great battery life, noise cancellation is great too. The best part is the software updates from sony. It is miles better now thanks to those updates. Very satisfied with the Sony's (coming from (sennheiser momentum). Recommend !

column8: Love it! Great sound! A little quirky/unstable at first tho, I need for them to settle down.
column9: Love it! Light weight, great sound! BUT... that review was a little haste. column8: If you want quality, these are the earbuds for you
column9: I’ve been looking for a great pair of wireless earbuds and, after much searching, I’ve finally found them. First of all, the presentation is excellent. From the first impression of the Beautiful case and then the earbuds themselves, there’s no doubt about the quality. The sound quality is Also wonderful....I’m not lacking the strong bass that I love. Once you find the correct size ear tips—-it’s a must to pick the right ones to truly get a tight seal—-you’ll be good to go. You have to sort of insert and twist them to get the seal but it’s simple and makes all the difference. Another unexpected bonus is that they are extremely comfortable for wearing for long periods of time. The only downside is the price point over $200 that almost kept me from buying them. I think a $199 price point would be more in keeping with some of the other strong contenders out there these days. That said, I have no regrets and am extremely satisfied.
Actually I thought they would work for environmental sound, as in hearing aids. But they were not good at this. And they keep picking up the music from my phone, no matter what I selected them to do.

column8: Sound quality is excellent, but call quality is terrible
column9: Sound quality is excellent. The only problem with this earbud is that the microphone picks up everything that's around you. I'm always asked to mute when I'm on a conference call.

column8: Inconsistant Noise Cancelling and Ambient Noise
column9: Paired with Galaxy S10+ I got these to replace my Galaxy Buds. After reading reviews and having this on my wish list, I finally pulled the trigger and bought these. I was not impressed. These earbuds were a downgrade from the Galaxy Buds that I was using. Sound Quality The sounds was crisp for the highs but really felt empty towards the lows. When compared to how the range felt with the Galaxy Buds, I felt there was a huge gap. Tweaking the EQ in the Sony Headphones app barely made any improvements. My impression is that this was possibly due to the form factor of the earbuds. The Galaxy Buds come with different size rims around the outer part of the bud that seemed like it sealed the sound in and secured the bass. Fit Numerous times the Sony Earbuds fell out of my ears. I tried the different caps to try find one that would fit, but not really felt seated in my ear. With the Galaxy Buds, I never felt like the earbuds would fall out. In most cases, I actually like I was peeling the Galaxy Buds out of my ears. This was a good thing. They were secure. Ambient Sound and Noise Cancelling This was kind of the final push for me to go back to the Galaxy Buds. If there is a fan, or something that has a slight hum anywhere around, the ambient noise would pick it up. Fine, I turn off the ambient noise. That's kind of a waste of a feature, but whatever. With the Noise Cancelling, because the earbuds never really fit in my ear totally, noise cancelling was mostly just a muffling of the sound. Also, instead wooshing with the fan, I got a low rumble in the earbuds. When I turned off noise cancelling, that low wooshing stopped. Calls/Use/Battery Life The battery on these Earbuds is less than half of the Galaxy Earbuds. I got numerous complaints from people when I was on conference calls about not hearing me or hearing extraneous noises. I had to shift to a wired headset. When listening to music, the Left earbud would drain faster than the right. And when taking them out, it was possible to turn the music back on by accident, even though the auto off was turned on. The App UMMM... There was some calibration tool and some sound adjustments that didn't really make a ton of sense. I played with all of them to see if there was some sort of setting to give me the best experience. My feeling is that you shouldn't have to spend that much effort to get a clean consistent sound. It felt like there were features for the sake of features. It even had a player. I didn't hate these Earbuds. It was just not up to what I expected with the spectacular reviews and my prior experience with my Galaxy Earbuds. Anyway... I'm going to the Galaxy Earbuds Plus+.
The sound keeps shaking even if you switch the mode of sound priority to connectivity priority. Extremely disappointed with this product.

The bluetooth on these is trash; it blips and cuts out and disconnects if I turn my head or someone walks by or a butterfly flaps its wings - I've never had such bad bluetooth issues on any device before. I've made sure the firmware is up to date, but that didn't help at all. The sound quality is only slightly better than my Beats in-ears. It's a good thing these come with 7 different sizes and types of in-ear padding because it took me forever to get the right fit so they wouldn't just fall out of my ear if I moved too much. But even then, the noise-cancelling is only so-so, there's no way to get a good enough seal to be truly noise-cancelling. You can also only customize the tap-controls to an extent. There's a list of things the headphones will allow you to do, but you can't mix and match from that list. You can't control noise-cancellation, play/pause, AND volume at the same time, even if all three theoretically had different gestures. Each ear only lets you pick one type of control, and you can't add or subtract from that type's given list of abilities. Hopefully they'll fix this in a future firmware update because it is unnecessarily restricted. Bottom line: at $75 these would be fine, but for $230 they're way overpriced.
Simple and Reliable.

column8: For music with 2 ears great. Phone conversations HORRIBLE
column9: Listening to music with two years this is pretty good for phone conversations this is horrible!
Really am enjoying these headphones - music sounds awesome. Calling is a bit more problematic but still good.
Not good
Love this Sony product. Works great!
Bad battery out of the box

There are some very good, in-depth reviews already posted, so I don't want to duplicate what has already been said. I am a dedicated Apple devotee, except when it comes to earbuds. Having spent hours comparing the WF-1000XM3 with the Apple AirPods Pro, I stuck with Sony. Why? 1. The noise cancelling is better. 2. The sound and fidelity is significantly better - I'd say a good 25-30% as a rough judgement. 3. Apple does not have a dedicated app that enables numerous adjustment - almost as good as Jaybirds. 4. AirPods Pro will only work with the most recent iOS and MacOS so I could only use them with my iPhone 11 - not my iPad or iMac, but they did work with my Apple Watch. 5. Sony's touch functions are way easier to use than trying to press the smaller AirPods Pro stem. In my opinion Apples earbuds while good - are not better than the Sony based on the criteria above in a direct comparison using them side by side. As a disclosure I also own the WM-1000XM3 over ear headset. While their noise-cancelling is a little better than their earbuds, I think the sound quality of the earbuds is better. Sony has been in the professional sound studio equipment business for decades, and I can't help believe that this give their sound products an edge. For all else - I love Apple's products and own most of them.
Totally worth the price. Sony always offers quality products. I love these babies.
Great earphones. Noise cancelation is amazing, sound quality is very good.

I like these earbuds! I didn’t think they were going to be as good as they are. I mean, they are earbuds. I stick 'em in my ears and hear stuff from my phone/laptop. These not only cancel sound, when I want to, but allow background noise when I want to hear things around me, like when I’m walking; and, I don’t have to constantly change the settings. I just set how I want the sound to work when I’m walking, sitting, commuting, or running; and, it automatically adjusts based on what I’m doing. If someone wants to talk to me while I have them in, I just put my finger on the right earbud and I can hear them, or I take an ear bud out and the sound pauses until I put them back in. My exit routine has an extra step... *pat* phone, *pat* keys, *pat* wallet, *pat* earbuds. I’m okay to leave.
Great quality!

column8: Good but not worth the price.
column9: First, I love the look of these which is why I ordered them. However, there are a few reasons I returned them and got the new AirPods pro (which are way more worth the exorbitant price). These are by no means cheap at over $200 and the noise cancelling works albeit not as good as the AirPods pro. I went through all the tips of which there are many like soft padded ones and standard rubber ones. The app for this is probably the worst I have ever used and frequently crashed or froze and would not provide information or not recognize I had the headphone(s) in. I say headphone because normally I use only one at a time and this meant that I would not have access to the application as it would think I had none in. The sound was clear with a good amount of bass but even after a couple of days was weak and not loud at all, even having a hard time keeping up when I was running down a busy highway. I want to note that I have a larger tragus and these were downright painful after just a little bit of tune because the front of the headphone pressed down hard on it just so I could maintain a good seal. No matter how I turned it it always ended up pressing hard on some part of my ear. I hope this helps some people as I wanted to love these but with the bulk of a huge case, overly large size of the headphone pressing on soft body parts and causing pain, a terrible application and sound that did not boom I would not recommend these for anyone looking for anc headphones. The AirPods pro are an example of the best of these kind and just work, small form factor and easy to use app interface. (I do have an iPhone).

Great for listening to music and podcasts but if you make a phone call these headphone are garbage. Call quality is complete trash which makes this the last sony headphone I will buy. So expensive and call quality is worse than $10 walmart brands, just get the Bose.

column8: Good bass, Volume control from buds, NOT for gym!
column9: You definitely have to adjust and re-adjust these buds if you move around a lot. These buds are for chillin'. The sound is awesome and with the latest software update you can now control the volume from the earbuds! I gave the noise cancellation 4 stars because I don't like the A.I. automatic noise cancellation. But you can change that setting and set as much noise cancellation as you desire. This is the better setting in my opinion. These buds have Good bass and a great balanced sound across the musical spectrum. I highly recommend these to anyone who wants excellent sound while doing light activities, ex: sitting, house cleaning, and walking. THESE ARE NOT FOR WORKING OUT IN THE GYM OR RUNNING!
By far the best BT ear bud on the market literally leaps and bounds better then Apples ear buds and fits better in ear!! Love them

A few points: Pros: - Good sound quality - The noise cancelling is very effective when you're in a closed environment - Generally comfortable and stay in your ear when still Cons: - There are 22, yes 22, noise cancellation options. These can only be controlled through the app (i.e. if they're connected to your laptop and you want to change the setting, you have to disconnect from your laptop, connect to your phone, open the app, wait for it to load, change the setting, disconnect from your phone, and reconnect to your computer.) - The app is often unresponsive or simply not working - Bulky (especially the charging case) - The noise cancelling is useless when outside with any semblance of wind. You have to switch to "wind noise reduction" mode, which doesn't cancel noise...
Highly recommend! !
The lack of any aptx (preferably aptx low latency) makes them terrible for watching movies or playing games on a plane, the 500ms latency is abysmal.

I purchased these Sony earbuds in anticipation of a long airline flight, where the noise-cancelling feature would be useful and welcomed. I previously owned a set of second generation Apple AirPods, but decided to replace them with the Sony product. In addition to the noise cancellation feature, I also wanted longer battery, as well as faster pairing with multiple devices. I'm not disappointed. The Sony's noise-cancellation ability is good; not quite as good as, for example, a set of Beats over-the-ear headphones... but as good as can be expected. I like the ability to select a mode where external sounds are incorporated. The battery life is quite good; I don't get the advertised '6 hours with noise cancellation enabled, 8 hours with noise cancellation disabled', but it does come close. I'd say it's good for 5 hours or so, with noise cancellation on. Furthermore, when the batteries run low, a voice announcement informs me... but the earbuds continue to operate for another half hour or so. This performance is much better than the Apple AirPods they replace. Pairing is actually better than the AirPods. I use these earbuds both with Apple devices (iPod, iPhone), as well as with a generic Bluetooth transmitter connected to my TV. The Sony earbuds connect instantly with the Apple products... but they also connect much faster to the TV Bluetooth Transmitter. I don't find them quite as comfortable as the Apple product, even after optimizing the fit with the set of differently-sized ear tips that are provided... but this is a minor quibble. The recharging case is pretty big.... not exactly the kind of thing you'd want to keep in your pocket... but it's a small price to pay for long battery life and rapid recharging.

column8: Great purchase and value, totally recommended
column9: Great set of in ear headphones. The sound quality is great and the battery feels like it last forever. I use these for the hour long train ride to/from work. The noise cancelling is not a good as my over ear headphones, but they work good enough for the purpose. Really happy with this purchase and would advise if you're interested in a new pair of noise cancelling headphones.

column8: Connects to only one device at a time.

My Bose QC35 will pair to my 2 phones or phone and iPad at the same time. No reconnecting needed. If the Sony's had this I probably would have kept them.

column8: ANC of the gods, sound is good?
column9: The ANC is nothing short of amazing. I never knew how amazing it could be until i tried these. The app needs a visual overhaul, works well just feels slow when you have to expand every item to use it. Its like having a sound track to your life, its amazing. The charging case is awesome, glows, and charges. it works, nothing special here.

column8: Only connectivity has issues once in a while
column9: The worst part is that there are a few connectivity issues once in a while but these are a very solid pair of earbuds and I have been using them extensively for 5 months. A very good purchase.

column8: Great sound, terrible skips and drops during use
column9: Had great sound and ideal noise cancelling. I heard the wind noise when outside, but it wasn’t all that detrimental. They fit ok- the foam tips actually worked poorly for me, but the silicone tips were great. The reason for the 2 star overall is due to frequent audio skips/drops while using my iPhone 11 Pro. I use Apple Music and the 11 Pro for the majority of my headphone uses. Nothing I could do would eliminate these skips. For comparison, I have the WH-1000xm2 and have 0 issues. Returned these within the week.

These earbuds break connection a lot more then you're average bluetooth earbuds and have underwhelming bass compared to previous products made by Sony(although still pretty good). Still though I would die if I didn't have these everyday at work but a cheap 40 dollar pair of earbuds at walmart will do the job just as good
Sound quality is fantastic. Battery life is a bit shorter than I prefer, but charges quickly. Occasionally the bluetooth disconnects when idle. Overall a good set of earbuds
Excellent

column9: There are quite a few bugs with voice over calls and loss of connection the biggest ones. Sony should look into it asap.

column8: Music sound great, call quality not so much. Not very comfortable!
column9: Everything was great but the only issue I had was call quality was not great and it didnt settle in the ear very well and was a bit uncomfortable. Best sou d quality for music lovers tho. App was a bit confusing but not overkill. Would recommend for music lovers but not people who talk a lot on phone.

I wanted to love them. I'm on an Samsung Android phone. They paired up easily and the connection stayed Rock solid. I used them for about 3 weeks, at the gym, at work, on a flight, at home, etc. I listen to some music, a lot of books and pod casts. The sound quality was good, clean and clear for this purpose. They are a little bigger than I was expecting. I couldn't get them to fit right and feel comfortable in my ears. I tried every combination of the different sized included silicone ear adapters. I just couldn't seem to find one that held them securely in my ears. Although they only fell out once, they always felt like the were going to fall out and I was always trying to push them deeper into my ears to get a better fit. All ears are different but despite all my attempts, I just couldn't get them to fit and feel correct. Maybe because of the fit, I was less than impressed by the noise cancellation. I wore them on a couple of four hour flights. The noise cancelling was there, you can tell the difference when it's turned on verses just having the ear buds in your ears, but it is underwhelming. The noise cancellation is the main reason I paid up for these but I was disappointed. I have a cheap pair of over the ear headphones that cost way less and work just as well, if not better, at noise cancellation. If you are buying for this feature you may want to reconsider. Phone call sound quality was adequate on both ends of the conversation. Battery life was ok, I got about 5 hours per charge which is pretty good, not all day good, but pretty good. The included case has about two additional charges in it but it's pretty large and cumbersome to fit in a pants pocket. They're not horrible, the sound quality is good, the noise cancellation is dissapointing. The battery life is just ok. I actually returned them to Amazon (they are great with returns) and got the Galaxy buds plus which I like better.
Perfect. Best in class.
It works.
Excellent noise cancellation, pretty decent sound quality
Terrible connection, bad fit, hard to stay in ears, heavy and chunky, case too big, okay sound quality and noise cancellation

I like the headphones but I can not just connect the right earphone. The left one solo connects but not the right. The case holder is a little big but you get a long battery life with the ear buds. Sound is good but it does not always stay connected. I am using a samsung s10 note as my phone.

column8: Good for music / Bad call quality
column9: Good: for noisy places, listening to music Bad: horrible call quality, every caller asked "are you on bluetooth?" which is the ultimate reason to return this.

Based on how high this product has been reviewed by the experts it is a far less superior product to Apple air pods. Noise canceling is non existent. Product is large and bulky which causes it to fall out of your ears constantly. Don’t buy it. Save yourself from buying two and just got straight to Apple.

These are great! When the work. The sound quality is awesome, the noise canceling is good, I can't hear anything when they're in, the battery life really is 6 hours, I can't imagine life without them. But sometimes they don't work: Sometimes they won't power on. Sometimes only one will power on. Sometimes the audio in one lags behind the other. Sometimes the audio quality is bad. Sometimes they won't shut off when I put them in the case. Sometimes the vocal queues freeze - "Battery is isisisisisisiisisisisisis" And God, that's frustrating. Why did Sony release this product without fixing these problems? How did QC not catch these issues?
La calidad del producto está perfecta, la única queja es que al entrar una llamada suele entrar más ruido del que deberia.

column8: Only hear music, no ambient sound
column9: As per expected, use it and you will lost in to your world.

tl;dr It's awful. Don't buy it or you'll be paying return shipping like me. The over-ear model (WH-1000XM3) has been a go-to headphone choice for traveling folks like me. I had the expectation that this product would be the same as the over-ear model, and I was wrong. The comfort is awful. It feels like my ears are being violated by the tips provided in the box. Also, if you don't get the "right" fit, the noise-cancelling is useless, which is 90% of the time. One earbud is just right, no matter how I stuff the other, it won't work right. Once I got into it, I discovered that it only provides SBC and AAC listening. No Hi-Res listening like the over-ear model. That DSEE-HX Is an upscaler, which is like taking a 720p video and watching it on a 4K TV. It's not good. For me, LDAC on the original model made it very appealing. The tapping-based controls of the headphones are unresponsive compared to the over-ear model. The "mandatory" headphone app doesn't allow much customization with the gestures (I want noise cancelling to be on a double tap on my left ear, but I'm not allowed change that.) Finally, the earbuds disconnect from my device during charging. I have to take them out, wait for the reconnect, then use them. It's infuriating when I just want to listen to some music. It's the small things that add up to making a bad product. Sony's over-ear model provides LDAC, good NC, and comfort. It has physical buttons for NC, Ambient noise, and power, with simple controls that are extremely intuitive. This provides none of that at two-thirds of the cost. Don't buy it. I returned mine while paying for return shipping.

column8: Great Headphones for music and phone calls
column9: I'm constantly on the road, and was using the regular wired headphones for calls, and then had a pair of nice Sony noise cancelling over-ears for movies on Planes, et cetera. I was on a trip through Japan and noticed everyone ws using these, so I finally bought a pair when I got back to the US. The sounds quality is great, although it did take a little tuning, and the battery life is fantastic. I've brought these all over the world and I love them.

column8: Bulky and doesn't stay in ear.
column9: The sound quality is off the hook!!!! They sound better than most over the ear headphones. That being said, I could not find any set of foam buds to fit my ear. They also lack some of the integral advantages that the air pods I have with my iPhone. If I just move my head too quick or eat moving my jaw, they come out and fall to the ground. Not cool, easy to lose one. Although I love the sound quality, I would not recommend these if you have weird ears and want total integration with your iPhone.

column8: These don't stay in my ears!
column9: I had to return these. They come with tons of ear attachments but none of them fit well enough to keep them from falling out of my head. Also, there were microseconds where the sound would drop from one of the earbuds. I do not recommend. I went back to my pair of Bose wireless earbuds. They don't have noise canceling but the stay in perfectly.

I bought these (not on Amazon) and have had them for about 30 days. Unfortunately, they're going back. I have Sony over the ear noise cancelling which are awesome. I wanted these for video conferences so I didn't have a huge headset on. The sound quality on calls is horrendous. There is an annoying digital blip that happens frequently when sound comes from the other end. I worked with Sony tech support and they were unable to resolve the issue. I was hoping a firmware update would fix it. One released yesterday, I applied, annoying noise is still there. It's so annoying, you can't concentrate on what the other person is saying. Lastly, as other reviews note, these do little to cancel noise. Nowhere near over the ear Bose or Sony I have (which I wouldn't expect), but not even noticeable reduction in outside noise when turning it on.
Only real problem is that the top of the charging case gets scratched easily

Nothing about these headphones really amazed me. The sound quality is okay, the best part is probably the equalizer in the app. I found that they had some static and cut out from time to time. The noise cancelling is just okay and ironically the actual sound pumped in from the headphones to cancel it is more annoying than the outside sound. It's very distinct and causes a lot impedence. The battery life is amazing, I would have to give them points for that and the nice design and build quality of the case and headphones. The ear pieces are very nice and comfortable, and they are probably the best part of the noise cancelling. The sound quality is smooth but unremarkable, I have a $7.00 pair of Panasonic earbuds, and I actually prefer the sound quality from them. The latency is crazy high, you're looking at a full second of lag. If you're thinking about playing a game or something with these it absolutely will not work. Overall I feel like these are pretty mediocre, definitely not worth $250, that is robbery for what you get with these. If having true wireless is that important to you, I suppose these are some of the best you could buy. For me though, I am happier with my Panasonics.
great for noise cancelling and music...not the greatest for phone calls ...
Lo mejor.
Not a GYM earbuds
I liked it for its noise cancellation feature and I use it for work so I can switch to ambient sound so I can still hear around me.

Really great range of sound, functional app that improves sound quality based on EQ, noise cancellation is great Bulky and heavy, good for walking and sitting . Just don’t move around too much or think about working out in these. Maybe it’s my ears but none of the sizes seems to stay in when moving around.

Overall great. Price is about 25-40 bucks over priced but still great earbuds. Pros Sound is overall on point. Connection is good. They sound better then AirPods Cons The charger box is too big doesn’t fit in the pocket comfortably The EarPods themselves look kinda goofy they’re so big.

Pros: fantastic sound quality, great EQ customization capability, ANC is top notch. With firmware 2.3, microphone quality has improved - 90% of Airpods Pro level. Cons: little inconvenient with the large and bulky carrying case, fit may bother some. Biggest CON: right earbud loses connection after 15-20 minutes of listening, especially when turning head. Sound returns by itself after 1-5 minute. VERY ANNOYING. Ordered replacement with the hope that my unit faulty. FYI, I am using iPhone X, macbook pro and iPad pro to connect.
good

column8: Was hoping for more and missed the return window
column9: After reading all the positive reviews on these earbuds, I was hopeful. And I liked the fact that Alexa voice control was included. But these things will not stay in my ear. I have the same problem with a lot of earbuds that do not have fins or loops to secure the device to the ear. Went back to my old Bose wired in-ear headphones and missed the return window. Sound is good and the noise cancelation works, but no matter how hard you screw them into your ear canal they fall out at the slightest turn of your head. Going to try 1More Stylish Earbuds and see if they stay in place better.

I was on the fence on getting true wireless buds for a while. I did a lot of research and landed on these. I came from the wireless (not really wireless) jaybird x2s which I liked. Long story short these buds surpassed all expectations. They have a really wide stage for earbuds wider than any I have used and really provide a clear and balanced sound. I am an audio professional, but my main desktop setup is dt990a through an amp. I find myself listening to these instead more and more for the convenience. PROS +INSANE RANGE I can leave my phone downstairs and walk to the bathroom upstairs without sound cutting out. + Battery life is amazing and I've never had to worry about charging. I use them all day at work no issues. +Equalizer in app is amazing and Reddit as plenty of presets that people recommend for different genres +sound canceling is insane (be careful I almost walked in front of a car with them in). Cons - They go deep in yours ears and take about a week of getting used to but are by no means uncomfortable - app is kinda weird it acts strangely sometimes when you disconnected earbuds and recconect (noise cancelling always comes back on by default) I'm sure this will get improved over time
Noise cancelling very mediocre and cannot be paired with PC. Don't waste your money.

I'm not sure where to start. Half the time the earbuds don't power off once taken out and set down. The power drains drastically different between the two earbuds even though I don't use the control functions on them. Noise cancellation works for me but for people I'm talking to on the phone all background sounds seem amplified. Then there are the connection issues. Constant, unrelenting connectivity issues. I haven't dropped these earbuds. They don't leave my house. And why exactly do I need two apps downloaded to use these headphones? These are the worst ear buds I've ever had the displeasure of owning. Given the price Sony should be ashamed of itself.

column8: I should have stayed with My Bose Quiet Comfort
column9: I'm having a hard time with regret over these. Three weeks ago, my second pair of Bose QC 30's began falling apart. A little annoyed at the quality of the workmanship on them and my previous pair, I decided to look elsewhere. Most reviews on the WF-1000XM3 earbuds are thru the roof with praise for the design, sound quality and noise cancelling. Now, with my QC 30's, I could connect to both my phone and my tablet, and switch between them with a push of a button on the headset. Few earbuds I looked at supported multiple device connection, but the WF-1000XM3's listed that as a feature. Great. Those were the buds for me. What the reviews, packaging, support site, youtube videos etc. didn't say was that while you can connect to multiple devices only one is ever really connected. They say only one is active, but that's misleading. Only one Ever is connected. To switch devices, you have 1. have both devices in your hands 2. log into both device A 3. go into BLUETOOTH settings 4. Manually disconnect the headphones 5. login into device B 6. Go to BLUETOOTH settings 7. Manually re-connect to the headphones 8. Wait for the earbuds to catch up. These steps were not present in an Google searches I performed, weren't in the product literature, and weren't in any of the youtube videos I watched. To get them, I had to contact support and go thru all sorts of time-wasting do-this-first support steps (reset the device, reconnect bluetooth, verify software version, etc. etc. etc. etc.) only to finally get the answers above after almost half an hour on the support chat. Sorry SONY, but that doesn't qualify as multiple bluetooth device support in my book. That's not even a work-around. That's a kludge. OK, so I'm annoyed over that. Take a deep breath, lets test the noise cancelling and sound quality. Oh. My. God. Really? People are raving about these? The sound is tinny or fuzzed. I played with the equalizer and found nothing that sounded good. Maybe I've been spoiled by Bose, but the noise cancelling on the WF-1000XM3 doesn't come close to what I had with my QC 30's. They're not even in the same area code. As I write this, I'm wearing them. I have them set to Noise Cancelling on and set to MAX thru the app, Adaptive Noise Control turned off. I can hear myself typing with the same volume with Noise Cancelling on or disabled. Wearing them while grinding coffee this morning, I could not hear my music. I wore them as I took my trash to the curb. I heard every bird chirp, every step I made, and the rumble of my trashcan wheels. As I closed the garage door, the rumble of the door cancelled out my music. Sorry, but that's noise cancelling in the wrong direction. And yes, SONY Support, I tried each of the different sized silicone ear pieces. The ones I'm using are as good as it gets. And yes, I have Adaptive Sound control turned off, and noise cancelling MANUALLY set to Max. And yes, I have the latest software, and Yes, I did a factory reset, and yes, I did clear it from bluetooth and re-add it. I have to wonder about all the positive reviews. Either SONY gave a lot of these things away as review incentives, or people have never experienced real noise cancelling. My advice: spend the extra $50 and get the Bose QC 30's. WF-1000XM3's are not worth the money, time or aggravation.

Triple comfort earbuds (S, M, L × 2) long hybrid silicone rubber earbuds (stainless, S, M, L × 2), card, operating instruction, Reference guide, USB Type C cable (Approx. 20cm) ALL WERE MISSING NOT IN BOX

They work well but are fairly heavy. I find that I’m always readjusting the earbuds to stop them from slipping out of my ears. I wish they had the expanded eartips that cover more of the ear so they can grip better. The sound quality and noise canceling is very good. There doesn’t seem to be any guidance on how to use them with Amazon Alexa.

Amazing noise cancellation. Comes with a multitude of earbud tips that could fit many ear shapes, once you find the one with the best fit, the noise cancellation is bar none the BEST I've ever heard on earbuds. Audio quality is great, sound is clear and not very neutral, not bass heavy. Personally I prefer this, but I know that might not be for everyone. Though the equalizer can make up for this. The battery life lasts about 6 hours, and I've yet to have an issue with them not making it through the day. 5 out of 5, worth the expense.

The sound quality is great if you can get it to stay in place in your ear. My ears apparently generate a ton of wax, so they start falling out in a matter of a couple hours, but that's my problem. Some way of securing it better to your ear would be welcome, though. The only problem I have is the noise cancellation, and this may be a problem common to many or all noise-cancelling devices, but this is the only one I've used. It uses external mics to detect sound around you so it can produce the right frequencies to cancel out, but if there's even a little amount of wind (a breeze, really), it sounds like someone blowing into their mic or phone during a conversation. Pretty annoying. Otherwise an excellent product, definitely worth the money I paid.

column8: Frustrating yet amazing, still lots for Sony to improve on
column9: Everything about these earbuds is great in terms of what is advertised versus what you get: the noise cancelling is truly great for the size, the ambient noise pass through is really great, and the audio quality is incredible when compared to budget earbuds. The battery life is great, the charging case is sleek and easy to use, and labeling the left and right earbuds with different color dots is a stroke of genius. Now for the not so good: these fall out so damn often that I have to return them. I got them for a daily commute which involves walking but they cannot seem to stay in for an extended period of time while walking, chewing gum, and much less running. I don't use them for working out but jaw movement and minor bumps seem to dislodge them quite easily. Additionally, the Bluetooth connection seemed heinously unreliable for the price, and when it comes to Bluetooth usage for phone calls, they are infuriating. I hope they can fix these issue with a firmware update, and I'll look into getting replacement eartips for them because I like the other features enough to keep them.
A+

Very impressed with these earbuds. Sound quality is probably the best for any earbuds that I have owned, wireless or otherwise. Noise cancellation is good, but I haven't had an opportunity to really see how well it works in various settings. For me at least, they are also remarkably comfortable. Battery life compared to some other options on the market isn't as good, but for me it hasn't been an option. I usually have an opportunity throughout the day to throw them in the case and let them charge for a bit. No reservations about these and I have recommended them to several of my friends.

column8: Amazon very slow to deliver products,
column9: Good soundstage, a lot of dropout in signal, after reading all the rave reviews, and checking out all on youtube, I must say that these earphones do provide good noise cancelling, and good sound, but I have been having issues wit the app dropping out and disconnecting momentarily during use, other than that, they are very good for the money, sound is not as good as wired earbuds, but hey, they are completely wireless, which is very nice, I do not feel I have wasted my money, or feel like I was ripped off, money has been doing a great job lately in the manufacturing of premium earbuds, some of my more expensive earbuds have been indestructible, and have been listening to them for about five years without fail,
Awesome earbuds after trying many others I think I found the ones ! !
Unusable latency when watching video. For a product at this price this should not be an issue. Razer's buds are half the price and have solved this. Shameful Sony

column8: Could you please add user controlled timer to turn buds off, otherwise known as 'sleep mode'?
column9: These are great earbuds, no doubt. But many of us use earbuds and headphones to fall asleep. We can turn off content using our phones, but don't want the earbuds to remain on all night. All other headsets I've used have a sleep feature, an easy software update for Sony, I'd think. My Bose 700 headphones work great this way, but.... sleeping with headphones just doesn't work.

column8: Very disappointed in a fit and a quality.
column9: So disappointed... Fist of all, the fit is horrible. Not sure how people can be saying so much that it fits perfect and never fallls out - probably lies. It stays in the ear for about a minute and then starts to slowly fall out. I have standard ears, so it's not related to me. You can actually hear the bud slowly getting out. Noize cancellation - pretty much non existent. You can barely hear the difference once it looks in. Sound pass through is ok, bit them again... What's the point of they fall out and noize cancellation does not do much...? And believe me, I have triues everyone of the tip combinations they offer... Still nothing. I even tried the once from my daily buds that I use for phonecalls that fitnme perfectly, still nothing...

column8: Fantastic audio quality! (when listening to music!)
column9: Have been using these with a couple of iOS devices (iPhone 8 Plus & iPad Air 3rd gen) and am very happy with the audio quality for music. The headphones & iOS devices all support Bluetooth 5.0, so range and connection has been very good, and Bluetooth AAC streaming so audio quality is quite good to my middle-age ears. No idea how well they'd perform with an Android phone using Bluetooth AAC - YMMV? And yeah, about that: There's no AptX support, so AAC is the best Bluetooth codec available, making these fine for use with iOS devices but maybe not so good for use cases not involving AAC over Bluetooth. Overall, these headphones have a sound profile not unlike nearly every other pair of Sony headphones I've owned (MDR-V6, MDR-CD1700, MDR-1RBT, MDR-1000X), which is mostly flat with some low bass boost. Pairing these with my Macbook Pro (Catalina 10.15.3) was a nightmare. I had no idea what the SOC codec even existed until that unfortunate experience, only remedied by Toothfairy which was able to enforce an AAC connection after my time-consuming attempts to poke at the OS Bluetooth system runtime configuration failed. SOC is apparently used for telephony, and because the WF-1000XM3 has a microphone the system treats it like a phone headset rather than audio headphones. It's unlikely I'd ever use these with a Macbook Pro (usually have wired headphones at my desk, or some wired earbuds in my laptop bag), but I had to try. No regrets on my purchase, and I tend to use them often during the day as they're unobtrusive, sound great, and pair & connect easily with my 2 iOS playback devices.

column8: Great sound - if you keep still
column9: I purchased these, not from Amazon, for some work out buds to wear mostly during gym sessions. Bad decision. The sound quality and noise cancellation of these earbuds are second to none. However there is one issue that has really irked me to no end. The fit to the ears and the ability to stay in the ears while moving is absolutely pathetic. I tried all the supplied tips and none of them have made much of a difference at all. The issue is simple. As long as you put them in and remain still or sit in a chair or on the couch and relax everything is fine but the minute you want to tilt your head, bend over, move quickly, run, jump, or do any sort of movement it’s only a matter of less than a minute before one or both will loosen and if your hands are tied up with, say, a barbell, out they fly crashing onto the floor. I guess they’re just too heavy overall. These buds are absolutely not for activity. Buyer beware.

column8: Sound quality can’t compensate for extremely poor connection quality
column9: I really, really wanted to like these. The sound quality is great. But connectivity to my iPhone is so, so awful. Frequent audio drop-outs, lots of audio stuttering. Even the most basic of Bluetooth congestion will cause these to almost completely drop connection. The software for iOS is downright atrocious — frequently the app doesn’t even properly detect that the headphones are connected. Compared to the non-pro AirPods I have, these are total duds. I would rather have the consistent, reliable audio quality of the AirPods over the extremely flakey connection quality of these Sony WF-1000XM3’s. Also: Sony, really? Can’t you come up with an easier to remember model name?

Very high quality. Noise cancellation works very well. Sound quality in general is great. The look and feel of the product is top notch as well. It took a while to find the right tip to be comfortable for long periods of time, but once I got the proper piece, it is quite possible to listen for several hours comfortably. I had them in for most of a train ride from London to Edinburgh one day, which was about a 4 hour ride and had no discomfort. Battery life has been excellent so far as well.

I am not an earbud person. They sort of bug or even hurt me. Maybe my ears are weird. I have had some luck with the soft tipped ones, so I thought these would be good for me. They are more comfortable than hard ones. I don't really need complete noise cancellation, so I don't really seal them when I use them. I work in with many people close to me and the constant talking and chit chat can be distracting to me when I need to do a lot of paperwork. I will use these to help block out my noisy co-workers! I am sure sealing them would help even more, but sometimes I still need to respond to them, so I leave them a little loose so I can still hear them if I try. I really love them more than my over ear headset ones because they aren't as obnoxious to wear. Those are more comfy and they do send the message "leave me alone" but these are more practical.

I bought these to replace my air pods that I lost (again). I’m really disappointed with these ear pods. Fit: They don’t stay in your ear well, even though there’s multiple sizes you can adjust. None of them seem to fit well. They continuously are falling out. More so than my AirPods did. Additionally, they aren’t that comfortable. Syncing: Not good, when someone calls, I have to select the audio from my phone screen, it doesn’t automatically switch to the headset when I’m wearing them. They seem to get out of sync, ie when listening to podcasts they start over, switch to the next episode as examples. The sound quality and noise cancelling is very good. But the over all comfort, fit and syncing issues are big deal, and the reason I probably won’t be using these very much of at all. I would actually like to return them, however I’m concerned that amazon would cut me off, as I’ve read stories that amazon will cut people off that return items.
Excellent sound quality and very good noise cancelation, I recommend 👌

column8: Connection Issues ruined a good product
column9: I'll add some pros and cons below but the bottom line is that the spotty connection made these unusable. Pros: 1) The noise isolation was good once I got used to how to fit them in right. 2) The connection range was great, made it 10-15 yards outside of the front of my house with my phone sitting in the house close to the back yard. 3) The noise cancellation was good. I didn't notice much static sound with it on and it lowered most constant noises significantly (microwave, refrigerator, dishwasher and fans). 4) The sound quality was good, I wasn't blown away but it was better than my old earbuds Cons: 1) The fit can be tough to get right, you'll have to try multiple tips several times and play with how far in to go and how much to twist them into your ear 2) My wife had a tough time getting them to fit at all, I joke that she has tiny ear holes and I guess Sony would agree because these didn't work well with any eartip 3) My wife also heard a constant running water sound when the noise cancellation was on. Possibly due to a bad fit but could just be frequencies I can't hear 4) Battery life seemed really low, after a software update I was getting like 2-3 hours tops with noise canceling on. Before the firmware update I got 4-5 5) The deal breaker was connection issues. On my TV (or computer) sitting 6 feet away (or less) I would get one ear dropping sound every 2 minutes or so. If it wasn't dropping sound then both buds would make a garbled sound which was like a few milliseconds of sound being dropped every half second. I could still mostly understand what was going on but it was terrible to watch like that. Other times I would get a delay from one ear to the other so it was like a constant echo. For anyone that wants more info on the connection issues, I didn't have any issues with my phone at all. With the TV and the computer I also had some times when the connection was solid the whole time so it seems like it's not a hardware issue but something in software. Also I did send back the first pair hoping it was a defect but the second pair had the same problem (both on the original and updated firmware). I also had a pair of over ear BT headphones that I started to test on the TV when my connection would have issues with the earbuds, I never had any connection issues at all with the over ear headphones so it doesn't seem to be a interference issue. So I guess the bottom line is that if you just want to use these with your phone you might be happy with these. If you want to connect to anything else you are rolling the dice as to whether they with have connection issues or not.

Great noise cancellibg earphones, especially for the price. Unfortunately, they weren't comfortable for my unusual ears. If only somebody made Large and extra large tips that were wide but not long. :(

Overall: a five star product. The only issue I would say I have with them would be that they become uncomfortable after about a couple of hours of ware and I find myself taking them out for a minute or two. The battery life is excellent and I have only run out of juice once while using them. I have used them on long 3 hour car drives for its noise isolation and cancellation and they perform well.

So I have had these for 2 weeks now. After watching and reading multiple reviews I set myself up for a bit of disappointment. Although the reviews were all positive there are a few things I did not anticipate when I started using them. This is the first Bluetooth earbud I have ever used so I can’t compare to any other products. Wired earbuds yes, and I have tried a pair of Airbuds a family member has for about 3 minutes. Definitely not a substantial amount of time to use as a comparison. I have a Note 10+ phone and was thinking of trying the Samsung buds at first. I was more excited about the Sony’s for the noise cancelling features. I went for the Sony’s just for that feature more than anything else. I’m not a hardcore music junky so sound quality was not a issue in my buying discresion. Pro's The noise cancelling feature is fantastic. I work in a manufacturing plant with 35 machines making noise all day long. I sit with my back to a wall which reverberates the machine noise. Our operators use compressed air to blow off parts repeatedly every few minutes. Pop these bad boys in and they tune out around 90% of the sound. For this reason I will not return them. The only things I noticed it could not noise cancel were random sounds (rain, forklift beeping and high wind noise). Sound quality is quite good. The preset EQ is tuned very well and I'm sure you will find one that suits your desire. They feel and fit good in my ears. Light weight and do not move around or slide out during the course of the day. I do not run so I can not say they would stay in while exercising. Battery life is acceptable and they charge up very quickly. I wear mine for around 6 hours a day. During lunch I charge them and they seem to be good for the rest of the day work and my commute. Con's Spotty connections. It is a bit annoying to hear them drop out a few times an hour. The drop only lasts for 1 second but still, I expected something better. Microphone is horrible. I'm on the phone a lot during the day. Almost everyone complains they can't hear me clearly in the shop environment. When I go outside with less noise people still have a hard time hearing me. No volume control on the default setting. You can change that in the app but at the loss of other functionality. I seriously wish there was a sliding touch sensor along the bottom side to adjust sound. It is a pain to have to grab the phone to control volume. If you listen to music at a low level and receive a call, I have to pick up the phone to bring the call volume up. If you have the music louder and a call comes in, the ringer is very loud in your ears. You can adjust this in the phone system setting easily enough but I find it inconvenient to have to turn the ring volume back up when not using the earbuds. Button location is large but not exactly where my fingers naturally go. I tend to have to try and find it on the second attempt. I want to touch the front of the earbuds but the button is near the back. Seems a bit awkward to me. Connectivity to some non standard devices has been disappointing. My computer has Bluetooth so I thought it would be cool to get sound from it to watch Youtube or a news video during my lunch or break. Well, sadly it will pair but my Bluetooth seems to only be for file transfers. I can not get sound transmitted in Windows. I can buy a dongle to solve this problem but I would rather not. I was really disappointed when a Sony product could not connect to another Sony product. If you think pairing these earbuds with a PS4 would be the best... sorry they are not supported. Again, I can buy some dongles to "MAKE" them work but who wants to do that? Sony not supported by Sony? What's up with that? The case is a bit large. I think the design could have been refined. Seems like there is a AA battery in the bottom of the case to give you an idea of what I think should have been sized down. Additionally the lid could have been thinned down as well. The last annoying thing. When you take a call it deactivates the noise cancelling feature and puts the earbuds back into ambient sound mode. This is frustrating to say the least. I want to hear the caller and not the outside sounds. I have to assume this is a safety feature so you don’t get hit by a car while walking. I would prefer it stay in noise cancelling mode but that is just my opinion. Last thoughts. Would I recommend them to a friend? Probably not. I would recommend trying some other brands. Maybe ask a coworker or friend if they wouldn't mind letting you test out whatever they use.

column8: Great headphones, not great in the wind
column9: I bought the product to use for biking and running, but they caught the wind and amplified the wind sound so much it made it very difficult to use outside going faster than a walk.
Simply amazing. No complaints.

Great sound and noise canceling for an earbud. Would have loved to keep them but they would not keep a connection on phone calls or FaceTime with my iPhone 11. The call would come in and the audible ring would sound in the earbud. Once the call was answered audio would transfer back to the phone. I would have to go into the phone call settings and force the earbuds to take back the audio.

You know that happy feeling when you open a box and get more then what you paid for well you don’t have to worry about that with this item it’s a dispirited disappointing failure from one of the top names in the business the sound quality is unmatched I could have kept them just for that but the noise canceling leaves a lot to be desired I’m afraid it’s a waste of time it got delivered yesterday it was last night before I got to try them out and I was happier with the pair I got at wal-mart for 49$ just wish I could find them. The Idiots that give em thumbs up on YouTube are the paid idiots Sony or Amazon , ebay, Newegg that get to keep the stuff they. Advertise. Well like you, I pay hard earned money for My stuff and if it doesn’t do exactly what they claim I return it and buy something that does.

These are definitely not worth the money. I have had these for a year. If you are barely moving, they work great. Otherwise they skip and are pretty much garbage. Huge disappointment. I have several other Bluetooth headphones for work (Bose) and working out (JBL Sprint) and they are cheaper, don't skip, and better sound.

These came today because my older wired Bose ones crapped out finally after a few years and a lot of wear and tear. It's like I've never heard music before! Sure there MIGHT be some out there that are "fine tuned" this or "bass thump" that- but it's not like my ear will be able to tell the difference. The thing they can? THE NOISE CANCELLATION. I used these while using a leaf blower, angle grinder, and oscillator, and it was like I was listening to a live concert and couldn't hear ANYTHING else! I was not paid to write this- and rarely, if ever write a review. BUT- I did a ton of research and reading before I chose these, so I feel like if I can pass it forward, I will. I got myself the black ones and love the style and fit, and will be buying the white ones for my wife- she loved mine too! Pros- Fit (they come with about 8 different sized tips) Style Battery Life: is great- sure not as long as the Galaxy, but the case can charge them 3x NOISE CANCELLATION Size Cons- Noise cancellation is so great that my wife scared the crap out of me and I put a bad divot in my concrete project.

Pros: Great sound and noise-cancelling quality. Cons: Hard to switch between laptop music and phone for calls while working; not a perfect fit in ear and heavy/bulky enough that they would slip and need to be readjusted frequently; connectivity issues - sometimes one earphone would connect and the other wouldn’t, which drove me crazy. I ended up returning the product and bought AirPod Pros. Super satisfied with the AirPods, despite the $50 price increase. I did quite a bit of reading beforehand and thought I’d like the Sony product best, but it did not fit and stay connected as necessary.

column8: Poor Bluetooth swapping. No Sports. Decent sound. So-so phone mic. Good Battery.
column9: In short, I'm unimpressed, and I tend to be a Sony guy. The sound being the most important part of any headphone, here left me unimpressed. As with most earbuds, the bass is faint, the mid is 50/50 and the high end is great, but it is not particularly well balanced. There's also an extreme lack of overall power. With everything turned up all the way, there were still movies I couldn't watch via tablet on a plane even with the noise cancellation. My plug in headphones worked fine. The Bluetooth is frustrating in general. The headphones must be unpaired with one device in order to connect to another. Meaning, if you were using them with your tablet, and now you want to use them with your phone, you MUST unpair with the tablet first or they're useless to the phone. This is irritating as I don't always carry my tablet around. Battery life seems good, charger pack is cool, but it's finish will scratch and degrade easily. The built in microphone for phone calls is fine if you're in a quiet place, but even basic room noise is noticed by those I speak with. They are not useful with sports, running or cycling in particular. Any wind or breeze creates significant static chaos making them worthless in this environment. For the money, I'm just not impressed. They are decent earbuds with decent sound and good battery life, but for the most expensive pair buds out there, they should be significantly better.

column8: Great for listening. Not so much for talking.
column9: Mic stopped working properly after months of use.

column8: disappointing performance in fit and noise canceling
column9: To get decent performance of these earbuds, they must be able to make a good seal in the ear canal. Sadly, none of the included squishy ear tips worked for me. Even the largest failed to seal and if I walked while wearing them, they just fell out. I bought larger third party tips and got a seal, but then was disappointed at the quality of the noise cancelling. My daily walk goes through a neighborhood infested with leaf blowers. The noise canceling of these earbuds was noticeably inferior to my old worn out Bose earbuds. Finally, the feature of removing or tapping the earbud to pause rarely worked. In listening to Audible, I would find my story chapters ahead of where I put the earbuds away because they failed to pause.

After having these for well over 4 months I have to say that I'm a little dissapointed with these very expensive earbuds. Sound quality is great as well as the noise cancelling, and since I work in a noisy enviroment it's great to have. However, the bluetooth connection is absolutely awful. There are moments when I'm listening to music and out of nowhere the sound completely cuts out to the point where I have to turn them on and off, as well as times when the audio cuts in and out when I'm listening to music. I mean, I didnt pay over $200 for earbuds that cut off constantly. I dont usually write reviews on Amazon, but I just had to complain about this. Really dissapointed and now getting ready to sell them.

column8: Not as great as I had hoped for a sony product
column9: Not sure about everyone else's, I've had my headphones for 8 days. They now won't pair or show up on my phone's BT. So a waste of $200 to me. The bass really isn't that great, there are some songs that has a hiss coming through my headphones. Not even sure how I can return these. Dont spend the money if you dont have it to spend.

column8: For a brand like Sony, these earbuds are seriously flawed
column9: I was stunned by how poor the audio quality is. Tinny with limited frequency response. Changing sizes of the ear tops made no difference. Limited controls. Terrible Sony app. The inflated price does not justify such a poorly developed Sony earbud.

column8: Overall a good product, but not for everyone
column9: I also own an AirpodsPro, so it is inevitable to compare these two. I got this as a replacement of my APP which is being repaired. WF's Noise cancellation was ok, however the transparent mode got wrecked. Sound quality was better than APP for sure, especially since SONY offers a configuration app that allows the user to tune the sound mode. But by end of the day I had to return this product, because wearing them was a nightmare. Although the description of this product describes the wearing to be comfortable, I could not have them on my ear for more than 1 hour. I have tried all provided earplugs, but none of them helped. APP could rest on my ear all day without notice. So the ergonomics of this product apparently just doesn't work for me.

column8: Works good but frequent connection problems with my s10+
column9: It's a new adjustment from my galaxy buds but I really like them. Noise cancellation isn't as good as I thought but really good considering they dont cover the entire ear like headphones.
