I wish the 360 reality sound was good without paying for a subscription on another app but I can live without it. More recently for me the right earbud disconnects from my from frequently and sporadically. One second it will work and the next it beeps off. I can fix it by putting it back and the case and taking it out but the connection doesn't last long. Besides that they work really good.

column8: Easiest to use on the market!
column9: Holy cow! I absolutely loved these! The set up was absurdly easy! They're completely noise canceling. They fit perfectly! And the added functionality of the buttons on either side... incredible. I love that I can do so much without even having to touch my phone! I also loved that the case was magnetic, I'm a lot less worried about them popping out if I drop it!

The earbuds were delivered on time and packaging was very good, which made the unboxing experience very pleasant. The charging case feels nice and high quality, built with high quality materials and feels sturdy. The charging case however is very bulky and not something that can be carried in jeans pocket when you step out. The bulky charging base provides more charges on the go, but would be nice if I had option of choosing a larger or smaller size case. The earbuds are on the bulky side but are lightweight and comfortable to wear for short periods of time, but get's uncomfortable over longer periods of time. The sound quality and bluetooth connection is great and did not have any issues while listening to music. Pairing the earbuds to my phone was also a breeze. The "Headphones" app gives the flexibility to choose the sound signature that suits you the best and works great, it also lets your customize various other features of the earbuds. Noise cancelling and ambient modes work very well for earbuds this size when you are indoors, like in a room or commuting. However, its a completely different story outdoors, the external microphone catches a lot of wind and you will hear buzzing sound through the earbuds when noice cancelling or ambient mode is turned on outdoors. You will hear this even when its not windy outside, just walking is enough. Let's talk about call quality. All my calls were clear and person on the other end could hear me well, but I always hear a lot of static noice when on a phone call and would expect a better experience with high end earbuds. Battery life of the earbuds are good and as advertised, I was able to get 6 hours of mixed usage with ambient mode and noise cancelling. The charging case provides 3 extra charges which is great and sort of justifies the bulky charging case Touch controls on the earbuds work great. These are not physical buttons but touch pads on both earbuds and are very sensitive and easy to use, having touch controls is great since you don't get the feeling of pushing the earbuds deep inside your ears every time you touch them. Left ear buds control the ambient sound and noise canceling which worked every single time for me. Right buds control pause and play and skip tracks which also works really well. The right buds can also be customized for volume control depending on your needs. The below improvements will make these earbuds a great contender for quality high end ear buds - Poketable charging case with wireless charging - Water resistance - Smaller earbuds and more comfort for long term wearing - Better placed external microphone so reduce wind noice outdoors - Better call quality.

column8: Terribly over rated. Try the Bose.
column9: I am disappointed in these. The noise cancelling is inferior to the Bose q30 in ear buds. Also the connectivity is poor. I continually have to repair with my Samsung Galaxy 9 phone and my Fire 8. I experimented with all of the provided ear tips. Considering the price, these are a terrible investment and I will probably return them.
These things are truly incredible. Watched some YouTube videos on how to set them for music and OMG. You not believe how great they sound.
I was very hopeful for these. They are horrible. They glitch, the noise cancelling sucks and the battery life is short. I wish I went with the AirPods.

A few months into purchasing these the issues appeared which is disappointing as I thought these would be a godsend for working from home. The left earbud died, randomly. The app is terrible, hard to navigate and updating the software is always a challenge. The Bluetooth disconnects randomly, even when my phone is two inches from the earbuds. Overall, very disappointed especially for the price.

column8: Don’t buy if using computer or WhatsApp/FaceTime calls
column9: DO NOT BUY if you intend to use these headphones for calls on your computer or WhatsApp etc – for some reason they garble you’re voice and distort the other people’s voices. Sony deny it can be used for video calls or telephone calls on computer or tablet: ‘Only ordinary phone calls are supported. Applications for phone calls on smartphones or personal computers are not supported’ Waste of $$$!

column8: They wouldn't stay in my ear.
column9: After trying all the ear pieces provided, none would grip in my small ear canal. They continually fell out. I swapped them for Air Pods. The Air Pods are much lighter and much more stable in my ear, though, even they don't provide a really tight seal in my ear. Still, I'm really pleased with the Air Pods, and they work great with my Pixel 3 Google/Android phone.

column8: Superb Noise Canceling and Sound Quality..but no water resistant :(
column9: The sound quality on the WF-1000XM3 is amazing, way better that the Airpods Pro in my opinion. NC is great. I wish they were water proof or at least water resistant, but overall I'm very happy with my purchase.

This is the best set of BudBuds I have ever used. I have the Galaxy Buds, the Jabra Elites, none of these come close to the performance, comfort and overall quality of these buds. Unfortunately, I lost the left bud and can't find a replacement.

I just got these in hours ago and so far i am loving them. my only real problem was trying to update them. the update kept canceling itself. the audio itself is wonderful. I can hear static tho when there isn’t anything playing, but when there is something playing you dont hear it at all

Wow!!! ! Wow... terrific......excellent sound quality...excellent battery life... noise cancellation is wonderful....I like it... thank you SONY.. Thank you seller..you are really a trustful seller...recommend it surely snd the seller too...
They are alright but not really android friendly, they disconnect randomly for some reason and wish I would return them but got too busy to make it to the post office

First and foremost I have to give props on the craftsmanship of the case, earbuds and the packaging itself. I wouldn't expect anything less from Sony. Second, the technology built into these in-earbuds are truly spectacular. The sound is superb and surpasses any other buds I currently own. They truly give off an over-the-ear headphones experience. The noise canceling feature is beyond anything that is currently out there for earbuds. I've gotten a good 4-5 hours with continuous playback of videos and with Active Noise Canceling on high but when turned off, you can get 1-2 hours more. The buds themselves are very well held by strong magnets and the cover is well designed that the buds will not fall out if held upside-down. Nicely done Sony. A small length Type-C cable is provided for charging but any decent cable will work. The case itself will give you about 3 charges. And with only a 10 minute charge you can get about 1.5 hours of play. Just open the lid and it will start the Bluetooth pairing for you to find and connect on your device. If you have an Android device with NFC you can just touch them together and voila! You can connect to 2 devices and switch between them. To connect to a 2nd or another device touch both buds for about 7 seconds. They work right away with or without the app (Sony Headphones Connect). But you will be able to do more customized settings with it. They do have a Touch interface so one will control the Ambient Sound/Voice Assistant and the other one Playback. Also if you touch the Ambient side, it will let you hear the outside sound as long as it's being touched. Ambient features works really good. It adjusts your sound according to the level of noises in your surrounding. They do work with Amazon Alexa, Google Assistant and Siri. I've used both Android's assistant but not with Siri yet. They also come with extra different sized ear bud tips for you to find the right size. The Sony Wf-100xm3 headphones are a great purchase. The price is fair and the quality is amazing. I've already ordered a 2nd pair as a gift.

column8: Sony WF-1000XM3 Headphones are a Game Changer!
column9: The first thing you’ll notice is how perfectly contoured and comfortable they are while wearing them. Sometimes I forget I have them in, I’m not exaggerating! The second thing that struck me was their ergonomic design. They are lightweight but durable and sturdy in the hand. The charging case was larger than average but that’s because they’re packing 32 hrs of juice on a single charge of the pack! With my Sony WF-1000XM3’s I’m getting around 7-8 hours of playback at a medium volume. The promised 90 minutes of playback after 10 minutes of charging is a true claim, I was very happy with that! Sound: The Sony Headphones Connect app is available for free on iOS and Android, this app unlocks so many additional features. I was blown away at the level of control you can get if you want it, there is an equalizer that controls the tonality of your music and podcasts. You can achieve warm or bright styles of sound with the tap of a button in the app. Performance: Because of their light weight these headphones simply stay put, they always seem unaffected by my movement. Wireless headphones with 8+ hours of playback runtime are unheard of, but Sony does it somehow. Forget about distractions because these puppies will drown out virtually everything around you, the various noise cancelling options can be changed on the fly using the touch panel on the ear bud, simply tap to cycle through the different default settings and customize them in the app if you’re a control freak like me. Your ears are unique to you, Sony includes 7 pairs of various sized ear bud tips with different material qualities. This vital accessory is always an after-thought so I was happy to see that I had options. The different types of tips also changed the characteristics of the sound in my experimentation, I found the squishy type tips provided a better seal in my ears and improved the treble, bass effect and comfortability. If you’re currently vacillating between different ear buds and the Sony WF-1000XM3, go for the Sony pair. I honestly don’t think you’ll regret your decision after hearing and feeling them in your ears. I’ve purchased many popular “high-end” brands of headphones, I wasted so much time on them before landing on this Sony pair. They were all nice but their fit left very little to be desired. The sound quality is simply phenomenal and the noise cancelling tech is bar none the best I've experienced. My old wireless ear buds feel like kid’s toys compared to these!

Unbelievable sound quality don’t waste your money on Apple. Easy to setup and very comfortable to wear. Apple airbuds look like walrus tusks. Sony buds are compact and good looking and don’t protrude from the ear canal. Highly recommended.

column8: Great for music & noise cancelling, terrible for phone calls
column9: Ordered these to make working from home easier during quarantine - they sound great, and noise cancelling works so well that my wife would get upset anytime I had them in because I could completely ignore the family! Unfortunately, every time that I used these for a call (work & personal), the person on the other end said it sounded like background noise was actually magnified to the point where they could not hear me. Bottom line - it was completely unusable for calls (some subsequent online research reveals that this is a known problem, and despite following instructions to update, repair, etc. I could not fix this issue). Returned them and got Airpod Pros instead - they sound almost as good, and call quality is vastly improved.
Sound sucks , can’t adjust volume from eat piece , they don’t stay in all the time , and for the money Bose are far superior

First off, I was super skeptical when I ordered these as I have never been a fan of ear buds; I have always preferred actual headphones, either wired or Bluetooth. Most ear buds are too heavy, fall out easily, or do not fit correctly and hurt my ears. Not these! They were super lightweight, and came with multiple sizes of ear bud tips, which meant I was able to find a set of tips which fit my ears perfectly, making them comfortable and preventing the ear buds from falling out. I unpacked the WF-1000XM3's and let them charge for about 20 minutes. I was too excited to go longer; I wanted to try them out and see if they were as good as advertised, and I was not disappointed. After downloading the app and making sure they were connected to my phone, I put them in and wore them while taking a walk. The sound was impeccable and after awhile I almost forgot they were in! When I returned home I placed them in the charger and let them fully charge. Lately I use them more days than not, especially with being at home due to the pandemic, and on average, I will get 7-8 hours of use from them before requiring a recharge. I am a student and these are great to use to block out my children when trying to listen to videos for class. I cannot say enough good things about them and encourage you to try a pair; I bet you will love them!

column8: FOR ME THE NOISE CANCELLING ISN'T GOOD ENOUGH
column9: There were a bit clunky, but didn't;'t feel like they'd pop pot. It's he noise canceling feature that I must say isn't impressing me. Not what I expected when I can hear a coworker talking on the phone in the cube next to me and it's to the point where it gets annoying. Maybe if I had music or radio playing it would be better, but I also wanted something I could while mowing the grass, but these just didn't "cut" it.. I may be expecting too much, but for the price, I'm not keeping them.
Hurts the ear wells. Feels loose.

column8: Best Headphones I've ever used, sound quality +
column9: I wanted to try these out since Sony is known for good products. I've had other headphones in the past, so this was something I could compare to. Upon opening the package, I seen the charging container and the ear buds (not in the container). Then taking these out I came across extra ear buds plus the charging cord and manual (which you'll need to get setup). So, first thing is you'll notice the headphones don't sync to anything until you out them in the case to activate, then you can start the sync process once they've been removed. I love how it tells you L or R so you know which is which. Once in you install the app on your phone and follow the prompts. The coolest thing is it you have to take pictures of your ears so it can then get the best listening experience based on your ears. This is something no other headphone has done, so this was intriguing. So, once that's done you can go thru the settings to see what sounds good to you. I loved how you can hear the difference when sitting, walking, in a car and running. The Ambient when in the car was the clearest. I couldn't believe how clear this was and how you can hear others too when they were talking. Now when I was in a room and someone was talking, it was hard to hear them. Once I switched the ambient function off, you could tell a huge difference in hearing background noise and people talking. It's crazy how much of a difference this makes, but just knowing you have those options is even better. Also, you can adjust how much ambient is done by adjusting the bar. So, I tested out the sound with certain music types it literally sounded like I was in a Music Hall. It was amazing. My other headphones don't do that, so this was a pleasant surprise. So, one thing that's a really nice feature is the built in Alexa voice control. I used this to ask what the weather would be like then asked to play certain songs. This is one thing my others didn't have and it's been so convenient. Just to be able to run or go walking and use this function has been a blessing. The battery life on these is by far the best I've ever seen for headphones, 24 hrs! This means you can use them during the day without fear if the battery running down. So, after hearing the difference between normal and the ambient sound, Sony has outdone themselves with these headphones. I love these and I had my boyfriend try them too after I did and he loved them.

column8: Perfect for focusing on the music
column9: I have owned many Sony headphones, from basic earbuds to studio monitors. The WF-1000XM3 has quickly become my favorite given its fantastic sound quality and adjustable noise cancellation. I sought these headphones primarily for music enjoyment, and Sony delivered. I was surprised when I first listened to the WF-1000XM3. Never would I have guessed that wireless earbuds could sound this good. Noise canceling works really well, with even loud noises becoming almost silent. The headphones present a warm, laid-back musical experience with an emphasized, punchy bass-end. It’s a great combination for listening on the go, producing a dynamic sound that doesn’t fatigue the ears. My favorite feature of the WF-1000XM3 is customizable Ambient Sound Control. It’s truly an impressive feat to dial in exactly how much of the outside world I want to hear. Especially useful is being able to activate “focus on voice” when I’m in a noisy place but still need to talk with people nearby. Music listening is where these earbuds shine, but they can handle phone calls when needed. In addition to sounding great, the WF-1000XM3 feels great thanks to the bounty of 14 included earpads in several different sizes and materials. I easily found just the right pair that fits securely in my ears without excess pressure. For iOS and Android devices, Sony’s Headphones Connect app manages the noise control, sound equalizer, and other features of the WF-1000XM3. It may not be flashy, but the app is straightforward and gives quick access to every setting on one scrollable page. Even without its app, the WF-1000XM3 paired easily with other gadgets (and even my PC), offering the same noise-free listening experience for any Bluetooth-enabled device. Overall, the Sony WF-1000XM3 is easy to use, sounds amazing, and offers excellent noise cancellation. Perfect for focusing on the music.

column8: Excellent noise cancellation, good ergonomics, great sound, strong battery life.
column9: Photos show the previous model, WF1000X for comparison. I picked up two sets of these in a recent trip to Tokyo (one black, the other "silver" which is more of a putty color). The noise cancellation is, as one might expect, not quite as powerful as that found on Sony's over-the-ear WH series NC headphones, but it is pretty close- perhaps 85% of the WH capability- but a lot more convenient to have with you at all times. On the busy streets of Tokyo, noise simply disappears- replaced with the "thump" of one's own steps going through your body. Signal strength never wavered- the connection remained rock-solid even in some of the most RF-saturated places on the planet (Shibuya scramble crossing and Shinjuku station, for example) greatly outperforming the previous model. Video sync was excellent on both iPhone and iPad for movies downloaded to the device, but there was slight lag while watching Amazon Prime Video streamed items on my iPad Pro. I got every bit of six hours listening to music from an iPhone on my return flight. The touch controls are a little bit fiddly, they are actually perhaps a little too sensitive (as in, they tend to activate when making minor adjustments to fit, for example). Sound quality is flat and natural, and easily adjusted if desired with the Sony app. It was, subjectively, more detailed than the previous model. The main feature these lack compared to the over-ear models is the altitude correction function on the over ear models isn't available on these. No matter, they were still 80% as effective in NC as the over ear WH models. The case is not a burden in a reasonable pocket. It easily provides three or so recharges. All in all, this is a 9 out of 10 effort. Sony hit it out of the park.

Love over the ear headphones but these cancel noise better than my Sony WH-CH700N Over ear headphones and they are super comfy. The amount of different ear size adapters is fantastic. The case is great to charge them in and the fact they connect just by taking them out of the case makes it super easy to use. Pros: Easy to connect Battery life is 6 1/2 hours out of case super snug great Noise cancelling cons: no buttons can accidently turn off noise cancelling while trying to put in ear.

column8: Sound quality among the best. Noise canceling - Fantastic. Pairing with a PC - nightmare
column9: I want to love these. I want to hate these. I've spent the last 10 hours with them going back and forth between using them with a phone and trying to get them to work properly on my laptop paired with an intel AC9560 wireless card (BT 5.0). The major pros of these head phones are the sound quality when they are used properly. Listening to them with my iphone xs max has produced a quality experience I was lacking when I solely used my apple airpods. The noise isolation and ambient inclusion features are done well, by in large, tho some latency between activing and de-activating these does leave one to want to change it on off less and less. My biggest issue has been using them with a non-mobile device. Windows will not allow you to disable the microphone. The microphone stays hot the entire time its connecting to a laptop making the audio quality drop to 92kbps (tape quality). Not to mention the ambient noise that floods in from the hot mic. I went through every ounce of possible troubleshooting, even turning off the headset and microphone services. None of this works, it's simply not compatible with a windows PC. Mac users, rest better assured that you are able to turn off the mic independently and get your audio quality back, however, it seems that on mac once you do this, you are very limited by the amount of volume they put out. Something to know that has not been covered by any mainstream reviews. Connection to the iphone has been flawless and effortless. It paired immediately, and connects disconnects upon entrance and exit from the large charging case. The video latency is still an issue with iphones. This is more noticable if you are streaming any service. If you watch downloaded movies / music videos on the native player for iOS, it seems that it is, at the very least, compensated for and has less to now lag - no perceivable lag that is). All in all, I'm going to do some more testing to see how to bypass this microphone issue on windows. However, if it turns out to be a driver conflict issue with the bluetooth chipset used by the headphones, they will have to go back.

If you a Bose earbuds user, you might dislike the fitness and comfort of this industry leading earphones on your ears. I might have to return this due to the comfort issue. 30 minutes of use will hurt your ears for sure. Otherwise, this is the dream earphones so far. As a tech fan, this is the dream Bluetooth. Noise canceling is better than BoseQC25. Sound quality is way better than other competition. No lagging sounds using an IOS device.

column8: Great sound quality & noise isolation, solid Bluetooth connection
column9: PROS + really excellent sound quality that rivals wired over-ear headphones and far surpasses all but the most expensive truly wireless earphones + 6 to 8 hours of battery life depending on settings, most others have 3 to 5 hours + with the included charging case, 24 or more hours battery life + excellent noise cancellation, works about as good as over-ear Bose QC headphones + has "ambient sound mode" to let sounds in if you need to + app lets you tweak the amount of noise cancellation + app lets you customize EQ + rock-solid bluetooth connection + can connect to and remember many devices + very good build quality, both case and earphones + other truly wireless earbuds that purport to have near-audiophile quality cost $300 or more and offer crap battery life. These are $230 and have much better battery life. CONS - not rated as waterproof or sweat proof - charging case is a little bigger than other models - every time you open the app, it needs 3 seconds to connect to the earphones, even if you just left the app for a short time to read a quick text message. (It's just the app that needs to reconnect to the earphones; your phone or iPad or other device maintains a solid connection) MEH . comfortable enough, but not as comfortable as the Bose SoundSport earphones . stable enough most of the time, but once in a while I have to adjust the position of one of the earbuds I own these (bought at Best Buy who had stock before Amazon did). I own (or have recently owned) a variety of other wireless headphones, including over-ear models with noise cancellation from Bose, Sony, and Sennheiser, and ear-bud style ones from Bose.

I got these to compare to my apple air pods - I had wanted a pair of bose headphones prior to buying the air pods but eventually settled on apple and never looked back. I think that I expected these to be subpar - but WOW are they amazing. I actually cant wait to use these on my next flight for the noise cancelling capabilities! They are SO flattering (case and all) and the sound quality and noise level is really amazing. They are a bit large which is tough for people with tiny ears (me, hi). But all around - a great head phone. Pros: flattering, noise level is really high, noise cancelling quality is amazing, quality of headphones themselves are really great. Cons: price point, bulky (case and ear buds).

column8: Not the Best In This Segment
column9: Sony is aiming for the higher end of the market with these wireless earbuds. So what am I going to do? Compare them to a pair sub $100, Bluetooth headphones. Any set of earbuds at this price should crush earbuds that cost less than half. Which ones will I be comparing? Skullcandy Push https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B07N2B3HRP OnePlus Wireless Bullets 2 (only available from OnePlus) Hopefully comparing these three will expose areas where you get more or less for your money. 1 – SOUND SONY – Excellent sound. Some of the best I’ve heard. It’s accurate. Skullcandy – Great sound. They are very dynamic. Not as accurate, but they impress. OnePlus – Great sound. They cheat though. If you own a newer OnePlus phone, there is a setting for these specific earbuds. They truly optimized these to an extreme degree. Others phones will get this experience. WINNER – By a small margin – SONY 2 – FUNCTIONALITY SONY – They do a bunch of stuff. They have a half baked “ambient” mode. It’s half baked because all it does is let you hear some things in the background. You still can’t really carry on a conversation without taking the buds out. They are the only of the three that has active noise cancelling. It’s not just ANC – it’s ANC so good I’ve never seen this quality in earbuds. I’ve seen it in over the ear, but never in something this compact. These use touch (not button) controls. They automatically shut off if take one out, and start again when you put it back in. One MASSIVE thing missing – there is no option to control volume via the touch interface. You have three options for each ear bud. They can be – Controls – ANC / Ambient – or Google Assistant. How is volume missing there? How is that not an option? I think it’s safe to say that just about everyone changes the volume more often than use assistant. Both of these earbuds connects via Bluetooth. I mention that because most wireless ones connect one and then beam one to the other. Skullcandy – No ANC, but these have a tight fit, which reduces noise. They have a button on each ear. Using combos of pushes, you can skip forward and back, trigger assistant, pause / play, and change the volume. Only one ear does calls, which is a little annoying, but not a deal breaker. OnePlus – You can volume up, volume down, play / pause, trigger assistant, but – you can only skip ahead. I don’t understand that. These also have a bizarre power system that you’ll love or HATE. There is no power button. The two earbuds are magnets. If they are connected, they are off. If they are apart, they are on. This causes issues when traveling. They can easily pull apart and connect your phone. WINNER – By a slim margin – SONY – they could have crushed this one, but no volume controls is a really dumb thing to leave out. BATTERY LIFE SONY – Six hours, if you don’t use some features. Then you can put them into the case to charge up. The case will charge them a few times, so SONY claims 24hrs. Skullcandy – Pretty much the same as SONY. OnePlus – 16hrs. Straight up. WINNER – OnePlus. DESIGN and COMFORT SONY – They give you six different tips you can try. I played around with them and ended up with the default. I can’t really call them comfortable, but they are not uncomfortable either. They are more bulky than I’d like. They point forward when you are wearing them. They feel pretty solid. They fit a little loose. There is no hook or good form to keep them in your ears. I have not had them fall out yet. Skullcandy – Very comfortable. Possibly the most comfortable earbuds I’ve every used. They use a little hook that makes them feel solid in your ear. This is something SONY should have thought about doing. They are a decent build, but it’s all plastic and they do not feel as solid as the SONY ones. They point up when they are in your ear. OnePlus – No hooks to secure them. They feel okay. Better than the SONY but not as good as the Skullcandy. Like the others they give you a bunch of tips to try. These are a more solid build than the Skullcandy, and they are formed to fit into your ear a lot better than the others. The big drawback here is the wire. The two ear buds are connected by a wire. This is how they get their amazing battery life and it you will never worry about losing one. If you want truly wireless, you’ll want to skip these. Where these look more like conventional earbuds, they have less of a d-bag factor. People who always have BT headsets in their ear have earned that rep over the years. WINNER – Skullcandy. SONY could have won it, but they didn’t do enough to separate themselves. You don’t gain anything here by paying more. I can’t say OnePlus lost here, they are just different. CASE SONY – The case is bigger than you’d expect. Once the earbuds are in there, they are not really easy to get out. Skullcandy – Smaller case, easier to get the buds out. It’s still too big for my liking. It’s much bigger than Apple’s case. OnePlus – Dear OnePlus team who created this case – YOU SUCK! This is god awful, steaming pile of poo, case. It’s a silicone oval with a magnet to close it. It’s not easy to cram everything in there and then, most of the time the earbuds come apart. WINNER – Skullcandy – not much of a win here. It’s a very low bar between these three. VALUE SONY – Let me put it this way – You gain ambient mode and ANC. You lose volume controls. You pay nearly 3X more. No water proofing for that extra either. Skullcandy – Both OnePlus and SONY offer better sound. It doesn’t win many categories, but it doesn’t really fail in any. They are also the cheapest of the three and, unlike OnePlus, they are truly wireless. OnePlus – Ten dollars more than the Skullcandy. They have much better batter life, but are not really wireless. WINNER – Skullcandy. VERDICT If ambient sound and ANC are a must have for you, and cost is not really a factor – buy these. If you are concerned about getting the most bang for your buck – buy the Skullcandy. If you own a OnePlus phone and don’t mind (or actually appreciate) the wire – buy the OnePlus. OVERALL In the end it’s really hard to recommend these earbuds. If the case was smaller, they had volume controls, and they were more comfortable, I’d recommend them. The problem with this price point is pretty simple. People are expecting the best. You need to be the best. You can’t make mistakes. Sure these are coming in lower than their rivals in the high end market, but the lower tiers offer a far better value. If I’m willing to pay for earbuds at this price point, I’m going to buy the best. These are not the best in this category. UPDATE #1 11/26/19 A huge update was released. You can now control the volume on the headset, Alexa, was added and more. One full star bump up for this. Some of the most annoying issues have been addressed. UPDATE #2 12/4/19 I've had some time to really work through the recent update. I'm convinced that Sony is just an update away from being the hands down winner in the high end segment. Right now they are not because their controls are awkward. Want to turn up the volume? Single tap the ear you mapped in the app. Want to turn it down? If you've used other earbuds like this, you'd be tempted to double tap. Not Sony. You have to hold your finger on there. It's awkward and inaccurate. Right now you are stuck making one sacrifice or another. You have to pick two out of the four functions (track nav, profile, volume, and assistant) to use. The others cannot be used. It would be a very simple matter to have them all available. If Sony were to program the following, these would be killer. Ear 1 Volume up = 1 tap Volume down = 2 tap Assistant = Hold Ear 2 Skip ahead - 1 tap Skip back = 2 tap Switch profile - hold If they release something like that, I'd be willing to give these 5 stars. Side Note: Sony also updated these with a 360 Sound option, that scans your ear and gives you HD audio. Only catch is it's only useful for three (at the time of this writing) rather expensive, subscription music apps. Beyond those it does nothing.

column8: The best bluetooth buds I've used yet. Some quirky things I think they can fix.
column9: We are in the age of no headphone jacks on phones. It sucks, but these are the second pair of earbuds I've put in my ears and said "I can live without a headphone jack." The sound quality is really good. The buds are suprisingly comfortable. Like all ear buds they take some getting used too. The noise cancelling isn't the best. But it's good for ear buds. If you are expecting to use them in an extremely loud environment probably stick with overears. The software is a little wonky. The only other buds that have compared sound wise are the sennheriser ones. I returned those due to not being able to listen to one at a time. A huge deal breaker for me. I almost thought you couldn't do it with these either. When I would put one back in the case both would turn off. Now it works though, I didn't do anything other than try it a bunch of times, I guess the software figured it out. The sound without EQ is decent. As far as EQ, I didn't really like any of the presets as a set and forget it. The "excited" preset is good for podcast but adds too much noise for music. Bass boost is fun, Sony's "clear bass" setting is really nice. I would encourage use of the manual EQ, turn the clear bass up to desired sound, turn down the 1k setting a few notches, leave 400 and 2.5k where they are and raise the 6.3 and 15.6 k to what sounds good.

column8: Best wireless headphones! Noise canceling optional
column9: I’ve purchased many (expensive) wireless headphones over time, as I listen to audiobooks nonstop. These are my favorite pair I’ve tried. They are slightly larger than earbuds and have a soft changeable silicone tip of various sizes (very similar ear tip to bose headphones). You have to play Goldilocks and find what tips work for you as far as the ear part for what fits best out of ones they give you. The case is larger than earbuds (about double the size). Theres a round button on each ear that works in single tap, double tap, triple tap, tap and hold on either R or L headphone for different functions. Examples of these functions are noise canceling on, ambient noise, pause, play, fast forward, rewind, call answering, and a few more. This is useful if you want to do stuff just by touching ear and not finding phone in purse or walking back to it on a charger. I did accidentally pause things when fiddling with my ear and hair more than once but just need to get used to this feature I think. There’s an option in a Sony headphones app to turn on or off the feature that the headphones will stop automatically when you take them out. There’s a helpful one page quick start directions w pictures that just sort of tells you how to charge them in its case then pair them to your iPhone. I’m NOT the tech savvy one in the house who does computer setups, but I was able to set these all up by myself with no help. The case and the headphones themself have lights on them that I’m still figuring the colors etc out. When you drop one on floor it lights up blue so you can see where you dropped it. The noise canceling worked to drown out all the ambient noise around me (dishwasher, lawnmower, distant television, etc) but it didn’t work on voices of anyone talking near me. I think that means they aren’t AS noise canceling as the over ear headphones one might use on a flight, but these are so much more compact. I LOVE that the noise canceling is optional and just a tap turns it off and on. There’s so many times you don’t want the noise canceling (crossing street, when watching kids, in a dark parking lot, when you think somebody is talking about you at work, etc) so it’s great to pick and choose when to use it. The battery life is amazing. I was listening for hours and didn’t need to charge them. You get a few charges out of the case once it’s charged too. They give you a cord that has a usb end to charge them up so you will need a wall plug to usb to charge them or a usb outlet somewhere. My ONLY complaint is this charging cord is soooo comically short (about the size of my hand) that even plugged into a kitchen counter outlet it just hangs there bc it’s too short to sit on the kitchen counter. Had to move books over to boost it up to sit on while it charges. That’s such a minor personal peeve that I’m still rating it 5 stars. Very pleased and highly recommend.

I was excited about this product. I love listening to music and with these cordless ear buds it made it easy. The sound quality was great and I liked the different sized ear cushions. The battery life is also a plus I felt the design of the product was a little off but the stayed in my ears well.

Pre-ordered prior to release- couldn't wait to get one. And now I can't wait to return it. Design wise they're gorgeous. If you're sitting still and right next to your phone, the sound quality is beautiful. But that's about it. A test at the gym (don't dare to sweat though, because they're not sweat / water resistant) summed it up. Virtually nothing north of mid-bass or maybe 600Hz felt like it was being reduced at all. That's wildly different than my 2 year old Bose (wired) in-the-ear noise canceling earphones and it's lightyears away from Sony's own over-the-ear models. In those models, flip the noise canceling switch and your ears experience that awesome altered state where the sound pressure changes and the outside world fades. Not here. At this price, they barely performed better than my TRANYA $40 set of in-ear earplugs I usually use at the gym (passive noise canceling from plugs only). The $40 Tranyas are sweat proof too, much lighter, have a smaller case, smaller form factor and longer battery life. Pairing it with an iPhone wasn't fool-proof. Sometimes it paired and sometimes it didn't, requiring me to select it on the iPhone or turn it on / off or put it in/out of the case. Sound quality is gorgeous, especially if you select sound quality vs. connectivity (set through the app). I did that, but in a basic gym workout of doing squats with my phone in a side pocket, the signal would cut out or one ear would stop working. I couldn't believe it. I tried using it as a way to meditate while others were in the room- it really doesn't cut the voice frequencies out in a pleasurable way. The rest of the features (like activating ambient sounds) are forgettable if the primary function is mediocre. So they're going back just 3 days after I got them. It's all hype I think. Yeah some people will buy them because the DO look cool and why not. But performance-wise, the don't come anywhere near my wired noise canceling Bose, and for wireless, at $229 they don't offer enough to compete with my tiny, water-resistant Tranyas. The Sony gets tiring to wear, the Tranya does not. I wish this was one of those "I liked the product so much, I bought the company!" reviews but instead it's "Oh wow this thing is gorgeous but doesn't deliver in the least and is going back." Sad.

column8: Great earbuds but comically large case lacks basic ergonomics...
column9: Big is not always better, and in the case of the case for your earbuds, it's definitely not. My first thought when I saw the case was "seriously?" These are not clown-show big, but definitely in the "holy cow" range. I have a pair of inexpensive truly cordless earbuds, and the case is about twice as large, and these are also about twice as large as the Apple Airpod case. The next annoyance is that the case is rounded on the bottom. I like being able to put the case on a flat surface then take the ear buds out simultaneously and plonk them in. No can do with the rounded bottom unless I balance it against a vertical surface. Finally, getting these out is tricky. It's not like I have big "Andre the Giant" sausage fingers. I'm a guy with smaller hands and I still have a hard time getting these out. OK, so enough with the case issues. The earbuds are FANTASTIC! Sound quality, particularly bass, is significantly better than the other 6 pairs of true wireless earbuds I've tested. The controls are easy and intuitive. Comfort is excellent, mainly beacuse they have 4 sizes of silicone tips and another 3 comfort foam tips. The comfort foam seal sound better but actually don't seem as comfortable as the silicone. Size isn't bad and the silver color is fairly discreet, compared to even ear-commas (airbuds) Sound isolation as a result is excellent. Active noise cancellation is so-so, compared to full-size bluetooth noise cancelling headphones, but then again, power consumption and noise processing is probably size and power limited, and the overall combined effect is comparable to ANC headphones, though earbuds being what they are, without the size or the long-term comfort of headphones. There are 3 sound modes - ANC,, Ambient Sound and Ambient Sound Control Off. - with Ambient Sound you can still hear everything well, just with your music overlaid. With ,ASC off, you get ~20% longer battery life. Earbud controls takes a few tries to get used to the.touch-sensitive pads. It's easiest to use your middle finger to tell where the front of the bud is before using your index finger to control. Pairing was simple - NFC is enabled on the case, though I ended up just pairing normally and then loading the app. No issues, Battery life is impressive. Take them out for a few minutes and you're back to nearly full. I've been using them about 5-6 hours a day for the past 4 days and have never fallen below 50%.

column8: Amazing sound quality... no seriously... mind blowing.
column9: I have IQbuds and Bose Hearphones, so a bit of experience with high end noise cancelling headphones. The sound quality of these playing on my phone is astonishing. First time I've had an ear bud that could do serious staging and bass! Not shake your body bass obviously, but it is beautifully reproduced. Let my son try them out and he was blown away. The noise cancelling is as good as my Bose Hearphones, maybe better than my IQbuds. Connection is way better than the IQbuds along with the sound quality. As a noise cancelling ear bud Sony has concentrated on that rather than the tricks of hearing enhancement my other earphones have like directional concentration and environmental aware noise reduction. Only downside I can say is that first time I tried them out was on my Win10 desktop computer... sounded AWESOME! That night my computer did a major windows update and now they are not recognized as headphones, just as a voice headset and the sound quality and connection is horrible. I tried everything I could find to fix that, it is NOT a Sony problem, it's freaking Windows. On my phones it works great although for some reason I could not get the app to load on a borrowed Iphone5. I wore these for hours at a time and NO discomfort. But the warning is that these are NOT waterproof in any way. If you have the money and sound quality is what you are looking for with the ability to block out everyone around you really well without big bulky headphones or a bar around your neck... hit the Buy Now button. Let my son's friend try these with his Android to see if he had any connectivity issues... connected right up and the app instantly knew they were on and took control. App works well. Reason I mention him is that while listening his mouth kept dropping open and he was mumbling "Oh Wow..." "Oh Wow..." and let me know he could not hear anything outside of the earphones with the ambient sounds off and noise cancelling on. With the app allowing conversation he could hear me perfectly well. Then he loaded up some serious bass and could not disturb them and was as impressed as I was. Followed up with a clip designed to demonstrate 3d sound called "Virtual Barbershop" and he was just astounded as he listened. I did not know what he was listening to until he handed them back to me and I listened to the clip... HOLY SH#&! There is a guy playing a guitar off to your left and a bit behind you that you'd swear was coming from the tv in the other room... the stereo imagining was perfect as a guy 'walks' around you trimming with clippers and scissors. You can almost feel the clippers against your neck. Added this to the review as these are a bit mindblowing.

column8: Software Can't Keep Up With Hardware
column9: Sony's new Noise Canceling WF-1000XM3 excels in gorgeous product design and hardware, but falls flat with their software counterpart. Upon first use, I was in love with the matte texture of the case and minimal earbuds, however, over the course of the next week, a lot of the faults within Sony's software became too large to ignore. The biggest issue is the bluetooth pairing. Coming from Apple's AirPods which paired magically every time, Sony's WF-1000XM3 would take a good 15 secs to connect via it's own app. With most of the physical controls missing from the earbuds, you're forced to use the app to adjust anything and over the course of a week, I realized how much of a burden this became. 15 secs might not seem that long, but try just staring at the black screen of your phone and count to 15 secs and you'll see what I mean. The second biggest issue is that the each of the earbuds would connect to different devices! I had left earbud connect to my iPhone and my right to my MacBook. I basically had to factory reset the 1000XM3 (which is not very obvious) to over come this issue. All-in-all, Sony really needs to step up their software game before shipping a product like this out the door. I'm sure Sony will eventually push out firmware updates, but my Bose headphones and my AirPods never encountered these kinds of issues because the software was very polished from day 1. I really wanted to like these headphones, but unfortunately, I will have to return them.

Overall, these are pretty cool earbuds. Love the wireless function. I will never not enjoy a wireless device. Totally eliminates the need to have my phone on my person, which is awesome. The app that you must download for this is very handy, gives you a full overview of the battery life, what audio is playing, the connection and different audio settings. You can adjust the quality of audio depending on your preference, including the noise cancelling options. It's also nice that I don't have to worry about turning them on and off myself. They're pretty smart, and they know when they're in your ears, and when they're taken out. Put them back in the case when you're done, and they maintain a charge for days on end. The battery life is pretty fantastic. They also come with several different types of domes for the buds that are inserted in your ears, to make it easier to choose your own level of comfort. Now, for the cons. I really wanted to love these, but there's just a few too many inconveniences to make these my favorite set. One, they're supposedly not waterproof or resistant? A pretty dangerous combination for completely wireless earbuds. I have cheaper "wireless" buds that, while not as fancy, at least are sensibly designed to be resistant to water and moisture. That is a concern for me. Another thing, the instructions were not exactly dummy-proof. There are still functions I'm not certain of, nor even how exactly to control the volume without the app. They're very sensitive to touch, yet I couldn't for the life of me figure out where the "volume button" would be on these. Lastly, I took these to the gym at work today, which has no service, mistakenly assuming these would connect to my phone or the excercise machines regardless, like my cheaper pair. Imagine my annoyance when I couldn't get them to connect, or even show up! So I had a music-less, audio-less workout today, begrudging my decision to bring these with me. So, as you can see, pros and cons. A neat toy, but not perfect. There are plenty of cheaper and sturdier options online. These are probably nice for people that enjoy smart tech, but if they don't give me exactly what I need, I don't really care how cool the app or touch-sensitive siding is. Just okay, for me.

column8: My husband and I fight over these!
column9: The sound quality of these earbuds is the best I've ever heard and the noise canceling is pretty good too. The first time I used them, all I could think was "Wow"! My husband paired them with his ipad easily but I had a little trouble pairing them with my iphone until I downloaded their app. Then it paired easily. They give you plenty of choices of cushions in an attractive case, too. My husband uses wired headphones all the time, and until now I really haven't used headphones much at all, but now we find each other wanting to use these at the same time! The sound is just so good I get lost in listening to music with these. We both highly recommend them!

column8: Microphone for calls I'm told doesn't sound good
column9: First day. I have had two of my friends comment on the poor sound quality of my voice when making calls. With one person I hung up and tried my Airpods and he said it sounded much better. Otherwise the noise cancelling is pretty good and sound good too. But I did notice on calls the reception was cutting in and out, when my Airpods were a bit more steady. But if my voice is no good for anyone I am talking to, that is not good. I will revisit this review in a few days.

First off, these sound great. How great? This is maybe all you need to know. With other sub-$100 wireless earphones I've used (about a half-dozen or so), I can not tell the difference between a 128K and a 256K AAC stream from my iPhone 8. With these I can clearly hear a difference between those, so I'm storing less music at the higher bit rate on my phone. I haven't listened to a few different things to make an assessment. Music I was very familiar with. Peter Gabriel's "So", Steely Dan's "Aja", Grace Jones' "Slave to the Rhythm", Pink Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" and Bruce Springsteen's very magical new album "Western Stars." I also checked out a couple big loud superhero movies. I'll likely not use these for movies, as I don't like watching movies on my phone, but they work well for that, too. They can be a teeny bit finicky to set up...but this is a GOOD thing, because you have control over these that you don't have with others, thanks to Sony's app. Know that the "Clear Bass feature" needs to be turned up (to about +6db imho) to sound right for rock or pop music (leave the rest of the EQ alone). Also, imho, for best listening, turn off adaptive sound control and turn on ambient sound control, leaving noise canceling ALL THE WAY OFF. Also, mind-bogglingly, when my app updated, it reset a few of my controls so I had to go in and change them again. VERY minor annoyance. Finally, experiment with the very generous array of ear buds that they give you. Finding just the right pair (they might be different for your two ears, btw) is key to getting the sound right. I find them comfortable to wear for a longer period of time. The charging case is a little big for a pocket, and the actual units are bigger than you might guess from the photos, but you get a full array of ear buds that will probably fit any ear you can imagine. So, why not 5 stars??? Simply put, I can't give 5 * only because of the price. In fact, normally I would only give them 3 when they are this expensive... but I have to give them 4* because they are so amazing sounding (once you get them set up). This is too much money for most people to spend on something like this. If you are the person for whom it is not, you will love these. As you may notice, I got my set free, and personally would not likely have spent my own money on it. This means when I'm going out somewhere, I might find myself carrying my cheaper set, afraid that I might lose these somehow!

column8: Brilliant sound but precarious fit and absolutely zero noise cancellation
column9: The "noise cancellation" was so bad that I returned the first set I received, thinking it was defective. The replacement had the exact same problem: the 3 levels of noise cancellation are exactly the same: No noise cancellation whatsoever. Not that it matters much, since all 3 levels are the same... but when you tap the left earpiece to change levels, it occasionally announces which setting you have chosen, but 9 times out of 10 it simply beeps and changes nothing. I wanted wireless, noise-canceling earphones to dampen traffic noise when I walk along the street. My Bose, over-ear phones are wonderful for both sound and noise dampening, but they are awkward and hot in the summer. I also have Bose, in-ear phones that are wonderful for noise canceling, but the cord and control switch leave much to be desired. I pre-ordered the Sony WF-1000XM3 based on "expert" reviews that made them sound like the perfect solution. As you can see, I was disappointed. Regardless of the size of the earpiece tip selected, the shape and weight of the units make me feel they might easily fall out while I am walking. The iPhone app is very smart and useful and the "tap the earpiece" functions to skip or replay songs work fine, but, unlike my Bose units, there is no built-in volume control, so I have to pull out my phone whenever I need to change the volume. Also, callers complain about ambient noise from the Sony microphone, unlike their experience when they call me on my Bose headsets. Bottom line: I am still waiting for the ideal, wireless, noise-canceling, in-ear phones.
Wasn't too sure an earbud could provide noise cancelling but these are great. It's not 100% noise cancelling but almost.

column8: Lived up to the hype and reviews.
column9: I assume if you're about to drop $200+ on buds you've been doing a lot of research. So I'll jump in with my experience and then comment on some of the common pro/con talking points and add some of my individual experiences. PROS -Sound! These are top notch (as advertised), I'm a basshead and the bass on these is a nice deep rolling bass that hits at all ranges with a nice punch at the proper frequency! The bass doesn't feel ear damaging like I've experienced on others that just play loud...Bass is very crisp/clear/on point. Sony's EQ app does a great job for personal preference. -These buds are surprisingly comfortable for me. I usually struggle with buds staying put but these fit perfect, after a bit I forget the are even in. They aren't heavy, seat close to my head and don't stick out too much. -"Silver" color is more of a matte/dull light grey. Attractive and Sony branding is classy/subtle. -Case is a nice matte finish and houses them perfectly. I see ppl complain about the size but it's about the size of those XL tic tac cases and holds 3x charge. A little bulky but not cumbersome in pocket. -Technology...Noise cancellation is amazing for earbuds! Better than my Bose over ears. And I love the long press to allow ambient noise in for conversation or w/e (music continues to play at very low volume). Everything stops if you take a bud out and reads power level to you when placed in ear! Sony's headphone app is a must for customization and sound control. I found "EXCITE" to be my favorite EQ setting. Buds blink blue when out of ear, great for locating them when set down, they DO NOT blink while in ear. -Battery life is great so far. Just as others have mentioned. -Connectivity is very fast and easy. -Handsfree calling is nice. When asked, people said I sounded clearer than when just on phone (I tend to mumble away from the mic) CONS -No hands free volume control. Even via google assistant, I tell her to lower volume and she tells me it was done but volume remains the same. I did not take away any stars b/c this is common for earbuds, just hoped Sony added this to their groundbreaking tech. -No Qi charging...I common complaint, bu I honestly don't see a big deal since I have both Qi and usb-c chargers throughout my house. -No charge level indication of case, only full or not. Would be nice if at least 4 LEDs to indicate battery level. -Touch pads are seated back further than ear hole, takes some getting used to to tap further back to use commands. -Sony isn't clear about their level of water/sweat proofing. -In Sony's Headphone app, when you scroll through the EQ settings- it stops/switches sound at each setting. Hopefully w/ and update you can scroll to which setting you want and press to switch to it. -Price. A little pricey but you get what you pay for. OVERALL These are my new go to's for sound! They are not cheap but if you are in the market for high-end buds, IMO the best out there. Their noise cancelling and sound are top notch, comfort level is the best I've experienced. You get a great daily bud that can serve as an airplane/transportation noise cancelling...The only question mark is for working out, I am comfortable in doing so as I am not a super sweaty guy. Even mowing the lawn was fine with these (although I purposely tried to avoid touching them with sweaty/dirty hands). But if working out was your main use for an earbud, you are most likely better off with something more waterproof, durable and maybe over the ear hooks.

column8: Can't get to pair with win 10 computer correctly, earbud will not stay in right ear...
column9: Update: Sony released a firmware update; however, some people report if fixed the issue and others have reported it has NOT. I can't say as I returned mine; I do find it interesting that This product can NO LONGER BE PURCHASED at most retailers. It suggests to me that Sony has a big issue here and they don't know if they can fix it without a design change (hence the stopping selling), they are probably working on a product update right now and will quietly replace people's terrible bluetooth devices. Now, if they just do that WITHOUT dealing with the fit in the ear then they would be wasting their time. Both issues need to resolved or these earbuds are worthless. I loved them when they worked and didn't fallout and would love if Sony could fix both issues. We will see. I can get VOICE mode to pair; however, not matter what I try, I can't get the audio to play sound paired in bluetooth mode. I hope these are just a small issue and that another pair can work correctly. found that it is non intel chipset have bluetooth connectivity issues with these earbuds. When I first called Sony said they didn't know anything about it. Instead of trying to understand the issue they simply stated since they didn't know about it, they had NO PLANS TO FIX IT... If you have a windows 10 computer that is NON Intel chipset I would NOT buy these!!! Update: I have found that my left ear holds the earbuds well; however, no matter what cushion I put on. I cannot get the right ear to sit correctly. After a few minutes the right earbud falls out of ear (that is with normal movements, NO vigorous shaking, etc...) That is with the BEST piece I could find. The inability to stay in ear makes these worthless for walking around, not even to mention doing anything 1/2 way rigorous. If I can't find a solution, they will have to be returned.

WOW! I had to capitalize that word... because the sound is unbelieveably good for such a small package. The noise cancellation is superb. Now I can really drown out the city sounds. Everything is first rate with this system.

column8: Great Noise Cancelling; Easy to set up
column9: I watch TV on my outdoor porch and these are great. The noise cancellation is excellent. They set up with my LG tv with ease. (far easier than my air pods)

The two most important and best consumer electronics companies are Apple and SONY. They produce, overall, the best and most well-thought out products. In this case, SONY has hit an out of the park home run with these earbuds. They are exceptional in every respect and a true game changer. Incredible sound quality coupled with noise reduction almost on a par with over the ear headphones make these a steal at $230. Build quality is at the same level as with everything that SONY makes, which is to say absolutely first rate. Ease of use is amazing, and the app that couples with the earbuds is about as well designed as possible. To sum up, these are probably the best earbuds that can be purchased at any price. Fantastic.

column8: No Noise Cancellation and Tiney Sound
column9: I really want to like these. I've been using the Sony WH-1000XM3 noise cancelling headsets for lots of airplane travel and they sound great with fantastic noise cancelling. I wanted something more travel friendly (smaller package). These earbuds sound very Tiney no matter what equalizer or ambient settings I use. Also the volume max level is not as high as the headsets. Maybe these are defective but there is NO noise cancelling on the airplane. I can even hear the guy next to me tapping on his laptop keyboard while I have music playing at Max volume. Ugh. Pros: - small for travel Cons: - Tiney sound - no noise cancellation - low volume Darn, I'll have to return

I live in a fairly small apartment and it's hard to watch TV at night (my primary time of entertainment) without the risk of disturbing others. These wireless earbuds provide excellent sound quality and noise cancellation with absolutely no signal drop! I use these with my Fire TV Cube and it feels like I'm sitting inside a movie theater. You can adjust the sound settings through the Sony Headphones Connect app. I always like to add extra bass.

column8: The Best Totally Wireless Earphones you can buy today
column9: I've been a fan of totally wireless earphones, but found myself always going back to traditional Bluetooth earphones due to issues such as audio/video sync, sound quality, poor fit, or (lack of) features. I own a number of Sony earphones and headphones, many of which have active noise cancellation. I think Sony does not get enough credit for their noise cancellation and how well it works. The moment I unboxed the WF-1000XM3, I was anxious compare it to my current favorite, the Beats Powersbeats Pro. The Powerbeats Pro actually fit my ears (unlike Apple AirPods), are fully in sync with video on iPhone, and admittedly I like the sound signature. For comparison, I also have the Bose SoundSport Free, and while they also fit and I enjoy the sound, audio/video sync has gotten better but still is not perfect (the YouTube app on iOS is a prime example). So, I charged up the WF-1000XM3 and gave them a whirl. First off, as is usual of Sony they include multiple size eartips in two different sets; both in Hybrid Silicone and Triple Comfort forms. Getting a good seal is extremely important for earbuds and I appreciate all the options. Connecting them to iPhone was uneventful, especially since I'm already familiar with the Sony Headphoens Connect app. One oddity is that it always takes a few seconds for the app to connect to the earphones, even while actively using them. With the app, you can adjust the level of noise cancellation, view battery level, and adjust sound equalization and/or Clear Bass settings. Each earbud has a single touch-sensitive button that can be used to play/pause music, or switch between noise cancellation settings. How do they sound? Great! I really enjoy the sound signature of these; to me they're comparable to the PowerBeats Pro if not slightly better in overall quality. For me, the fit is actually more comfortable long-term, and audio/video sync is perfect, even in the iOS YouTube app. Battery level is reported to iOS so you can see it in the Sony app, or in iOS itself including the Batteries widget. The noise cancellation works great; I will retire my Sony Wi-1000X for airplane use and see myself using these more than my PowerBeats Pro as well, if for nothing else, the smaller battery/stroage case. The only improvements I could see would be to have some sort of IP certification, and to add aptX and LDAC support for the best possible sound on Android. Perhaps the XM4 will address that gap, but don't hesitate to get these as they are truly the best totally wireless earphones you can buy today.

column8: Sony excels at sound quality, but can’t get the basic things right.
column9: Touch control breaks down every now and then, and requires force restart of the headphone; iOS app disconnects automatically and requires reconnect every time you listen; EarPods auto turns on even though I am not wearing it, draining the entire day’s battery. I never had to go through these problems with AirPods.

column8: Another level of sound!!! Very happy!!
column9: Sound is great, noise cancelling functionality works well. So far happy.
Very good wireless earphone, unfortunately left era piece out of order, well undate the review after the repalcement arrive

As a tech YouTube reviewer, I have to be completely honest. These headphones were great for like 2 days. After that, my left earbud kept saying. I would do a hard reset, it would start working again but then a day after it stops. I had A LOT of latency issues, and I had to repair my headphones SO MANY TIMES especially if I'm switching to another device. The last issue I had that I couldn't fix was the volume level. The sound level were so low even when my volume was at max. This part got really annoying because I was hearing my surroundings more than the music itself! When I first tried these on, they sounded perfect but after testing firna few days, it gave too many problems. I contacted sony about this, but they were no help.
Poor fit, but it's good in sound quality.

Had these a few days now. What other companies tried to do Sony did with these wireless earbuds. I have the Sony headphones which are the best of the best right now but wanted something smaller for my commute into the city. I have tried all sorts of noise cancelling earbuds and hands down these are the best. Noise cancelling, sound, and comfort are too notch. They beat Bose any day. My only complaint is the wind noise. When it's windy that's all you hear but I just read there's a setting for that so going to give it a try. All and all they are worth every penny.

column8: Waited long after pre-prder, got disappointed
column9: Perhaps I received a defective product, but I couldn’t notice any difference with NC on at the gym. Sound quality was satisfactory. The unit is too big and heavy. I started feeling pain in my ears in 30 mins of use.

Man, sony sure has gone down hill. I guess these earbuds would be good, they fit good but only the right side works. The left side is totally DOA and it's another 2 weeks wait for a replacement. Sony is destroying their reputation the past few years.

column8: The best true wireless earbud with noise cancellation I had!!!!
column9: This is a best true wireless noise cancelation ear phone I had now. The WF-1000XM3 sound excellent with a very good look and feel. It has decent battery life and USB-C charging with a quick-charge. Sony said, you can use it for 6 hours and with charging box is 24 hours. It is enough for whole day usage. Sony also made a very good over ear noise cancelation headphone, I thank they using similar technology here. This earphone is design for whole day usage. It is very comfortable. It has many ear tips. To have best noise cancelation, you should chose one which fit your ears. It works well with my iPhone X, there are a touch control on each earphone. You can change the feature of touch control. But, no volume control. I don't care about that. At the right earbud, you have playback control and right has mode selection. I used it for my conference call a lot, the voice is clear. But, the remote end known you are using the earphone. I can clear hear the voice from remote side. If you use the Sony Apps, you can select equalizer to speech. This is very good for conference call. It has Bluetooth 5.0 support, but, my phone is not support Bluetooth. I am a little impressed on the wireless connection. The coverage is bigger than my another Bluetooth 5.0 earbud. I turned the adaptive sound control in app, it can auto detect my behavior and change the audio mode. This is good if you wear it for whole day. Overall, as I said at the beginning, the sound quality is excellent. The clean and well balanced sound is the major reason I given 5 starts. If you want to complain it, the only thing I can say is the changing box, the button is round. Hence, the changing case can't stand on the table.

This unit is great as far as sound quality goes. It automatically adjusts the surrounding noises and I really do appreciate the additional ways to personalize for your use. I don’t live in a city where I am in and out of noises per say, but this does have that feature to block out noise better than the AirPod. This takes charge way longer than airpod in my opinion. At least few more hours with same type of use. One of the best thing is really the ear pads/plugs. It’s NOT one size fit all. Comes with variety of sizes and it’s sure to fit anyone. It’s comfortable to wear and much less likely to lose it due to its size. But nonetheless the size isn’t going to make my negative list. Size actually didn’t bother me despite how much bigger it seems compared to airpod. Love the case and the high end finish of the unit as well.

column8: The best pair of true wireless earbuds on the market
column9: I have to say, having tried several pairs of true wireless earbuds (ranging from the Chinese knockoffs to the ones costing hundreds), this is the best pair of true wireless earbuds on the market. They have excellent sound quality, noise cancelling on par with QC-25s, look and feel great, and have a pretty impressive battery life. I haven’t had any connectivity issues whatsoever after two weeks of pretty frequent use. I don’t know how they are with moisture as I don’t use them for running or anything like that. The only downside I can think of is that they can start to hurt the ears after one or two hours of use, but they come with tons of different ear plug sizes so they’re generally comfortable and don’t fall out (and at the very least are definitely no worse than any other earbuds). The button functionality is great too (takes a bit of getting used to but super smooth once you know the controls).

Had high hopes for these but they were a disappointment. Spent about ten days with them using them with both my iPhone X and my Cowon Plenue R. Sound volume was disappointingly low. They weren't comfortable in my ears and had to be continually adjusted. I tried working out with them a few times, cardio machine, and they were again uncomfortable and hardly worth the asking price. Major disappointment all around.

Love the design, and though some say they fall from their ears, I found them secure and comfortable. Crisp sound, good quality. I also like the charging case. However, there is simply not enough volume from these to satisfy me (with or without use of the Sony app). They're going back. 😩

I bought these solely for the noise cancellation function and they exceeded all my expectations. I use these in a noisy New York City apartment. I have had noise cancelling headphones before from well known names; they did not work! These ear buds work! Highly recommended!
Unspeakably beautiful! My music, my world!

Really disappointed in these headphones. I was super excited to get them after reading and watching great reviews. However, the microphone is terrible so if you're buying these to make phone calls, I'd stay far away. Using them to make cell calls is adequate as long as you're not having more than a 1-2 minute conversation. VOIP calls through skype or teams is 100% unusable. the only thing these are good for is getting fired. the rest of them is fine. great sound quality, battery life is good, build quality is good. just zero function as a headset hoping sony will issue an update as i don't think it's a hardware issue but if it doesn't come before the return window closes, these are going back for sure I use airpods, beats and a variety of other bluetooth devices and can safely say this is a product specific issue. Samsung S8, windows 10 pc. 9/3 update: Sony issued an update to fix the microphone at the end of august and it did zero to improve call quality. return window on these ends in a week and i'm almost positive they're going back. really disappointing since music quality is outstanding

column8: One of buds doesn't work. Not even a week of use.
column9: I've been using a few different kinds of wireless earphone including Samsung, and B&O. This is one of the best wireless earbuds. However, the right bud lost the signal from the 5th day of use, and it never detects the Bluetooth again. Of course, I tried factory initializing, rebooting my iPhone SEVERAL TIMES, and did everything I could do to solve this problem. And I realized there's no blue light in the right bud when I take it off from the charging case, which means that it didn't turn on. So I will return them and replace a new one to see if it was just no luck having a bad unit. Finger crossed!

I love my Sony MDR-1000X headphones which I have owned for two years now, so I had extremely high hopes for these "true wireless, noise canceling headphones. I was shocked when I put them on at how tinny and closed the sound was, how poor the bass was. It was like listening to an early transistor radio back in the 1950's. I tried four different sizes of ear tips, knowing that can make a difference depending on the depth and quality of the seal. It didn't. Sound was terrible throughout. Plus no discernible noise cancelation, or ambient sound control. Changing the equalizer manual also didn't make a difference. I would have so much liked something of quality that was smaller for my workouts at the gym or riding on airplanes, but I will have to settle for my MDR-1000's. I can't believe some of the "professional" reviewers, like the one on CNET. What do they usually listen to?

column8: Its alright, but not as good as what i expected
column9: The noise cancelation is so so, the connection is kind of slow compared to airpods

column8: Amazed at how bad this is
column9: I was ecstatic to receive this product because the reviews across the internet have been really good. I was sorely disappointed when I put them on - mainly because I was trying to figure out how to enable "noise-canceling" and realized it was actually on the whole time. It's incredible weak on the noise canceling sign. I have the WXMX headphones and those are night and day in terms of noise canceling. I bought this to replace my Bose Soundsport. The other more major issue is even after trying all the earplugs that it comes with, it ALWAYS falls out of my ear. This effectively renders it unusable. In short, it has decent sound quality, shite noise canceling, and they're big and bulky relative to other ear phones. And they don't even stay in your ear. Biggest disappointment all year.

column8: Great sound all around, touch control too sensitive
column9: These buds are great in terms of sound quality and battery life......but I'm shocked when the left bud completely stop working on 2nd day. Putting it back in the case did nothing. Normally, the red light indicates it's charging. It charged normally for the right earbud, but nothing happened for the left one. No light, taking it out and putting it back in did nothing. There isn't even any button on the earbuds or case I could press. Finally, I found out you could do reset by placing it in the case and hold finger on the sensor for 20 seconds (felt more like 35 sec). This fixed the issue. The left bud can charge and has sound like normal again. Honestly, I'm surprised this happened on 2nd day. Even though it is fine right now but I'm worried will this keep happening? I'll update review if it happens again. Update: After a month of use, I love these buds. It has the best sound quality and ANC is the best among its class. I'm a bit concern that one ear's (left) battery always gave a warning and ran out of batter before the other. Yes, of course, I put both of them at the exact same time in the charging case always. I still find the touch control to be extremely annoying. They'd react to tiny little touch. In the end, I just completely disable touch control. I also disable auto-pause when taken out of the ear. They didn't pause/un-pause like I expect. It feels like it's just a gimmick. In the latest firmware, they add the option to change touch control to volumne +/-. It think that's good but by this point I already rely 100% using my phone for volume control. Update #2: I completely disabled the touch control even after their update. At no point will I ever use "Hey Google" with these. Yet, it just keep trying to use that function. There is no way to set it only playback or volume control. It's just too annoying. I have also gotten Anker Liberty2 Pro NOT to replace these but use them as addition pair. In simple comparison. Anker is cheaper, sound mostly the same, has longer batter. It has little button instead of touch control which I preferred. But Sony has better noise cancelling. They are both very good IMO.

First off, pairing these with a windows 10 PC is going to work or completely fail depending on the driver you happen to have on your computer. I found the driver that works linked on a forum and it works perfectly now but I cannot for the life of me find it again :( Other than that - on my Samsung Galaxy Note 9 these headphones are amazing - I used to think active noise cancelling on an IN EAR squish their way in headphone was superfluous but it does make a difference and it works. It can be subtle at times but it works.
