Additionally, the app resets to default settings every time you close it, which becomes endlessly annoying to switch the settings back to the way you want them EVERY time you listen to these earbuds. Good: Sound quality Noise cancelling When you take on out your audio pauses Charges quickly and lasts a long time Bad: Usability needs work Bluetooth connection is worse than my $30 knockoff buds. Seriously, how can it be SO bad for the "best" buds on the market? App needs a lot of work They don't stay in your ear extremely well. I wouldn't trust them at more than a light jog. Not waterproof

i have the Sony’s and i have a lot of connection issues...most of the time only one connected and sometimes none. App is horrible! And they dont get very loud... Which is weird because the noise cancellation is great. Case way to big for your pocket. And the headphones are way too heavy tried working out with them they will not stay in your ears Sound Quality is just Okay if you spend a Minute with EQ. I carry both a iphone 11 pro and a Samsung galaxy S 10+ and have the same issues on both phones. I give them a 3 out of 10

column8: Beware - these DO NOT WORK with iOS13 or later..... read on....
column9: So, this is awkward... They sound awesome. The active Noise Cancelling works great (as well as my AirPod Pros). Design is nice, albeit large (but you get a great battery life). Case is logical (although a bit big). But you open the package, and you're greeted with a hastily printed pamphlet from Sony explaining that the earbuds aren't currently functioning (the app) with iOS 13.1 and later. I tried pairing, and it disconnected every 3 or 4 minutes, and the app wouldn't recognize the earbuds. So - great earbuds rendered completely useless in 2019. Returned them within 10 minutes. This really should be listed in the description. No wonder you can pick up a hundred "used" ones on amazon warehouse....

column8: Great sound, good insulators. Not perfect... $250 is a hefty price for average call quality.
column9: If you plan to use these for conference calling be advised that callers will complain about you being in "a tunnel" or unable to hear you. They are a fantastic alternative to over the ear design headphones but far from perfect. I expected better from the premium price. Call quality was where i was depending upon these to shine. Software updates are regular though so perhaps things will improve.

column8: Maybe next generation will be better...
column9: Overall I found these earbuds to be too difficult to use. I used them with iphone Xs and here are the issues I had: first, I used them during a flight and despite having the noise cancellation turned "on" I could not increase the volume enough...so the max volumein this Sony compared to my first gen airpods at 60%. There are multiple settings for the earbuds and you have to keep pressing noise cancellation as it loses it's position every time you put the earbuds down. Also, there was a delay connecting to my phone every time I put the earbuds down. Finally, there is a blinking light that is on all the time which can be annoying...I wish we could turn it off. One last thing, the case is too bulky I think.

Loved the idea and thought these noise canceling earbuds would be great like the Sony WH-1000XM3 headphones that I have. Unfortunately no. While they do a adequate job canceling out noise, sound quality is not what I expected and they made a popping/crackling sound when watching moves on my laptop. Much as I wanted these to work they did not meet my needs and I returned them. Now I am waiting to see if the to be released in 2020, Bose 700 Earbuds will meet my needs.

I had originally bought the Samsung and Amazon earbuds, but returned both because the sound quality wasn't as premium as I expected. I bought these as a refurb from Amazon because the price was too good to pass up. Ok, so I've only had these for a few minutes at this point, but I had to write a review because, WOW, what a difference in sound quality! I am so impressed. I have the Sony WH1000XM3 headphones, and I have to say the sound quality is pretty close, which is to say, very good. Pairing the earbuds with my phone was quick and smooth. Amazingly (after my previous experiences), these fit in my ears very well, and while they are bigger than most truly wireless earbuds, they really don't feel bulky. I was lucky to get an amazing deal on these buds, but I would willingly pay the retail price for these things...they are worth every penny, so start looking between the mattress cushions for change and get a pair of your own! !

column8: Better than ANY OTHER... Just Perfect!!
column9: Works EXACTLY as described. Perfect for bass and super loud music listening. We have NO complaints about this one. Better than the bose ones. Worth every penny. Sound quality is perfect, True noise cancellation, Battery life is just as described. ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐ 5 stars! !

column8: Felt like a sucker after buying these
column9: I bought these based on the “expert” reviews on the major tech sites. It’s pretty clear these reviewers are just “influencers“ who write up sparkling reviews to generate revenue through their affiliate programs on their bankrupt sites. The supposed noise canceling, the only reason I bought them, is nothing. I could go on and on, but if you read the 1-star reviews, the experiences described by them are identical to mine. The “noise-canceling” is just marketing bs. Of course, it’s possible there was a defective batch which might account for all the negative reviews. Idk, I sent mine back for a refund before it was too late. This was one of most disappointing purchases I’ve made in a long time.
I bought these because of the advertised noise cancellation. However these buds provided only a slight reduction in ambient noise. Not worth the premium price in my view.
it just arrived the expectation what i want.

I’ve owned the Sony earbuds for 3 months. I’ve flown with them take. Them to the gym and now they have sound 360 which is unbelievable. Anyways they are the best earbuds for the money. Sony is a game changer right now.

The box came in, and its excellent, really gives you that "smartphone" level of quality where you just want to keep the box (actually I'm keeping the box because I want a place to store the different plugs). It charges via USB C, which I appreciate because its a better, easier plug than micro USB. It came with half a dozen different sized plugs, it was a bit confusing which was for which, but on the third set, I found a pair that feels snug without feeling uncomfortable. Honestly the fit is so gentle that I keep thinking they might fall out, but despite trying to make them fall out, they haven't yet. (probably more of a testament to previous earbuds that didn't stay in). I have fairly pronounced ear ridges for them to nestle into, so other people may have a different experience. When I first went to use the Sony app on my iphone, it failed to connect. Instead, I went to settings -> Bluetooth and added them there. What was nice, was it automatically popped up the ability for me to go to the app store and download the app (but I had already installed it), and a few minutes later, after going through the configuration, I had my noise cancelling setup and was listening to music. Wow! I went from Bose Sport earbuds (where are amazing) to these and the sound is distinctly an upgrade. Not only that, but my office is near a busy road and now my music isn't competing with the cars. I'm really really impressed. Excellent sound, excellent bass, the noise cancellation is great (probably 75% reduction, I'm sure I could get better with over the ear, but for the convenience of these, I'll take it!). I'd really struggle to go back to non-sound cancelling earbuds after this, these look, feel, and sound great!

Maximum battery life from fresh out of charging case to dead-battery shut-off (ANC on, volume at 20%) is 4.5 hours. That's nowhere the "6" hours listed on the box. I was suspecting I had counterfeit batteries until I cross-checked with a coworker, and he also gets only ~4 hours from charge to shut-off. On the flip side of this battery lie, earbuds recharge ridiculously fast back to 100%. Charging case does make it really easy to keep the earbuds always fully-charged, and in parallel charge the case while using the buds. This is the only superiority over the WH-1000XM3s.
Great product and form factor. This are prefect for the frequent flier.
Sound quality is good. Fit in the ear is good. Connecting is a bit funky.

These are THE absolute best! I have been wanting a pair of earbuds, foreverrrr. Finally got these and I am in LOVE! The overall sound quality is excellent (for music and calls), and the noise cancellation makes it even that more impressive! Zero background sound for me (which helps me block out my noisy neighbors). These definitely live up to the hype and are so worth it! Get a pair!! !

column8: Sound is great but spotty bluetooth pairing
column9: These sound great and have very decent noise cancelling...but...pairing is very particular. They pair perfectly with my samsung android phone and music sounds great. However, my Microsoft surface recognizes them and "pairs" but doesn't recognize them as speakers so no sound at all. (Yes, I've updated both.) Another major disappointment was my kindle, one reason I bought these was to listen to audible while mowing. They pair, but the connection is terrible and drops out frequently even when directing the speaker to sacrifice quality in favor of connection. Given how well they sound with android, I'm hoping this is a software issue. I'm probably going to keep them and hope I'm correct. I'd caution against buying these until this issue is resolved unless your only concerned with pairing them to your phone.

column8: Great noise cancelling, lousy sound quality.
column9: These headphones have been a lifesaver for me. I bought them almost exclusively to block sounds while I am in a noisy place. I have very sensitive hearing and some sounds will literally, physical knock me over. It’s weird. What can I say? The noise cancelling feature is positively delicious. Put the earbuds in, turn on the noise cancelling function and suddenly, I don’t want to stab my ears out and can venture into public places knowing that if I need to, I can pop these in and have some control over the way sound hits me. I can still hear conversation albeit somewhat muted. I can still hear some ambient sounds but not in the clash of everything going on at once. It is as if the earbuds help to ‘sort out’ the various sounds around me and make them more manageable. It’s hard to explain. When I use the Ambient Sound setting, I find conversation more difficult. I hear more of the sounds around me but again, in a more orderly way. When all sound settings are off, all sounds are muted simply by way of the ear canal being blocked by the ear buds themselves. I do appreciate the different size and type of ear tips as I have very small ear canals. I find these comfortable if not a little heavy. They stay in if I seat them well but I do feel as though if I were to swing my head, they might fall out of my ears. It’s a good thing I don’t jog with them. I’m not sure they’d stay in. Still, many reviews say that this is not a problem so maybe it’s just my tiny ears. So, why the four star review? Well, for the hefty price tag and the brand, I truly expected better sound quality when it came to music. It also struggles with connectivity in that it will be connected to my phone but won’t respond to the tap commands to play/pause. Sort of frustrating. Even more frustrating is the quality of sound when on a call. Every single call I’ve ever taken using these headphones have been met with “hello? Can you hear me?”. Eventually, I just end up pulling them out of my ears and taking the call directly from my phone. Lame Sauce. Again - for the price paid, these really should be capable of managing a phone call. Other reviews show this as a common complaint so I guess I’m not the only one disappointed about sound quality and crappy phone calls. Basically, I paid a bunch of money for the noise cancelling feature. It’s a good thing that it does this really, really well or they’d have been returned. In summary, if you are looking for stellar noise cancelling, these are the ear buds for you. If you’re looking for stellar sound quality, pass.

Sound accuracy is excellent however the noise canceling in the microphone / voice is terrible. It picks up every little sound and is difficult to communicate in any type of noisy environment. Not enjoyable to the person you are talking to.

column8: Awesome for listening, decent for exercise
column9: I love these for sound quality, battery life ease, and noise cancellation. Only thing is fit in my ears. If I’m not doing physical activity, they’re great. But I did want to hike and run with them - I know, I know: they’re not specifically meant for that, but they’re still headphones. They’re fine for weight lifting or hiking uphill, but hiking downhill jostles them out a bit, and I keep pushing them in when I run. None of the other sizes work better. I also wish they were a bit louder. I like loud music when I run, and it feels like they max out early. It’s probably to protect the ear, since they’re noise cancelling and sit inside the canal. Still love them and they’re superior to anything else out there.

They don't stay in my ears at all. I just hated that feeling of slowly slipping put of your ears and loose this precious thing to ground and scars. I love the design, comfort, style. I don't like the bug touch buttons. They're oversized and worthless since they keep activating my google assistant or changing noise cancelling modes or ambient sound while I'm trying to put em in my ears or trying to keep em stay in or from falling out suddenly. So hard to keep em when you pay so much.

Great buds. The best blend of all the others. Sound quality isn't as good as Momentum, but MUCH more reliable, and MUCH BETTER battery life. Sony has a done a great job with these. They have become my go-to. Highly recommend.

I purchased these headphones to use on long flights in conjunction with the TAO Tiny Bluetooth transmitter plugged into the airline entertainment system. Works great as planned and the noise canceling is much better than some reviews I have read. Until now I have been using the BOSE wired noise canceling earbuds - After using the SONY for a month I gave the BOSE to my wife and I'm not looking back. What I was not expecting is that I like them so much I have found myself using them at work for phone calls. The other feature I was not expecting is they charge really fast from the storage unit.

Headphones are mission critical for me. Due to gun violence I have acute PTSD. Headphones (along with some Bruckner and Bach) reduce my hyper-vigilance. The more isolated I can be from what is going on around me, the better off I am - be it Whole Foods or just the walk to Whole Foods. I read a few comments criticizing the ANC. Those folks do not know how to use the app. All the way to the left is noise cancellation. I find complete isolation (or back these would go). ANC is first rate. Yes, I know, there is an inherent danger to walking around effectively deaf to the world. I'll cope. One minor issue: Tapping the left earbud toggles the ANC: On, Ambient Sound and Off. The selection returns a voice confirmation that I find impossible to understand. Keep in mind that you can do this through the app. First thing you want to do is bring these to a full charge. The app will apply a firmware update but it is fussy about the amount of charge required to do so. There is a "360 sound" configuration which you should skip the first time around. You'll need a great deal of patience, and maybe a Xanax, to set it up which involves taking pictures of your ears — seriously. Moreover, there doesn't seem to be a supporting Android app. The charging case is magnetic so the earbuds seat correctly every time while allowing easy removal. The Android app is a bit buggy which is the worst thing I can say about these buds. While the buds stay connected the app keeps disconnecting for some strange reason. The app does not have to run to use the earbuds. If you close the app the earbuds retain whatever settings were in place. Sound is fantastic. I find it improves by turning off the Dolby processor. An equalizer is available through the app. Google Play Music starts automatically when the buds are removed from the case. You can connect to multiple devices but only one at a time. Again, the sound is very rich with good bass and clear high notes. I had good results with Wagner. Miles Davis and some 60s hard rock. I might be a senior but I am still a geek. I gave up reading manuals around Redhat 8. This is an exception. You really should read the manual. The included manual is impossible to deal with. Fortunately, on Sony's website, you will find a comprehensive "Help Guide" that is easy to read. Sony provides enough pairs of tips to fit every conceivable ear size (and then some). Best bet is always the largest set that you can use without being uncomfortable. Sony did cheap out on one thing: The damned C-Cable is about six inches in length. They also figure that everyone has enough adaptors at this point (they are correct) so none is provided. Bottom line. Premium performance is in line with the premium price. My last set of ANC ear buds were half this price. This is the first pair of truly wireless buds I have had. I must say that it is nice to get that thing off my neck. The downside is some loss of convenience.

These headphones have some really nice qualities that are ruined by some very frustrating behaviors. I took them on a two week transatlantic business trip where I had hoped to use them with my Samsung S9 phone, Samsung Tab3 tablet, and Dell Latitude work laptop. PROS 1. Sound quality is fine. It's not the best (in fact I have Sennheiser wired earbuds that are 1/4 the cost that sound much better) but they are still quite good for something so little and battery powered. So I consider this a win. 2. Noise Cancelling was perfect in a car, train, or bus. 3. Battery life is excellent. I was really impressed at how long these last and how quickly they charge. 4. The case is great. It's a little too bulky to carry in a pant pocket, but it is a really good design that keeps them from getting lost and keeps them charged. 5. Ear cushion options are great. It comes with a total of 7 pairs of ear cushions to choose from. This is practically a requirement for this design because without the right fit these will fall out quite easily. CONS 1. I did finally get it to connect to my Win10 laptop, but it was more complicated than my phone or tablet. First you have to update the firmware, and then hold both sides for 7 seconds to enter pairing mode. This took me forever to figure out because I did not need to enter paring mode to connect either my phone or tablet. I didn't even realize this was an thing. So for my whole trip I was frustrated that I could not connect these to my laptop. 2. Spotty bluetooth connection with all devices. One ear would sometimes just not connect, or suddenly disconnect. The fix in all cases was to disconnect and reconnect. 3. Microphone during phone calls was very susceptible to background noise. People had trouble hearing me, unless I was in a perfectly quite room. In a taxi or walking on the street, these were practically unusable for phone calls. 4. Touch controls for phone calls are not documented, possibly non-existent. When trying to change the NC option during a call (via the left touch control) it would just beep and do nothing, or even just hang up. I ended up getting disconnected from conference calls due to this. 5. Touch controls are not reliable. Sometimes it simply does not detect a touch, or it does and even beeps to signal it registered the touch, but then still does nothing. Most noticeable when trying to change NC options via touch. 6. NC in the airplane only worked slightly better than no NC at all. 7. NC in wind actually makes the wind louder. 8. NC in some rare cases seems to get out of sync and actually just creates more noise. 9. The volume is uncontrollable with the laptop. 10. Audio volume is not in sync, or not working at all, with tablet or phone. This was most troublesome with my tablet. If I first had it connected to my phone, and had turned the volume down, then connected to my tablet, the volume is stuck low and I can not turn it up (the tablet default bluetooth volume is full volume, so I can only turn it down). The fix is to disconnect the tablet, reconnect the phone, start media, turn the volume up all the way, disconnect phone, reconnect tablet, and viola. When they worked, I was very happy with them. But unfortunately, they are far too often frustrating to use. I expect better, especially at this price point.
These are not very comfortable even after changing earbud sizes. They tend to fall out easily. These are not for use during any exercise or activity.

column8: Great for phone, terrible for laptop.
column9: Will not connect to my laptop.

column8: They are totally worth every penny
column9: These ear buds are awesome and dangerous to absorb so much of the environment sound you have to be careful crossing the street. The sound is awesome the bass is legit and the vocals seem live.

column8: Not as good as people say.
column9: Fit is terrible. I live in NYC and going up and down the stairs taking the train and walking causes ear buds to fall out constantly. Tried all included ear inserts. None work for me. Sound is too low. Wish I would have gotten the jaybirds or samsung. For this price point and this company I expected way better.

Starting with the pros, these have very good sound quality. While I didn't get them for listening to music, you totally can and they will sound like a good pair of wired headphones if BT source you're using supports high fidelity. Unfortunately, that's where the good parts end. The touch buttons, while a good idea at first, perform very poorly. There's a significant lag between touching them and experiencing the effect of the touch. I found myself double and triple activating the buttons because I thought it didn't register the touch the first time around. Pretty bad. Then things get worse. Battery life is dismal. Li ion batteries don't like to be charged to 100% and kept that way. After desperately searching for an OFF switch on the headphones and then on the case, I resigned myself to just putting them down and waiting for them to power off. If only. They would randomly come back to life and more often than not, I find myself with low battery after less than 48h since last full charge and less than 30min of use time. Most of the time one side will be down to 20% while the other would be 70% or more charged. I also found the battery levels to drop from the reported "about 50%" to "low battery" within 15 minutes. Ridiculous. A bad attempt at copying the iFruit company. Like most other BT devices, they suffer from the occasional stutter and magic disconnects. To add insult to injury however, I also discovered that if you pair them to more than 1 device, the device that comes back to life last, will steal the connection upon powering on. Yup.. if you're connected to your phone and laptop and and the laptop turns on, the connection automagically switches. At least in my case it did. So overall not something you want to spend over $200 on. I didn't get them for the noise canceling feature and have consistently avoided doing so. I like the pass through sound mode, so you can hear the environment. At $100, perhaps more palatable.

Great sound when adjusting via their dedicated EQ app. The best I've found on a TW headphone to date. But these are heavy and bulky earbuds that simply did not feel comfortable no matter what tip I tried. Hence my return.
They were VERY uncomfortable!!! Abd the right one wouldn't stay in no matter what fitting cover I tried!! My ear was very sore after having them in for only 10 minutes. I'm returning them .

After a couple of months usage heres my review: 1. Battery lasts 3:30 hrs. And each size lasts different length. 2. NC is not as great as you expected. Maybe its cause the headphone is kernal type. 3. It cannot be linked to more than one device at a time. 4. Their 2.0 software now is much better. So make sure update ur headset.

column8: Better than AirPods Pro but still not worth it
column9: So I recently got the new AirPods Pro and returned them because of subpar sound quality. I thought these would be amazing because I have other Sony over ear headphones. The sound quality is ok and the noise cancellation is also ok, but the software of trying to configure everything is a dealbreaker. The AirPods have seamless UI commands and these are clunky and sometimes don’t work (left headphone is supposed to control noise cancellation and ambient noise but it sometimes doesn’t work). With these having no water resistance I also worry about working out. I’m sure down the road the technology will improve but for the time being I would hold off on these.

These wireless earbuds are amazing. The Noise Canceling is robust and clears a path for full-bodied sound from the drivers. I wear these in the New York City Subway and bear witness to their glorious victory over Mariachis, Buskers, Showtimers, the Loudly Unhinged, and the Self-important Conversationalists. By pressing on the left earbud you can simultaneously pause playback and noise cancellation to listen to your environment and toggle it on or off. The right earbud controls playback and digital assistant integration. No volume control via touch, must be adjusted on device. The machines themselves are well designed. Their aesthetic is elegant and mostly subdued with a flash of color. The Black option is adorned with Copper accents and the Silver option (which is closer to what silver looks like at golden hour, if we're color balancing here) has Gold accents. Both decidedly high-end executions that feel solid and worth your expenditure. My set included 7 different size options: Large, Medium (which ship on the units), Small, and Super Small; Large, Medium, Small of a shallower depth and different, more cushioned material. They charge via USB-C, because it's the best cable and it means you can carry less power adaptors - right now it means I can charge my phone, laptop, and these headphones all using one power supply. Battery life is great and a little better than advertised. Make sure to download the Sony Headphone app. I had it installed since I own the Sony XB950N1 Wireless Noise Canceling Headphones already. This will allow you to control the more advanced features.
TERRIBLE PRODUCT.. SHORT BATTERY LIFE, TOO BULKY, TOTAL GARBAGE

column8: Unsatisfying and unqualified for it's price.
column9: Sound quality is indeed not satisfying at all, even of bad quality. Connection is unstable, breaks from time to time. Sensor of quik gestures on the bud is not accurate enough. I doubt if this is the quality of the earphone or if this one I get is a fake and shobby product. I am really disappointed.
I think I wish it had better connectivity if anything. I really wish it could connect to two devices at once because switching between my laptop and my phone is very annoying.
Thanks

column8: Road noise wile making phone calls.
column9: I got them to use hands free wile commuting for phone calls. They pick up the road noise to much and not usable. This is my only issue 5 star on everything else.
These were perfect for my entertainment while walking.

column8: they were great until sonys last firmware update
column9: id have rated these a 5 except after the last firmware update, they now only play for about 3 hrs before dying and often die minutes after the battery level still states 50% charge. since the update the case also now stops charging when the case capacity reaches 30%. so now there's only two charges (instead of three charges that give you 6 hour play each) that give you three hours of play time each for a total of 9 hrs playtime instead of the about 20 hrs i could easily get before their horrible firmware update. im returning them. with the current garbage battery life they are a nuisance and no longer anywhere near worthy of the 240 dollar price tag. EDIT: the guy whos talking about a rubberized case with an aluminum cap? everyone should stop listening to you right now because right off those two claims/your first listed points?? are completely fabricated and false. even the manufacture denies them. your ability to honestly factually review is already garbage. the entire case is plastic. there's nothing rubberized or aluminum about it. your next claim? deeper in the ear canal? 3 sets of the included tips are MORE shallow than standard and three sets are JUST as deep as standard... i want whatever psychedelic you've gotten your hands on. edit Again: resetting the buds twice gave me my battery life back

I bought these because of the many great online reviews. I must admit that I was disappointed when I first received them. I had trouble getting them to stay in my ear and the volume was insufficient. In addition, the sound quality did not impress, I liked the iPhone wired buds which came with the phone better, Then I started switching out the earbud tips which came with them. there was some improvement, but they still had inferior sound quality. I was thinking about returning them when I decided to try some memory phone tips I had on another set of buds. This made a huge difference! First off, I noticed that the volume issue was solved. Rather than dialing them up to maximum or almost maximum, I was able to use them at 50 or 60%. More importantly, the sound quality was greatly enhanced - with the bass really coming through. Maybe my ear canals are oddly shaped and the rubber or silicon tips that came with them would not sufficiently seal the buds to my ears. Others may notice the same thing. One other issue is that they worked great on my iPhone and my MacBook pro, but were unlistenable with my iMac. After some research, I finally determined the problem was my magic mouse. By turning it off, the sound was fine. Luckily I still have a trackpad to control the computer. Apparently its bluetooth does not disrupt the buds. YMMV.

column8: Bought for the hype, tech not yet ripe
column9: I expected these to actually cancel “some” noise on purchase. They don’t. Not just voices; background sounds are almost amplified in all ranges except bassist of bass. Paid a lot of money on tech that has not matured and ultimately can get the same effect by shoving my fingers in my ears (which is basically what you're paying to do when someone mentions how great these are at "noise isolation"). Again: the TECH is not canceling anything that I can tell. You're just shoving them so deep into your ear that you can't hear anything around you.

column8: Impressive wireless earbuds, with the exception of wind noise when walking outdoors.
column9: I have been wearing the earbuds for the last month and have been very impressed with the Bluetooth connection on my iPhone. This has been an issue with four previous Bluetooth wireless earbuds. I have been wearing them daily to take my dog on his morning and afternoon walks. Sound quality is excellent. Initially, I noticed that as I was walking, if there was any wind It was picked up by the microphone. The wind noise is distracting and interferes with the sound. I started to play with the accompanying Sony Headphones app and found that turning off the ambient sound function helped to diminish the wind sound problem. I like that I can tap the left bud once to pause the music if I need to talk to someone. I charged the case when I received them and after using them daily for the month, I have only charged them one additional time. When I put them in my ears the buds tell you the percentage of battery life and that I am connected to Bluetooth, a nice feature. With the latest App update it now gives you a percentage of charge for the case. At age 68 and attending too many loud rock concerts in the 60’s and 70’ my hearing is declining with age, but these earbuds still deliver excellent sound reproduction. I would have given these earbuds 5 stars, however as my primary usage is outdoors, I continue to hear wind noise when walking despite changing the ambient noise setting. It is minimal but still noticeable so I gave them four stars. I also plan to wear the earbuds when It is warm enough to bike, and have concerns about wind noise with that activity. I am still experimenting with different size earpieces, between the foam and silicone to find the right size. I have an issue with the left earbud falling out when walking. "I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest opinion”

I've been using these headphones now for about two weeks. I flew from Seattle to London with them. I've also used them at home, at work, on the bus, on a train, and while just walking around. When traveling, I use to take two sets of headphones with me: a bulky, over-the-head, bluetooth headphone with great noise-canceling features and a pair of small bluetooth earbuds without noise canceling. The Sony WF-1000XM3 now allows me to take just one set of headphones that fulfills both requirements. I'm amazed at how effective the noise-canceling is, especially in an airplane! The battery life is also amazing, and I love being able to recharge it over USB-C, the same cable I use to recharge my laptop, camera, and iPad!

Nice
Definitely not worth the price, over hyped

So Sony sent me a pair of these to try out, as I'm a convert to their wireless Over-the-Ear headphones from Bose noise-cancelling headphones. Those are my favorite pair of headphones ever, so I was super eager to give these a go. I've owned Apple Airpods and Beats Bluetooth Powerbeats, and these are noticeably better on a lot of fronts. Comfort: Surprisingly, they fit super well and stay in my ears. I usually have issues with that, but they're snug, comfortable and lighter than they look. I worked out with them nearly all gym exercises (running, rowing, lifting, etc.), but if you're going to do a lot of HIIT movements or jump roping, you might look into something that wraps over the ear. But for more gym uses they're awesome. Way louder (or at least seemingly so with noise cancelling than my Beats). Sound: At first I thought they were a little tinny on the high-end, but I forgot I had been compensating for my Beats lack of volume with a treble-heavy EQ in Spotify. Once I reset the EQ, they were spot on. Suprisingly more bass response as well. Noise-Cancelling: So the noise cancelling is actually noticeable and legit, something I was skeptical about in an in-ear, but they'll also never be as noise-cancelling as over-the-ear headphones. That comes with the territory. I actually like there's a tiny amount of bleed so I'm not totally oblivious to the environment around me. If you're looking for even more ambient, there's an ambient sound which works great, one of the things I love about Sony's over-the-ears. Controls: This is maybe my only complaint, but in reality, it just took some getting used to. The controls work really well, almost too well. Every time I would go to adjust the piece in my ear, I'd accidentally hit the large control space on each bud, which would pause the song or change the sound mode. I just had to adjust it by holding the edges, instead of accidentally placing my finger on the middle of the bud. Not a big deal, just took some adjustment. But if you're looking for easy control over playback and settings, definitely not a problem here. Conclusion: These are probably the most luxurious in-ears on the market, which justifies the price point. If you need ultimate isolation over everything, I'd check out Sony's over-the-ears. But if you're looking for amazing quality in-ears with noise cancelling and great sound, these are imho, the best.

The Best Earbuds with amazing sound Quality!! I love Sony products and this one is outstanding my expectations. The only drawback is call quality but I don’t care for now as sony will upgrade and come up with a fix to it sooner..

column8: Poor design and constant tiny interruptions while playing audio
column9: I have quite a few different bluetooth speakers and headphones, but I heard good things about this one so I decided to buy it and try it out. Here are some things I noticed: 1. The headphones only charge from USB - USBC cable provided, Sony locks you in on purpose because their cable ONLY charges those headphones and none of my other devices would charge from the cable provided. The Sony headphones would only charge from the cable provided in the box. This means that I cannot share something basic like the cable between my JBL Charge 4 and these Sony headphones. I would understand if the charger needed to provide a certain voltage, but this is specific to the cable. 2. The Sony iOS app for managing these headphones is really buggy and needs a lot of work. 3. If I leave these headphones connected via bluetooth to the iOS device, it would cut out the music that I play on other devices if the IR sensor gets triggered (for example, if I pull them out or put them in my ears). This means that I have to go and disconnect the headphones from the Settings to make sure they don't send a signal for my device to stop/play music. 4. There is constant wireless interruption when I play music from any app (including native app) on iOS device. I made sure the firmware was updated to the latest. None of my other bluetooth headphones have this problem. The interruptions appear as noise for half a second or less. It appears to happen at every minute to 3min intervals. 5. It's a pain to pair more than one device to these headphones. 6. The sound quality is decent, but in noise cancelation mode, the sound of voices can still be heard. I find other products have done much better in the noise cancelation area than these headphones.
Noise cancelling poor

I'm really enjoying these earphones! I own (and love) Sony's WH-1000XM3 over-ear headphones, but it's not easy to take them on the go or to the gym with me, and these Sony WF-1000XM3 earphones help with that and match the headphones perfectly. Plus they're very comfortable and come with different size and types of tips to make them even more comfortable. The color (silver) is also very discrete, which was important to me. These have amazing sound quality and really impressive noise cancelling that are great for the office or gym (especially for earphones), but the ambient sound setting was actually the thing I enjoyed most. I've tried a few wireless earphones, and I don't like that they make me feel less aware of my surroundings, but the ambient sound setting lets me go for a walk or run and still be completely aware of the world around me - hands down the thing I liked most about these earphones. My only issue is that the Adaptive Sound Control feature is a little too sensitive and switched too often for my liking - I ended up turning it off and just changing the noise cancelling settings when I needed to, and it wasn't too big a deal.

column8: Excellent Quality Sound for Music, Poor Sound for Talking on the Phone
column9: The sound quality for playing music was excellent, but was terrible for phone calls. I sent the first pair back because I thought it was defective. If you are using these for music only, they will be great. If you use them for talking on the phone at all, you will not be happy.

Good: The design of the Sony WF-1000XM3 Earbuds is undeniably great. The sound quality is also amazing so I sincerely enjoyed listening to music or podcasts with it. I find the noise cancellation feature decent enough, and the battery life good as well. Not so good: For me, the major drawback of this model is the poor quality of calls, so I don’t recommend using them for calling. Another thing that might need a big improvement is the touch controls, and others might find it inconvenient to adjust the volume on a separate device. Moreover, people who love to sweat might not be happy to know that the Sony WF-1000XM3 is not water-resistant. Read the rest on my blog Girl On The Reviews. com

These earbuds and charging case are *considerably* larger than my 1-year-old Anker wireless buds (which sound like garbage, btw -- maybe the new ones have improved) I also have the over-the-ear Sony XM3 for direct A-B comparison. Comfort: the big headphone definitely wins, the earbuds feel heavier and less comfortable inside your ear canals Sound quality: the earbuds are about 75% of the big headphone, full warm well balanced sound but a little tinny in loud orchestral music or chamber music. ANC Noise Cancellation: also about 75% of the big headphone, but remarkable for these little guys. I tested ANC on my neighbor's loud muffler exhaust noise (don't you just hate those??) The big XM3 headphone cancelled it down to a whisper, while these earbuds cut it to a running-fan level, not bad. Overall, pretty impressed with these ANC earbuds. Bluetooth paring/reconnection works perfectly every time. I haven't tested phone calls but I have my trusty old Plantronics Voyager for that. I guess time will tell how long they can comfortably stay inside my ear without causing discomfort. So stay tuned for update.

You gotta learn how to put them on. They have too make a good seal first otherwise they won't sound as nice but this is true with all rubber tip earbuds. Just put them on before you play any music and they should both be blocking a fair amount of noise.

I've used these headphones almost daily in just about every environment (work, exercising, travel including flying, around the house, and even playing drums). Unboxing them there were a few things that I loved right out of the box. USB-C charging is a great feature. As most of my device are now on the standard, it's nice that I'm one device closer to finally removing the micro USB cable from my backpack. Also, there are six additional sets of ear tips with three different sizes in both silicone and foam. I generally have a difficult time finding earbuds that fit well, but with the many options and some trial and error I found these to be very comfortable. The overall look of everything was also very sleek and refined which is just a nice extra touch. Setting them up is easy and NFC makes it a breeze. The app definitely stands above the competition and has a ton of features such as EQ and adjusting the noise canceling intensity. The EQ wasn't anything I thought I needed, but I found myself using more and more. I really enjoyed using them daily. The sound quality is great for casual listening, but amazing when I was actively listening to music. The channel separation is fantastic and each frequency comes through nice and clear without overpowering each other. Initially, I discovered they weren't as loud and some I've had in the past, but the noise canceling really negates the need for outrageous volume. Watching movies with these on my tablet during flights was my favorite experience. The dialogue was clear, bass had great punch for action scenes, and the noise canceling made me forget I was on a place. The audio syncs up perfectly with the video which is also something I've had issues in the past with other wireless ear buds. Exercising with these was not my favorite. In all fairness they aren't really advertised to be used this way though. They don't have any kind of sweat resistance and once I got hot I had some trouble keeping them in. One unexpected area they shined, though, was using them while drumming. They stayed secure, which is something I've had problems with. Also, the noise canceling really muted the sound of my own drumming so I could hear the music I was playing along to. Their performance was on par if not better than over the ear style headphones. Overall, these have been great for me for daily use with great comfort, sound quality, and features. The only thing missing was volume controls and the ability to work out with them.

column8: These are best noise cancelling earbuds available

The sound quality & noise cancelling are so far beyond the AirPods Pro that Apple should be embarrassed. I am 691/2 years old so my workouts consist of walking and household chores. I never felt insecure about the fit. If I was going to do more strenuous activity I would choose my Powerbeats Pro. BUT for every other use. These are my choice. You won’t be disappointed if you’re looking for in ear, noise cancelling headphones with great, natural sound.

column8: Lotta potential, but doesn't quite hit the mark for me
column9: First, buy the renewed ones. They are just as good as new, but loads cheaper. Review: I had these for about 3 weeks hefore returning them, for several reasons. The buds worked just fine, no problems whatsoever, but I just felt like there was more that could have been done to really make them worth it. It was a worthy first release, but in the end, I would prefer to wait until the release of a WF-1000XM4 model to see if they've perfected the design. 1. Sound quality: This is all subjective but I feel like more bass was needed. It was too neutral for my taste. The mids and highs were definitely clear, but there was something that made the buds sound a little too synthetic for my taste. Probably just the way I tuned them in the equilizer. Also, these only support the SBC codec. While that isn't terrible (because they still sound good), at that price and at this day and age, you should be getting the aptdx codec as well for higher quality music listening. 2. Noise-cancelling: the reason everyone bought these things. Right now the competition is really in between the Airpods Pro and these. Most online reviews say these beat the Airpods, and I have no doubt that for their ears, it was so. But for me it wasn't. I tried both side by side and while the Sony's may cancel out more low-end noises and rumbles, I was disappointed by how little it cancelled out high-end sounds like voices. I then compared them side by side with the dishwasher going on in the background and found that the noise of the washer was cancelled more on the Airpods Pro. So, for me personally, I think the ANC in the Airpods was slightly better. But in any case, ANC for the Sony's was slightly underwhelming. Like I said before, I would wait for the 1000XM4 to see the improvement in ANC tech. 3. No IP rating for water/sweat proofing. 'Nuff said...like c'mon Sony. 4. Does not allow full freedom to modify the touch controls to your liking. Basically you have 4 options: Pause and playback/skip tracks; volume control; voice assistant; and toggling between ambient sound and ANC. The buds really only allow you to choose 2 out of those 4 settings, while the other 2 would require you to take out your phone. I was grateful they finally put in volume control, but I didn't want to have to give up one of my other controls to use it. I eventually settled on toggling Ambient/ANC on the left and voice assistant on the right, through which I could control volume and pause/play. It worked for a bit, but was a little too finnicky. I would prefer to just have everything on the touch controls. 5. They look super good, but just a tad to big for my taste. All in all, if you're on the fence about buying these, I'd say save your money and wait. There is a lot of unmet potential in these earbuds that I feel could be realized given a couple years. They're a good prototype, but by no means are they perfect.

column8: They sound great when they can stay connected.

These earbuds are pretty very slick. The design is attractive, including the casing. The buds fit snug in the case which also acts as a charging port for the earbuds. I've used them a handful of times and am still sitting with a 70% charge. The case is charged via USB. The earbuds were a little awkward when it came to selecting a snug earpiece- the small is a bit too small and the medium is a bit too big. The pairing was easy. The buds work well with both of my phones. I do find the noise controls to be a bit awkward. It doesn't always seamlessly switch between noise canceling and ambient sound. The ride controls were easy enough to figure out and work as expected. I would not call these true noise canceling as I would assume the fit would have to be near perfect for that to be the case. These work well in an office setting, but not a super loud area. The sound quality is crisp and clear. Overall, the buds are attractive and cancel noise as best as I would expect a wireless product could (pending fit). The product is fairly easy to use and the sound quality is superb.

I work in an office 9-5, travel a lot, skateboard when it's not raining, go on runs every few days and overall am fairly active. These earbuds have been a lifesaver because they have everything I need honestly. Superb audio quality? Check. Noise cancelling? CHECK! It's great in the office tbh. Stylish? Ahem-CHECK. Seamless syncing? Yes, check. Stays in my ears that are apparently a weird shape? You betcha-CHECK. All in all, would buy again. 10/10

I really wanted to like these. They ooze quality in how they are built, their appearance, the slick charging unit, and exceptional sound-stage. I used them over a 5 week period under various conditions and concluded the following: Sound quality, excellent. App, excellent. Noise reduction: very impressive. Sitting still on an aeroplane, great. But despite numerous attempts, using all kinds of tips, twisting and squeezing, the fit just didn't cut it. The seal was excellent as the noise reduction was nothing short of remarkable. But I had no confidence in them staying in my ears over time and especially while moving about. I finally gave up on the day I returned them, giving them one last chance while walking to work for 15 minutes. During that time I must have re-twisted and positioned them some 8 to 10 times. But the biggest niggle for me was that during these 5 weeks I attempted to source extra tips for them, to ensure a more stable fit. I googled and read up on others’ attempts, and began to order some third party foam tips to try. I contacted all the dealers in my area to find Sony’s own replacement tips, but these are not to be found. One googled tip (!) was to buy a cheap pair of Sony earbuds for $12 and use the assortment of tips with these as future replacements, as Sony uses the same tips on all its buds. So, worried that if I were to keep the buds for a while, and that finding future replacements might be difficult, I went ahead and bought a pair. But hey presto, the tips had the same inner diameter but were shorter, so this solution didn’t work. Then I just stopped in my tracks and thought: wait a minute. I shouldn't have to be doing this. Sony is producing an expensive piece of electronics without marketing spares. One could cynically imagine them sending out one of many messages here (add your own): 1) Our silicon tips will last for ever so you dont need replacements, which is why we don't market replacement sets of tips; 2) we are leaving it to third party manufacturers to find better solutions; 3) when the tips are worn out then so are the buds so buy a new pair…. and so on and so on. What’s the thinking here? Finally I returned them to my vendor. As I walked out of the shop I spotted a returns bin with 18 sets of these earbuds that had been returned and were reduced. Seems I am not alone. Hopefully Sony are listening, and solve this issue, perhaps by including a rubber hook or extension (together with microphone issues that many have complained about). I eagerly await the next incarnation. Methinks these were rolled out just a tad too early. Shame. What amazing sounding earbuds.
Everything I read was true of this product.

column8: the comfort and the adjustable noise cancellation
column9: the comfort and the adjustable noise cancellation it brings you are great performed, however sometimes one side would shortly disconnect due to the source is in pocket (in a frequency of twice a day).

Both the Apple Airpods Pro and the Sony WF-1000XM3 wireless earbuds had very good reviews so I decided to purchase both and see which one worked for me. Sound: I have been in audio engineering for 40 years but honestly sound is a very personal thing. Some people like heavy bass while I prefer a genuine full spectrum experience, as if I were sitting in front of a live orchestra. That said, I suspect the Sony earbuds will make the bass aficionado very happy. In my opinion they lacked a full range experience while the Apple was very refreshing making every instrument stand out, even the softest notes. Both had good quality as far as NO distortion even at max volume. Speaking of volume, the Sony could not achieve the same loudness as the Apple. (I should also point out that I was using an Apple iPad Pro as my source device, not that it "would or should" make a difference) The Apple also had better clarity most likely because the Sony bass drowns everything else out making it sound a bit muddy. Comfort: In my opinion the Apple wins this one hands down. The Sony is much heavier and seems to run a bit hot as my ears literally burn when I use them. I can't imagine trying to listen long term with the Sony while the Apple earbuds feel very comfortable for the long haul. They both have different size buds that can be interchanged very easily. The Sony has more options and even has two different materials that might appeal to someone who has skin allergy. The down side of the Apple might be that because they are so light it might be easier to loose them however if one the Apple buds fall out, the sound comes to a halt on both which is very nice. Another thing to point out for the athletic type is that the Apple is sweat resistant where the Sony is not. Function and Control: I hate to keep harping on the Sony but once again it mostly fails in this category. One thing the Sony has that I truly like is the ability to pass through external sounds by simply touching and holding the left bud. This also pauses what you are listening to while you attend to the interruption. Once you release your finger it resumes your music or whatever you are listening to. Unfortunately the Sony tap (touch) control for pausing, advancing and changing sound modes are hit or miss at best. Sometimes it works and sometimes it doesn't making for a very frustrating experience. The Apple has a little microswitch on each bud that consistently works as advertised. Either left or right bud of the Apple perform the same function while the left and right buds of the Sony have unique functions. The Apple has a seal test that you can run in the app settings to help you get a good fit. UPDATE: After loading the latest firmware the controls are much better for the Sony. No other improvements noted. Carrying Case: On both of these the case function as an integral part of the system. They both have internal batteries that charge the buds while the buds are in the case. The Apple case is a bit smaller and lighter making it the better choice for my pocket. The Apple can also be charged wirelessly or by USB cable where the Sony must use a cable only. The Sony is more stylish and feels more expensive. I haven't yet tested battery run time but from what I've read, they are both similar. Summary: Overall the Apple is my pick and makes me very happy. I'm sure there are many more options one might consider concerning either of these brands but this is just my experience in a nutshell and I hope it is helpful.

Ear secureness is a deal breaker. I'll be returning mine. I'm a sony fan. but they really need to make next model have a ear hook in my opinion. Who wants to risk a 230 pair of ear buds to fall and break within the first day or week. I sure dont. Everything that this product offers is pointless without ear secureness.
Best ear buds ever

The battery life is great. I really like how easy it is to retrieve them from the case and insert into my ear. They easily make a connection however sometimes the connection will lose and then reconnect. The noise cancellation is terrible on these. It think it is primarly a marketing gimmick to get people (like me to purchase). My biggest issue with these buds is that they will fall out of my ear. It seems like this is a design problem that the manufacturer needs to address. The buds needs to be more stable in the ear canal and they should not slip out. This is a big issue if you are trying to workout and listen to music.

column8: Sounds fantastic! Unstable connection in certain conditions. Poor call quality
column9: Pro: I got these mostly for when I travel for work. They perform great while listening to music during air travel due to the noise cancelling, clean sound and decent battery life (I generally only have a 6 hour commute from door to door and the app was reporting 30% charge left on buds). The buds charge very quickly in the case, so longer commutes shouldn't be an issue. Con: There was significant interference in lower Manhattan while walking around the streets in certain areas (audio choppy and cuts in/out). While annoying, the issue was isolated and fortunately only in areas I was passing through briefly. Another issue is with hands-free call quality being pretty much unusable in areas with moderate to significant ambient noise (crowds, music, etc..). The caller reports hearing the ambient sound far overpowering my voice which sounded muffled and distant. There has been a recent patch to address this issue, but I haven't yet confirmed any improvement first hand. Personal note: Careful with these little guys. If your hands are dry, it can be difficult to get a good grip on the bud when removing from the case. I dropped them more than once while removing and since they are black, they can be difficult to locate.

column8: The best sounding true wireless buds I’ve tried
column9: I have been listening to these for 2-3 hours now after purchasing and updating to the latest firmware. I am by no means a sound snob.. but wow these things sound fantastic. However, for the price tag.. I’m pretty disappointed to report that they have frequent cutouts. It’s just momentary sub-second blips here and there, but IMO unacceptable. Now I’ll have to weigh the amazing sound against the connection quality and decide whether to keep them. (Setting is set to prioritize stable connection) I have experienced several different true wireless earbuds over the years, including Bose Soundsports, Apple AirPods 1 & 2, Anker Zolo liberty plus and now my first Sony buds.. I just wish another company could match the insanely reliable connection you get with the AirPods (quite literally don’t believe either gen has ever cut out on me) These Sony buds are definitely the best sounding ones though, so there’s that ——- updated after additional use I increased my rating from 3 stars to 4. After using them more over the last week or two, the connection stability has been better. There are still a few random cutouts, but not that bad. I also experienced an occurrence where the right bud was very quiet. No idea what happened there, installed them back into the case, put back in my ears and all was back to normal.

These right and left ear units seem to work fine as listen-only headphones but they have a very annoying problem with gating my speech when in a conversation. I am told that the first syllable or two of my speech is cut off as I start to talk (and that I sound like I am in a barrel). Also, when connected to my Late 2018 Mac mini the mode feature is unavailable, that is, I cannot switch between Ambient Mode on and Ambient Mode off and Noise Cancel Mode. Also, sometimes the audio in the left earpiece simple stops even though I am only 3 feet away from the computer. And sometimes when connecting to my Mac mini the earphones repeatedly report "Bluetooth connected", over and over every few seconds, but the device does not show up in the Bluetooth device list on the computer. Very frustrating. The Active Noise Cancellation feature is very weak, the effect only works on lower frequencies and then only to a small degree. I would say that if you compare the Active Noise Cancellation of these devices to the passive noise cancellation of those little foam ear plugs that you can buy at a drug store for $1 then these devices are maybe 10% as effective in comparison.

column8: Great Noise Cancelling. Sounds very good. Mic and Bluetooth Connectivity are Awful.
column9: The primary use of my purchase was for business. Specifically audio conference calls and video conference calls. But, I also listen to music throughout the day. Pros: Noise Cancelling worked surprisingly well. Sound is really good. Look/Feel/Case are all excellent Cons: Quality of the mic, especially with any outside noise is atrocious. My first call was a call in my vehicle. Unfortunately, I had to completely disconnect bluetooth as they could not hear what I was saying on the other side. It's like the noise of the vehicle going down the road was so magnified that it overwhelmed my voice. I tried another call with a different person and it had the same result. Connectivity Issues - Random connects and disconnects between the phone and the earbuds, even with the phone sitting on my office desk. In addition, I experienced times where the right earbud would intermittently disconnect , like it was having connectivity issues between the two earbuds. This all happening when sitting at my desk. For me, because of the poor mic and the connectivity issues, they are pretty much useless for any kind of business use requiring voice and connection stability. Notes: Keep in mind these do not support multi-channel bluetooth, meaning although you can pair with up too 8 devices, you can only be connected to one device at a time. For instance, if you are listening to music on your laptop and someone calls your phone, you can't answer your phone with the earbuds. Instead you would have to pull out your earbud and put your phone up to your ear. There are other bluetooth devices that support this feature. Once again, limits flexibility for business use.

The sound on these headphones are amazing, but in my experience I could not enjoy this because they could not stay in my ears :( their center of gravity sticks out way to far and easily fall out, even with all the sizes and materials given. The touch pad along the side was a pain to use. The app was easy to use, even though you don’t need to use it. Another down side is NO ONE knows how to where them. I cant hand these to a friend for the first time without showing them how to put it on so they don’t fall out, or so they can deliver the best sound and noise cancelling. I just wished they stayed in my ear for the most part 😤 AirPod pros are much much more comfortable and deliver almost as good of sound (after a bit of EQ)

column8: The best ... If you set them up correctly
column9: UNBOXING: The first thing to do is to find the correct fit. This, like it has always been for in-ear buds, is a trial and error process. Out of the box, Sony provides you with six pair of tips - 3 pairs of silicone ones and 3 pairs of memory foam ones. I have large ears with almighty ear canals, and based on my past experience with other in-ear buds, I went for the large memory foam tips. These turned out to be too big, and the earphones dangled precariously off my ears. So I swapped them with the medium foam tips; this gave me the perfect and the most comfortable tip. The next thing I did was pop the earphones back into the case, and the case to a power supply so that both the case and the buds charged to 100%. I already had the companion Sony Headphones app on my phone, but if you don't, you can download it. Once they were charged, I launched the Sony Headphones app, went through the connection wizard, tapped my phone on the case (NFC) and that's it. They were paired - a very hassle free, and a no tech challenge process, which anyone can do. Bluetooth connectivity was perfect. I could roam around anywhere in my 1 room kitchen apartment without losing connectivity. Once these babies were paired, I popped them into my ear, and then launched the companion app to configure them. CONFIGURATION & PLAYBACK: Right out of the box, this pair provides a very neutral sound-stage with clear mids, though the highs can be very tinny and the lows quite muffled. This might make some people to take the knee jerk reaction of returning them as they do not sound all that well for the price. Well, don't, and have patience. Configure them to suit yourself, and that's how you'll get the best out of them. Configuration depends on the kind of music you listen to, and hence this step is critical. Personally, I'm not beholden to a particular genre, which makes this stage of the onboarding a bit difficult. I launched the Youtube music app, and started cycling through some of my favorite songs in the metal, pop, vocal, reggaeton, hip-hop, EDM and trap genres. To give an idea: I cycled through songs by Pink Floyd, Paradise Lost, John Legend, Post Malone, Nicky Jam, Alan Walker, Lil Nas X, Skrillex, Flosstradamus, Fever Ray, Florence + The Machine & Eminem. And post that, I went to work with the Equalizer, tweaking it while cycling through the same songs to find the perfect blend of settings that can achieve the sweet spot of a great sound-stage applicable to all these genres. My final equalizer settings for the slider bars: +4, +2, -2, -2, 0 with Clear Bass set to +8. I found that these settings gave me the best sound-stage across all the genres (of course, these won't be perfect for any one genre, but it is either that, or tweak them according to the genre that you listen to). I also set DSEE HX to ON, since this allows for the audio stream to be upscaled to simulate a high resolution stream - a good to have feature if you listen to streamed audio like I do. With the afore mentioned settings, I found that I retained the clear mids, but I was also able to deepen the lows and make the highs sound natural. USAGE: The drivers do taking some burn-in, and I started hearing a slight upgrade in quality after the first 10-12 hours of use. This was the same for my WH-1000XM3s, which sound absolutely wonderful after 4 months of use. While this pair is great on the ears while traveling (I sweat quite a bit, and the over-ear cans become uncomfortable for me), I'd still prefer the WH-1000XM3 if I'm at my desk working, or if I'm in an airplane traveling, because there is definitely some ear fatigue (which is typical for in-ears). The fit, once you have achieved it correctly as described in the first part of this review, is secure, and I did not feel any risk of these falling off. I would definitely not take this pair out for jogging or any gym exercises, since they are not water resistant, and the fit is not secure enough to handle strenuous activities of jumping, running, etc. CONCLUSION: All in all, this is a great pair, and well worth the price, if you have the patience to configure them according to your specific use cases. I highly recommend both the models from Sony, both are winners in my book, and I hope to use them for many years. PS: If you use the Tidal app, it's probably a good idea to go through the 360 degree music setup. I don't, and hence I didn't.
My brother loves them he said they are far superior to beats in every way

What I particularly love about these and their big brother Sony over the ear headphones is the ambient mode. I use these and the others in a variety of situations, but when walking the dogs the ambient mode is worth its weight in gold. I walk in a neighborhood with narrow streets, no sidewalks and a certain percentage of drivers going to fast. The ambient mode lets me listen to great sounding music, etc., but still hear a car coming from behind. If fact, the car sound is louder than no headphones so it’s like super hearing. I’m safer with them than without. How they do that while whatever you’re playing remains sounding so good is remarkable.

column8: I REALLY wanted to love these.
column9: The sound quality of these headphones are exceptional. and the level of control you have with the built in app is great. However I have a very active Lifestyle and these just don't keep up. The signal strength when you go to the gym around other Bluetooth users completely falls apart. My cheap old Samsung Buds held a much better signal in crowded environments. So every time I go to the gym I keep finding myself using my Beats Solo 3 headphones since they can keep a connection. I also ride a motorcycle and these are difficult to get in the helmet, and not quite loud enough unfortunately. But if you have a slower lifestyle. Or are buying these for wearing around the office or house and want AMAZING sound quality. These things are the best. Noise Cancellation blew me away. The pass through is cool but i don't use it. Battery life has not been an issue at all. I unfortunately will be heading back to bestbuy to return these today. I just ordered the Airpod Pros, Hopefully those have better signal strength at the gym. They should also fit in my motorcycle helmet a little better.

I feel so bad giving such a low review for these because the sound quality is epic! However, these things are horrible to wear. I own the Apple Air pod Pro and bought these because they are far superior in noise cancellation. The problem with these Sony EarPods is they are HUGE and do NOT stay in my ears. I am a city dweller in NYC and wear a hooded coat. These stupid things fall out constantly when my hood even grazes them. This does not work for me at all. Even when my hair style grazes them, they fall out. I wore them for one workday and wanted to scream. It was so frustrating. I tried every adapter and none of them worked. You put these deep in your ear and twist and they are supposed to stay but they don’t. They would be ok if you are very still and stationary. The connectivity was crap also. The phone would ring in my ear so I would tap my watch to answer because I have a hood on and can’t touch the ear pods but the voice would switch to the watch???? How frustrating! I tried answering a call by tapping my phone and the same thing happened; the voice switched to the phone. These things need work. The case needs wireless charging capability, they need a lower profile design and fit so they stay in and the connectivity needs fixed. I am back to the Apple AirPods and can put my hood on and off no problem...ever!

Can't keep them in my head. Tried all sizes of fittings. They also drop out and in with my phone. Not sure what that's about. I think the sound of the Jabra 75t was better and they fit better, but didn't work well with Alexa. I spent more for these Sonys. I really wanted to like these but by the time you grind them in to your ear hard enough to stay in for 5 minutes your ear hurts.
